name: Der Präsident. –

name: Der Präsident. –
text: Ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for your excellent work. Today we remember the people who were murdered 20 years ago in the massacre in the Bosnian town of Srebrenica. 8 000 boys and men were systematically and bestially killed within a few days, in the middle of Europe. In front of the world, Srebrenica was the worst war crime in Europe since the end of the Second World War – an act of genocide that should never have happened, a collective failure of the international community that still deeply shames us to this day. We bow to the victims. On behalf of the European Parliament, I extend our deepest sympathy to their families, to the bereaved. To this day, not all those murdered have been given justice. To this day, not even all those killed have found a final resting place. That is why we want to continue to fight to ensure that the victims and their bereaved people get the justice they deserve. In 2007, the Massacre was finally classified as genocide by the International Criminal Court. This was an important milestone, especially because the massacre took place in an area declared safe by the United Nations and became a symbol of an international community overwhelmed by serious human rights violations. We in the European Parliament have already taken a position on the Srebrenica genocide twice: in 2005 and 2009. At that time, we remembered all the victims of war crimes in the former Yugoslavia. Today, 20 years later, we are renewing our commitment: we will not forget Srebrenica. For reconciliation cannot exist without memory. Reconciliation can only take place if experienced suffering and pain are acknowledged, if we remember how poisoned rhetoric and populist incitement pave the way for ethnic cleansing, if we remember how the multi-ethnic and multi-religious roots of the Balkans were denied – with the aim of redrawing borders. We are determined to stand in the way of all those who want to resurrect old demons and cause trouble again. Therefore, ladies and gentlemen, commemorative events are important in order to remember that the destructive forces are always alive. I have asked my colleague, Vice-President Lunacek, to represent the European Parliament next week at the commemorative event in Srebrenica on 11 July. The European Parliament is working tirelessly for a European perspective on the Western Balkans, partly because a secure and stable neighbourhood is in our own interests. The door to Europe is open to those who are following the path of democracy and the rule of law, who also see reconciliation as a key to security and cooperation in the Western Balkans. I would ask you, ladies and gentlemen, to rise from your seats in memory of the victims of Srebrenica. (The House rose and observed a minute's silence)

name: Der Präsident. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the oral question (O-000075/2015) to the Commission on the subject: first response to the Commission's Green Paper on the creation of a Capital Markets Union by Roberto Gualtieri and Burkhard Balz on behalf of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs (2015/2634(RSP) - B8-0564/2015).

name: Roberto Gualtieri
text: Author. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner Hill, with this resolution, the European Parliament is expressing strong and strong support for the project for a Capital Markets Union. It is a first contribution to the setting of the agenda of the European institutions and an action plan of the Commission. The Capital Markets Union is a key component of a broader strategy to support growth and financial stability; it can allow greater diversification of financing channels to the economy, which must be complementary and not a substitute for bank financing, an incentive for a more efficient allocation of financial resources through the internal market, regardless of the geographical location of the lender or borrower, and can encourage better risk sharing and better shock absorption. In particular, we believe that the Capital Markets Union is particularly necessary in order to promote the development, growth and internationalisation of small and medium-sized enterprises and to encourage the channelling of financial resources towards long-term investments in support of the real economy, growth and development.  We agree with the Commission on the need for an approach which is both ambitious but pragmatic and practical. And, therefore, we also set out a broader, more forward-looking vision, but we fully support the first steps that the Commission has indicated. The resolution is very rich, mr Burkhard Balz will certainly help to explain it. I would like to highlight just a few points: of course, full support, as I have said, for the establishment of standards for high-quality securitisation, revision of the prospectus directive but also standardisation of certain financial instruments, support for access to information on companies, in particular unsused ones – on a voluntary basis, of course, but we can also think of a database and perhaps even an agency – and then we deal with , in fact, the most complex issues, such as the regulation on insolvency, the issue of taxation and, of course, the challenge of moving towards strengthening supervision to the goal of single supervision. In short, Parliament is ready to play its part. We are here and will actively contribute to the definition and implementation of a concrete roadmap for the Capital Markets Union.

name: Burkhard Balz
text: Author. Mr President, I would like to thank the The Capital Markets Union is an important project for this legislature. We support the Capital Markets Union because it promises greater diversification in the sources of funding for the European economy, because it wants to improve access to capital for small and medium-sized enterprises and because it can strengthen the internal market for financial services for the benefit of consumers. In other words, we support the objectives of a Capital Markets Union. At the same time, however, we also have clear demands for implementation. We do not give the Commission a blank cheque. From our point of view, the following is particularly important: we call for a holistic approach. The Capital Markets Union is not a substitute for bank financing, its task is to complement and strengthen proven financing models. It is therefore essential that the Capital Markets Union should involve financial intermediaries such as banks and insurance companies. Secondly, we call for a European approach. The Capital Markets Union is not a banking union, it must apply equally to the entire European market. We do not want to copy the models of third countries, but to develop an approach that fits into our European funding culture. And we are calling for a comprehensive analysis. The Capital Markets Union should be effective where there are barriers to capital market financing. These hurdles need to be analysed to see if they exist in the individual Member States or in the EU. The Capital Markets Union must learn from past mistakes. What went wrong in capital market financing during the 2007/2008 financial crisis must not happen again. Fourthly, we are calling for real benefits for small and medium-sized enterprises. The Capital Markets Union must not get lost in the small details of a set of rules, but must implement what it promises: better access to finance and better regulation for small and medium-sized enterprises. What is clear to us is that a Capital Markets Union can only improve the investment climate in Europe if further basic conditions are right. This includes, in particular, a stable economic policy environment based on economic reform and debt reduction.

name: Jonathan Hill
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, this is an important moment for the capital markets union (CMU), and I would like to thank Mr Gualtieri and Mr Balz for setting out the issues facing us so clearly. This is a classic single market project for all 28 Member States: for those without developed capital markets, as well as for those with. Indeed, I would argue that it is Member States without strong capital markets which could stand to gain the most, because CMU will help create the conditions for capital to flow across borders and to SMEs, no matter where they are. To help this flow, we will look at venture capital, at angel investing, at crowd-funding and at private placement. It is, as we have already heard, a major priority of the CMU to broaden the range of financing options for SMEs, to complement banking, and to improve the funding conveyor belt. We have all seen examples of European ideas and European businesses going to the United States for their funding. I want those businesses to stay and grow here in Europe. We will review our Venture Capital Regulation; we will strengthen our venture capital industry; we will review the Prospectus Directive to make it easier for larger SMEs to raise money on the public markets; we will seek to free up bank balance sheets by reviving the EU market for securitisation through the identification of simple, transparent and standardised securitisations. That will help banks to lend more, including to SMEs. We are also looking at how we could improve SME credit information to make it easier for SMEs to attract investment. I think that Members of this committee know better than anyone about the steps taken over the last five years to improve the regulation of capital markets. Your resolution also rightly argues that we should take stock of the overall impact of financial regulation and be proportionate in our measures, and I agree with that. On supervision, respondents to the consultation argued that the ESA’s existing set of powers are sufficient, but some also called for greater supervisory convergence to ensure a level playing field. We also need to consider our overall macro-prudential framework. In terms of next steps, we are on track to publish our action plan in September. Concrete proposals will follow shortly afterwards. They will include a comprehensive package on securitisation, with updated calibrations for Solvency II and CRR, the definition of infrastructure and revised calibrations for Solvency II, and these proposals to review the Prospectus Directive. This is an ambitious programme. It will require sustained effort over a number of years, but we need to make quick progress, so I hope that these first proposals can be fast-tracked by the co-legislators. I look forward to developing this project with you, but most of all, I look forward to helping more European businesses, especially SMEs, get the funding they want, in order to increase choices for savers, to strengthen cross-border investment and also, I believe, to increase financial stability.

name: Pablo Zalba Bidegain
text: PPE Group. – Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, the latest developments in Greece these days are proof that we need more Europe, that is, more economic integration, more fiscal union and, ultimately, more political union — that is, with the same rules — and more economic growth. And the single capital market is precisely one of the instruments for achieving and reconciling both objectives. Because the single capital market will improve the allocation of financial resources between the different countries of the European Union. And also because, as Commissioner Hill has said, it will improve the financing of small and medium-sized enterprises, a real driver of economic growth and job creation. This is the way, ladies and gentlemen. Let us not deceive European citizens. Removing it from a sovereign debt that has an average gap of sixteen years will not boost growth. With growth, sovereign debt will be sustainable. Without growth, it hardly will be. And for growth, to boost economic growth, we know what we need to do: reforms at the national level — my country, Spain, it is an example — and more Europe, more economic integration, I insist. And the Capital Markets Union is a first and great step in moving in that direction. (He agreed to answer a question posed under the 'blue card' procedure (Article 162(8) of the Regulation))

name: David Coburn (EFDD)
text: blue-card question. – I wonder if the gentleman might agree with me that the reason that London’s capital markets are so successful is that they are not completely dominated by the European Union. Any interference from this House, making problems for our capital markets, is not desirable because it is not capitalist-inclined, it is socialist-inclined, and that does not sit well with worldwide financial markets. Would the gentleman agree with me?

name: Pablo Zalba Bidegain (PPE)
text: "blue card" response. – Your Honor, I do not agree. The single capital market is an important tool to improve the competitiveness of our economy and to boost growth and job creation. And the basis of its success, no doubt, will be that it encompasses the whole of the European Union; not only the euro area, but the entire European Union.

name: Pervenche Berès
text: On behalf of the Group of S and D- - Mr President, Commissioner, it is important that the European Parliament can decide before the Commission writes its roadmap for a capital market.  Before you get any more involved in this project, I would like to draw your attention to four points. The first is to remember what happened in banking. You cannot build up a capital market without increasing the power, at the same time, supervision that is appropriate to the progress you want to make. You said you wanted these capital markets for financial stability. You will then need to strengthen the European character of supervision and regulation of these capital markets. In the same way, you will be forced to look at what is happening in shadow banking, otherwise you will create bubbles and speculative tools that will not serve the noble goals you display. The second dimension that needs to be taken into account is the specific disinterest in the euro area. We cannot pretend that the capital markets are totally ignorant of the currencies in which they operate. Now, you know, you have a real challenge in your hands.  With regard to the third dimension, you are telling us that all of this is to enable SMEs to have better access to capital markets. Is. But we must also use such an approach to direct capital flows where we believe we need them to finance the European project. From this point of view, there is a priority in terms of the imperatives that are related to a strategy for the ecological transition that you must carry and that you must have in mind when you move forward on the path of these capital markets. Finally, one last observation, I have seen almost nowhere, in your texts, the question of taxation. However, I think we cannot talk about a capital union without talking about taxation. I am waiting for your proposals to that effect.

name: Philippe De Backer
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, Commissioner, the capital markets union is an important part of the EU single market project. Its primary goal should really be to increase not only the diversity that companies have in looking for different ways of funding, but also the diversity that investors have in allocating their assets, especially in the longer term. Today we have entered a new era, and this is something that is also mentioned in your green paper: we have shifted from financial stability more into a position where we look at growth and job creation. It is also important to use the review clauses that you have at your disposal in the different legislative acts which have been adopted over the last couple of years to recalibrate and fine tune the system, to keep the stability that we have, while increasing the power, the diversity and the funding options for all in the markets. Second point: the capital markets union should really serve to remove barriers to private placements and crowd-funding, as well as to allow for the scalability of companies. We talk a lot about SMEs, but we also need mid-caps, we also need IPOs – I was the president of the IPO Task Force. We also need to keep our companies listed in Europe: the competence stays here and the financing stays here. This is also really important. Last point: we also have to make sure that we increase retail investors’ availability. We have seen them moving outside of the market – institutions as well – due to Solvency II and other regulations. We have to take a really good look at why, today, they are no longer investing in our markets. One of the issues there – and it is one of the things that is lacking in your plan – is the fact that you have not talked about, for example, the possibility of a pan-European private pension savings plan. This would facilitate the accumulation of the savings of many retail investors and the building of a true base for a capital markets union all across the European Union. The last point I would like to make is that we have to take a good look at how regulators are functioning. The gold-plating and the differences are really hampering the single market, and they should be tackled. So we have a lot of work, but our group is in full support of your endeavours, and we hope in September to see concrete proposals that we can support.

name: Fabio De Masi
text: Mr President, I would like to like to sanendour sto -- on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, I would like to thank the The Capital Markets Union is supposed to cure one of Europe's diseases: too little investment and banks that do not lend. But if you want to cure a disease, you first have to understand the causes of the disease before you agree on a medicine. And the reason for weak lending in the banking sector is precisely that we have had austerity in Europe, that wages have fallen, that pensions have fallen, that government spending has fallen. In such an environment, there is no dynamic demand for credit. The reason why banks do not lend was precisely due to the fact that they promoted, for example, a dubious securitisation market. If the Commission is just saying 'we want to promote simple, safe, transparent products', it must first answer why there is no private market for these products. This obviously does not exist because the risks are too high for market participants. That is why we say that the Capital Markets Union does not fit into the European landscape. There are reasons why Europe has always had a bank-centred economic system, because banks are more able to meet the needs of small and medium-sized enterprises. Banks that know the investment risks, while in the US they are larger economic units. That's why you shouldn't compare apples to oranges. We reject the Capital Markets Union. It is the wrong remedy for Europe's disease.

name: Sven Giegold
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, first of all, I would like to say that our group supports the basic idea of a capital markets union. We know that there are problems and that those problems have not become any smaller with the financial crisis. Our financial market has become more fragmented. Therefore, I think that the Commissioner has picked up on the right idea. At the same time, one has to be careful that we do not disappoint citizens by presenting expectations this project cannot meet. There is the danger that efforts like the capital markets union and developing open capital markets could be misunderstood to mean that it would largely replace the provision of credit to SMEs. For the reasons which have been mentioned, small businesses – also in the US – depend largely on banks and will continue to do so. It makes sense to complement their funding possibilities, and the Commission proposal also makes sense. However, what we can achieve will be limited if we do not tackle the biggest problems in Europe. The biggest problems for the opening of capital markets are clearly issues such as taxation, insolvency law or accounting rules. This will not change, and the Commission is not proposing to change it. Therefore, please do not promise too much. But I have one message for the Commission. I think it is important to reconcile this project with European values. This means that long-term funding and green bonds should not be governed by specialised instruments, but capital markets above a certain size should show that they have moved away from CO2 and are investing for the long term. Therefore, there should be ratings attached to it which truly follow, and give transparency to, European values. That should be part of the mission.

name: Steven Woolfe
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, the Greek people overwhelmingly defied the bullying tactics and anti-democratic tactics of the EU, the ECB and the IMF yesterday. They rejected a disastrous bailout deal created by technocrats in a vacuum detached from the misery of the ordinary Greek people. The euro was the cause of that misery, and it too was created by technocrats in a vacuum detached from the real people and, in this case, the financial markets. This idea of the capital markets union is also one of those technocratic dreams of centralised control; it is being created in a vacuum once again. As Mr Hill said, ‘it is a classic EU plan’. Europe is not a country; it is individual countries with decent people within it. The European technocrats do not, and never will, understand what the people need or what they want. The euro failed Greece because it was a failed plan. The capital markets union will be one of those failures once again. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: blue-card question. – Mr Woolfe, as you come from the UK, I would ask: do you know that the financial system in London City is also basing its activity on the European Union capital markets? The European Union capital markets union could greatly assist the London financial system to develop in the future. By taking the position you have taken, it seems that you are against jobs in London.

name: Steven Woolfe (EFDD)
text: blue-card answer. – Sir, that completely answers my case. You fail to understand that the London market is an international market. It is a capital market with investors from all over the globe coming into London investing in companies all over the globe because they understand the risks in those countries; they understand the risks in those businesses. Unlike in Europe, those businesses are not controlled by the EU; they do not have to take the EU’s negative regulations, they do not have to take the costs of the EU unemployment and they do not have to take all the damaging issues that the EU puts on small, medium-sized and large businesses, which is driving business out of Europe. That is why the rest of the world is succeeding.

name: Gerolf Annemans
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. I would like to join Mr Woolfe and put this debate into perspective, because a normal person really does not think it is possible. The citizens of Europe are now asking themselves: "What is it about the euro? Didn't it all go a little too far? Is this the beginning of the end?" That is what the citizens are asking themselves. "Will it be a Grexit? And if so, will Italy, Portugal follow?" All these debates are currently going on with the public. And what does this Parliament do? Instead of thinking about whether integration has not gone too far and whether, in the end, European integration has not stifling competitiveness and living Europe, we are continuing here as if there is no debate other than that today. We are continuing to integrate. We are going to expand Europe further. 'More Union', that is the european Parliament's response to what happened in Greece yesterday. More Union, in this case the capital union, is the answer we think we can give here in the logic of the European Union. Yes, indeed, a European Union, which is always on the assumption that more Union is always better, whereas the people, when consulted on this, say over and over again: 'No, we need less Union'. Every time a European Parliament is elected, the group of those who say that there should be less European Union grows. And what does this Parliament do? This continues on the path of 'more Union'. The Straitjacket of the European Union is bad for the people. The people know this, but Parliament does not care.

name: Markus Ferber (PPE).
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has First of all, I would like to warmly welcome the Commission's initiative for a Capital Markets Union. I consider this to be an important project in this parliamentary term. However, Commissioner, we must be honest about this, and there is a little more to come. Only through the revision of the Prospectus Directive and the strengthening of the securitisation market will we not achieve a Capital Markets Union in the European Union. We urgently need to take stock of what we have done in the meantime in terms of financial market regulation – as you have announced – and we then need to look at where there is still something missing or– to be honest – where we have perhaps done too much, so that banks can no longer do their job of lending. I would like to mention one key word: when I hear at the moment that the Basel Committee is considering the fact that what we as a Parliament have deliberately created – namely, that a correction factor for SME loans has been introduced – should be reversed, then it is the wrong signal to make it easier for small and medium-sized enterprises to access the capital market. Thirdly, we must ensure that we create greater coherence. We have partly legislated where we use the same terms in different legislative packages that no longer fit together. I am thinking here only of the disclosure requirements in various directives, which we still need to make coherent. And one of the concerns that is very close to my heart and which is very close to your heart, Commissioner, is, of course, the question of how we deal with third countries. They were in the US in the spring and dealt with the subject. We, as the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs, will be in the United States in a few days' time to make some progress here. We recently had the opportunity to discuss this issue with the chief negotiator in connection with the free trade agreement. I believe that a sensible third-country regime, which is more focused on equivalence, is the right answer to strengthen our capital markets in Europe here too.

name: Neena Gill (S&D).
text: – Mr President, my congratulations go to the authors. We have a good paper that demonstrates, in a clear way, the priorities of Parliament on CMU – to increase growth and jobs across the EU – and, more critically, that underlines that growth has to be sustainable and should not prejudice financial stability. I support the emphasis on timing. Given that CMU should have been in place a decade ago, it is high time that we step up a gear on this. Commissioner, you said that in the autumn we are to receive two new regulations on securitisation and the Prospectus Directive. We eagerly await those. However, there are many difficult political obstacles that we need to tackle, and many colleagues have referred to them: the lack of consistent implementation by Member States, the 29 different tax regimes for debt, and likewise for insolvency procedures. Does the Commission have any plans to tackle these in the near future? Furthermore, if we are going to review the CMU over the next four years, is it not an omission not to address the technological innovations in the financial sector? This is evolving very fast, but the regulators and legislators are not keeping up with it. We also have to acknowledge that confidence in the financial services has taken a knock. Perhaps the events of yesterday evening, with the Greek referendum, are not likely to shake that. So how do we restore this position? One way could be if the Commission came forward with an ambitious retail package, tackling the cross-border obstacles that citizens and businesses are faced with in financial services. Many procedures remain a nightmare for retail investors and businesses alike. Let us not forget our overall objective, which is to make the EU an attractive place to do business. (The speaker refused to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: David Coburn (EFDD).
text: – Oh come on, be brave!

name: Sander Loones (ECR).
text: – Europe will indeed have to learn to deal with the new reality after the Greek referendum, just as Greece will have to learn to deal with its dramatic socio-economic situation. The question is not only how Greece can reform, but also how Europe can continue to do so so that we can continue to move forward. One of the most important structural reforms is precisely this capital markets union. How can we promote cross-border investment? How can we ensure that our companies can raise money without necessarily having to walk past the bank? That is why, Commissioner, I wish you every success. Let's do this exercise very thoroughly. But at the same time, let's focus and focus on some quick wins. How can we remove barriers to our businesses? How can we simplify so that our businesses have access to the capital they need to grow and invest? Thank you very much.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, the European Commission considers that its proposal for a single capital market is the solution to the financing problems of the European economy, but this is not the case. During the early years of the euro, banks, among others, boosted with their credit the huge financial bubbles, the consequences of which we still suffer. Despite the billions of euros devoted to bank bailout, which we will never recover, the flow of credit to the real economy remains halted. Opening this flow to major international investment funds will only increase speculation and instability in financing. The problems of the European economy are different and stem from the deep stagnation of demand due to austerity policies, without lack of capital. Pretending that SMEs are financed through complex financial products, rather than credit, seems like a cynicism exercise. Financial markets have failed the European Union and now it is the turn of the public. If no one trembled his pulse in bailing out banks with public money, now he should not shake anyone to boost the economy from the state either. What can save the economy is public investment and public banking to finance SMEs and create jobs.

name: Molly Scott Cato (Verts/ALE).
text: – Mr President, we welcome the capital markets union, the Commission’s flagship project to tackle the problem of under-investment in our productive businesses across the single market. With investment now 70% below its pre-crisis levels, there is an urgent need to invest and particularly to invest in the sustainable sectors of our economy. We support the call for any redesign of capital markets to be orientated towards the needs of small businesses that have been starved of investment, rather than serving the interest of financiers. We will not accept any deregulation in the name of market integration, particularly if it weakens stability or the protection of people’s savings. While strong regulation is essential, it must match the size and scope of the investment and should not be allowed to choke off local investment schemes. In south-west England, which I represent, we are beginning to see the growth of local investment, particularly in community renewables projects. Here the local connection ensures accountability more effectively than a heavily bureaucratic process which might instead undermine these vital green shoots.

name: Marco Zanni (EFDD).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, it is not many years since the start of the financial crisis in which we are still stuck, but perhaps someone has forgotten, or pretends to forget, the causes that have reduced us to these conditions.  The reason why the world economy has found itself on its knees lies, in fact, in the excessive financialisation of the world economy, with the real economy suffering the catastrophic effects of inappropriate and risky financial choices. The solution that Europe wants to propose with the Capital Markets Union seems to be a mockery because we want to restart the economy by focusing again on big capital and finance. The references to SMEs are ridiculous, because we all know that this measure is not designed for them at all and comparisons with the US system are at least inappropriate, because our productive and entrepreneurial fabric is very different. Europe does not seem to want to learn from its mistakes, or perhaps the real objective is to build a Union of capital and finance without having the interests of European citizens and small and medium-sized enterprises at heart.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF).
text: Mr President, Commissioner Hill, I would like to thank the Commissioner for his work and for the work he has The importance of flexible capital markets has only really come to fruition as a result of the financial crisis – a financial crisis from which the US has recovered much better and recovered much faster than Europe – in the US, where banks play a minor role in financing the economy, and the capital market operates faster, more efficiently, and more easily.  That is why Europe also needs a diversified capital market, capital markets that have better access to capital for small and medium-sized enterprises. Yves Mersch put it in a nutshell with a quote that I would like to reproduce. He said: "The European economy is like an aircraft that only tries to fly with a turbine – with bank financing." In order to strengthen the speed and stability of this aircraft, a second engine is needed, namely capital market financing, and so it is: in the USA, medium-sized companies have five times more funding from capital markets than European SMEs. It is therefore not surprising that more and more European growth companies are raising money in the US, going to the US to operate in attractive private placement markets. The same goes for startups when they are big enough. When they are small, they need crowdfunding, but also with professional venture capital – there is no such thing in Europe.  Some key figures, bank financing versus capital market financing: seventy percent bank financing in Europe, thirty percent in the United States. This makes it clear that we need alternative financial instruments. The European economy needs a diversified capital market, a stable financing system and easier access to capital. This is the only way to create growth and employment.

name: Danuta Maria Hübner (PPE).
text: – Mr President, taking into account how limited the current role of capital markets in financing the real economy is, how fragmented they are and how shallow they are in many growth—hungry Member States, there is a chance that, in your effort to build a genuine European capital markets union, you can get it right. You can strike the right balance – right from the beginning – between regulation, self-regulation, good practices and market forces. I hope you will be able to mobilise all those vehicles. We expect proposals that foster the harmonisation of standards, reduce complexity and perhaps identify new asset classes, should we want to invest, for example, in energy infrastructure. There has been a lot of talk about SMEs and securitisation. There are many methods by which the ability of SMEs, start-ups and mid-caps to access funding can be improved. You mentioned them. I also understand that you will go beyond securitisation towards venture capital and towards focusing on providing information, and on making information more standardised. I would also encourage you to take a step towards establishing accounting standards for SMEs.

name: Jonás Fernández (S&D).
text: – Mr President, thank you very much, Commissioner. I believe that the document discussed and adopted in the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs on the future of the capital market is well oriented. I congratulate Mr Gualtieri and Mr Balz on their agreement, on their wording, but there are three things which concern me in relation to the Green Paper presented by the Commission. The first is the absence, I believe, of adequate reflection on the euro area's relationship with the rest of the Union. Forgetting that a substantial part of Europe is based on the euro area, that the euro can be a key element in organising a true capital market, I believe it would require additional reflection, a public debt issuance that would allow for risk-free assets. In any case, beyond this, the capital market wants or should regularize shadow banking, which in the end is non-bank financing. And I would like to ask the Commissioner what legislative initiatives he hopes to send us in order to achieve efficient regulation of that non-bank market, including taxation, in addition to insolvency proceedings. There is a very important financial regulation agenda to try to ensure that these non-bank markets have a clear and efficient order, and in recent months we have learned that the Commission does not feel like implementing many legislative initiatives, but in this area it is essential, in taxation, at any point to make that market work. (He agreed to answer a question posed under the 'blue card' procedure (Article 162(8) of the Regulation))

name: Steven Woolfe (EFDD)
text: blue-card question. – I have a very simple question. You congratulated the rapporteur and shadow rapporteur on an excellent green paper, but is growth in Europe caused by the fact that we do not have a capital markets union, or is it caused by the fact that our companies are uncompetitive because they are over-regulated and highly taxed and have huge levels of uncompetitiveness between countries? It is one or the other. Which one are you choosing?

name: Jonás Fernández (S&D)
text: "blue card" response. – Mr Woolfe, obviously I do not share your view that Europe is not growing because there is too much regulation. I believe that Europe has to have a clear regulatory order. That, in this case, to get that capital market unit forward, we need a legal environment. And I simply recommend or encourage you to clearly defend your constitution, your representatives, because I believe that the United Kingdom would have much to gain if we were able to organise a joint European market.

name: Stanisław Ożóg (ECR).
text: – Mr President, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for his excellent Commissioner, i would like to thank you for your comments. It should be noted that recent developments in the regulatory environment have increased the administrative burden on businesses, which may have the effect of reducing the benefits of traditional investment activities. I believe that, before new regulations are introduced, it would first be necessary to carry out an impact assessment and an analysis of the costs of implementation. In my opinion, the European approach should only be applied when the objectives set are not acho feasible with national resources.  I support the construction of a Capital Markets Union, but I stress once again that it should, in my opinion, be based on local capital markets and should focus on facilitating the movement of capital between existing markets rather than centralising them. I think it is also worth stressing the need for typical financial education in order to increase investor confidence, particularly retail and private, in capital markets.

name: Marco Valli (EFDD).
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, small businesses, those that create jobs, are linked to the traditional credit system and this system has been disintegrated by universal banks by extreme financialisation associated with the crazy euro project which, with austerity policies, has created imbalances and destruction of the internal market of European countries, unemployment, hunger and misery. As long as we continue to focus on finance and greed over a traditional banking system, we will create more and more inequality. And that's where the point is: inequality. At a time when we are focusing on who holds capital and who, in fact, has every interest in speculating about investing in the future, we will never be able to get ourselves out of the two main problems facing Europe at the moment, which are poverty and unemployment. We must focus on a credit bank project, on a functional bank project and no longer focus on finance, otherwise we will always have a crisis and it will always be the taxpayers who will have to pay.

name: Gunnar Hökmark (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I think this document by Mr Balz and Mr Gualtieri is a very good one. It is extremely important that we get deeper capital markets in Europe, but I always get a little sceptical when people say that we are to launch a capital markets union. I would like to disclose to this plenary that we already have a capital markets union: it is called the European Union, and its aim is for an internal market and the free flow of goods, capital services and people. I say this because this discussion is very much about the shortcomings of the past, where we have not been able to get rid of the hindrances, barriers and fragmentation. We do have well-functioning capital markets in the Union, here and there, which are rather deep and which are providing the capital. The problem is not the amount of liquidity but the amount of profitable investments. There are some things we need to do in order to improve the capital markets of the European Union. First of all, we should skip the idea of the financial transaction tax. Secondly, we need to have a review of all the legislation we have dealt with so far: some good, some maybe not so good, and some which hinders. We need to ensure that we are not regulating in a way that creates hindrances and that we are opening up for the free flow of capital – that is the way to get more investments.

name: Olle Ludvigsson (S&D).
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr I look postively at the construction of a Capital Markets Union. It would be useful to reduce corporate banking dependency. In the countries where banks have crashed, small businesses in particular have been dragged into the case. This, in turn, has crippled parts of the real economy. The system should not be that sensitive. It would also be useful if a number of cross-border barriers could be dismantled. This part of the internal market is severely underused. There is a great European potential just waiting to be safeguarded. At the same time, it is important to also see the risks. It must not be the case that the Capital Markets Union develops into a mere liberalisation agenda – for example, in the area of securitisation. Weakening key regulatory frameworks could jeopardise financial stability. We must certainly not end up there.

name: Antonio Tajani (PPE).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, access to credit and lack of investment are two of the problems that businesses face if they really want to support the real economy and solve these problems. There is a clear lack of investment in Europe and, of course, capital is needed to make investments. It is not enough for the banks: it is therefore necessary to unblock those instruments that are not used through alternative forms of financing and therefore also to make greater use of risk capital, but I am also thinking of an increasing use of pension funds. However, if demand is not linked to supply, i.e. investors to small and medium-sized enterprises, these measures will not be enough. There is a lack of information for small and medium-sized enterprises, but even investors do not know what the potential is within 24 million European small and medium-sized enterprises. We therefore need to improve the flow and quality of data on small and medium-sized enterprises in order to satisfy the thirst for information that is there.  So why not create an instrument, which can be a telematics platform, can be a lean agency, to collect, analyse and disseminate data on small and medium-sized enterprises and therefore an exchange of information between businesses and capital? This instrument would therefore be a bridge between entrepreneurs, businesses and investors, assessing the need for credit and the growth potential of Europe's small and medium-sized enterprises. It could be an initiative designed to group small and medium-sized enterprises into traditional clusters, thus supporting not only the real economy but also the development of the internal market.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D).
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, I strongly support this report representing the European Parliament’s input into the Green Book of the European Commission. The capital markets union can play a full part in financing economic recovery in the European Union through deepening and broadening European Union capital markets together with bank finance. I welcome the incorporation into this report of our main priorities, which lie at the heart of all social democratic values: namely, capital markets to finance long-time investment, the real economy and, especially, small and medium-sized enterprises. I agree that it is important to develop European capital markets to diversify funding and improve access to financing, thereby restoring the stability of the banking sector. We succeeded in improving the text by defeating many amendments which aimed at turning the capital markets union into a deregulatory agenda for the financial markets. The text now clearly refers to the need for legislative action. In this sense, I am strongly in favour of a review of legislation in order to ensure the highest investor protection standards. I also agree with the need to address the taxation of capital markets, because it might represent an obstacle, despite the opportunities offered by a well-designed European Union capitals market. I would like, finally – last but not least – to thank the rapporteur and shadow rapporteurs for this approach. (The speaker refused to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Siegfried Mureşan (PPE).
text: – Mr President, many are asking us why the economy of the United States has recovered easier, faster and in a more convincing way from the previous economic and financial crisis than our European economy. The answer to this rests partly with a quick restructuring of its banking sector and with a reform of its financial system, which of course has consequences on the financing of the economy, on growth and, subsequently, on jobs. The capital markets union, Commissioner, represents one of the lessons that Europe has learned from the crisis, and by implementing it now it will ensure better financing for our economy and our SMEs. I would, therefore, like to particularly stress the importance of one element of the question put to you: SME-friendly economic and regulatory conditions. I think the Commission should indeed focus on ensuring the successful and diversified access of SMEs to financing in the capital markets union. Every detail from your side regarding this initiative will be very much welcomed. However, national particularities of the business sector and business models of the financial sectors in different European countries must also be considered when providing equal opportunities for financing. The banking sector should remain an important source of financing and funding for SMEs in Europe. Therefore, a genuine European approach should take into consideration the interconnected character of the banking and financial sectors in Europe and should be a support to the internal market in Europe, also with the aim of avoiding financial fragmentation, especially in times of crisis.

name: Paul Tang (S&D).
text: – Mr President, when Mr Juncker first coined the term ‘capital markets union’, I had some doubts. Was this a solution to the remaining obstacles to investments in SMEs in Europe, or was it a way of reintroducing the old problems under a new flag? I think the answer very much depends on the way we approach the capital markets union. Two key principles have to be at the heart of the capital markets union: it has to be safe, and it has to serve the real economy. Enhancing the safety and the stability of the financial sector still requires a number of measures. On securitisation, the resolution strikes a balance – the right balance. The Commission must show how shifting risks and freeing up capital leads to lending to SMEs. At the same time, high-quality securitisation requires an appropriate allocation of property rights and risks and requires powerful monitoring. There are problems with security-financing transactions which remain unaddressed: it is pro-cyclical in nature and it has the potential to increase systemic risk, and of course we still have to complete the banking union. We still do not have a Europe-wide deposit guarantee. As regards serving the real economy, the potential of banking beyond banks is largely untapped in the EU, so there is a possibility for Europe to diversify in financial instruments, and I think that is a good thing. It opens doors for SMEs and, with more risk-bearing capital, more SMEs can grow and develop in Europe, contributing to the European economy as a whole. But it cannot be restricted to regulation in the financial sector. If we want to have more risk-bearing capital, we also have to look at the tax regime and at debt-equity buyers, and the Commission has thus far been quiet on this subject. To conclude, the resolution rightly asserts that the capital markets union has to be fully compatible with past regulatory achievements. So yes, the capital markets union can offer an opportunity for a safer, service-oriented financial sector. This resolution offers a welcome starting point and strikes the right balance, a balance between the power of diversification and the necessity for proper regulation. This is the balance we have to protect throughout this project.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE).
text: – The Capital Markets Union is very important for the re-financial and development start-up of SMEs. Low economic growth in the European Union does not provide new jobs.  It is therefore essential to ensure the international functioning of SMEs, which requires better access to finance. The movement of capital across the border plays a great role in this, which the Capital Markets Union will certainly provide for small and medium-sized enterprises.  A comprehensive approach and guidance of financial resources through long-term investment is also needed. In all this, however, it is necessary to ensure proportionality in measures, the effectiveness of legislation and uniform supervision in order to ensure real benefits for SMEs.  By September, when the Action Plan will be published and also a review of the perspective of the Capital Markets Union Initiative, it will also be necessary to examine and regulate the provisions towards third countries in more detail, as well as to consider how to better regulate insolvency and tax systems.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the persistent austerity of the economic and financial crisis has for years undermined European growth, spoiling the fundamentals of the economy and worsening social conditions. It is precisely in the last few hours in Greece, and therefore throughout Europe, that there has been a call for a strengthening of the level of protection of investors and savers, help-free in relation to the banking system, a free movement of capital for all 28 Member States, a market that is to the real benefit of the economy, growth and employment. This can only be achieved by removing obstacles to cross-border investment by means of needs, such as the adoption of medium and long-term measures on risk analysis and private equity, the simplification of capital raising for businesses, including SMEs, throughout the European Union and the reduction of the excessive administrative burden on businesses. I therefore agree with all the questions in the question and, in my analysis of the subject, I am relying on the principles of transparency and coherence to protect savings which, I hope, remain the backbone of any economic reform.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). Mr President, the construction of the capital markets union is aimed at boosting business investment and boosting infrastructure investment. The capital markets union should be an additional source of financing for enterprises, especially small and medium-sized enterprises.  The banks after the financial crisis were rescued with taxpayers' money and, after being rescued, they no longer invest their funds in the real economy but in the casino economy.  I believe that special purpose investment banks as well as local cooperative banks should be strengthened in particular, in order to strengthen small and medium-sized enterprises as well as local economies, in order to support employment in the South and Greece, in Greece where the European Central Bank has imposed credit suffocation and paved the way for the imposition of capital controls. , in order to impose the plans of the lenders in Greece where the capital market no longer operates, nor of course the banks. But the Greek people just yesterday said a thunderous 'no' to memoranda and austerity.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE).
text: - Mr. President, strong investments in the real sector are needed to get out of this already too long crisis that European Union Member States are in, especially some EU Member States.  No financial manipulations or transactions will solve the problem of our economy, except investments in the real sector and of course, primarily allow medium and small businesses to have access to real capital and thus make investments in the real sector really visible. This is the only way we could say that we will be out of this situation tomorrow, that we can create new jobs, especially for young people and I support this single capital market framework as one of those frameworks that will allow us to invest in the real sector, in SMEs, and create new jobs.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, the union of capital markets is a good example which illustrates, on the one hand, the contradictions of the current process of capitalist integration of the European Union and, on the other hand, the lack of solutions to deal with the problems that plague European economies. The European Union is facing a crisis of enormous severity: a quarter of Europeans are at risk of poverty and social exclusion, 24 million unemployed, the youth unemployment rate doubled between 2007 and 2014. Instead of understanding the causes of the crisis, identifying these root causes, and the need to find public solutions to correct the monumental market failures, one focuses on the same solutions that undertake the current crisis. Wanting to integrate a capital market will not solve any of the problems of our economies. Believing it is possible to create a legislative framework with necessarily complex supervision that will ensure a market solution to the issues of lack of funding for our SMEs is a dangerous illusion.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE).
text: – The Capital Markets Union can be an important post-crisis remedial examination, which has arisen, of course, from financial systems, including banks, loans that have been shared uncritically, and, in fact, also because of the questionable ethics in this area. That is why, of course, this document is to be supported, which gives new opportunities, as well as new content, to finance small and medium-sized enterprises. On the one hand, we are talking about free and, above all, more flexible markets, about, of course, the need for a tax union, investment issues and, of course, the content itself.  But I'd like to draw one more warning. On the one hand, the problem of insolvency, the non-insolvency at European Union level, that is to say, the rules. And, on the other hand, of course, employment policies. So that this way of funding can help reduce so-called over-employment.

name: David Coburn (EFDD).
text: – Mr President, I would just like to say that the most successful capital market in the European Union is the City of London, and if the European Union is going to inflict more regulation and annoyance on that institution, many of the world-wide companies who invest there will go abroad. They will set up in Singapore or Hong Kong or somewhere else. They will not remain within the European Union. The euro, which was a political currency and not an economic currency, is on the frontiers of leading to a Grexit, with Greece leaving the European Union and the euro. The imposition of these financial rules on the City of London will very soon lead to a Brexit, and that, I believe, will be the end of the European Union. That may not upset my party very much, but you gentlemen are heading for disaster. Yet again you never learn. You have not learned from the euro and you will not learn from this.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – Mr President, maybe we will never learn, but we must keep trying. We are all in this together, and by solidarity and cooperation we can make progress. I think we saw that last week in relation to roaming charges; we have been reducing them gradually over a period of time. There was a blockage in the system, but through a united front and determination – particularly at parliamentary level – we are now getting roaming charges reduced, and eliminated in 2017. We need to tell citizens that these are the things that Europe can do for them, because there is far too much negativity out there. Much progress has been made in the last five years in relation to a banking union and rules to deal with issues that have cropped up. Now, of course, we have the energy union and the capital markets union. Getting alternative ways to finance SMEs, etc., has to be a good thing. They need to know about it, and I think we are going in the right direction.

name: Jonathan Hill
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, the resolution and the debate we have had this afternoon sum up very well the main points that we are trying to achieve. I just want to highlight four or five of the main themes that have come up this afternoon. First of all, in terms of building from the bottom up, identifying barriers and obstacles and knocking them down, and building the capital markets union with people, rather than doing things to people: that is how I am approaching it. And that is why support for the capital markets union is very strong, as it happens, in the City of London – because they see the benefits that come to Britain from being part of a large single market. I think it is wrong to misrepresent the views of people in the City of London. In terms of some of the other issues that were raised, I think we need to identify and overcome these barriers. We need to be proportionate in our regulation and in how we regulate. The regulation that has been passed is clearly linked with the flow of capital through the union. Some specific points were raised about insolvency, taxation and private pensions. These issues are addressed in the green paper. We asked questions about insolvency and taxation, and we will follow those up in our response to it. We are considering a specific recommendation to do with the idea of having a voluntary ‘29th regime’ to encourage personal pensions. So a number of the points that have been raised are indeed being addressed. It is also important to emphasise that the point of what we are trying to do is to complement the funding streams we already have and to add to the banking system. If you have a system – which we have in Europe – which is heavily dependent on one source of funding – the banking system – and you have a contraction in the banking system, then you get the consequences we have seen: of businesses in the economy not getting the funding they need. I feel strongly that, if we can diversify sources of funding and give small, medium-sized and large businesses alternative sources of funding, we can make a contribution to growth and to creating new jobs. There is support for this way forward. I welcome the support I have had, and I welcome the arguments set out in the resolution. We have an opportunity to make some progress. I do not claim this is the Holy Grail, but I do claim that we have an opportunity now to do what we set out to do over 50 years ago, which is to achieve the free movement of capital. I hope that we can now make some further progress on the back of this proposal.

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: I have received one motion for a resolution tabled in accordance with Rule 128(5) of the Rules of Procedure. I close the debate. The vote will take place on Thursday 9 July 2015. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Eva Paunova (PPE)
text: in writing. – The Capital Markets Union (CMU) is a classic project meant for all 28 Member States; an initiative aimed to overcome dividing lines and boost the growth of the real economy in Europe. I welcome the Commission’s efforts to build a true single market for capital, which would make it easier to channel available savings into the productive economy, enhance the funding sources for SMEs and break down barriers for investment across borders. Growth has to be funded without building debt and by avoiding a focus on one type of creditor. Currently, European companies rely on banks for three quarters of their overall debt financing, especially in states with less developed capital markets. Capital markets activity in some Member States needs to increase more than twice to achieve the average for the EU. This process can be triggered by finalising the CMU, which will enable more intensive flows of capital and will reduce discriminatory factors at play in access to financing, like the origin of the borrowers and the lenders or the business location. These developments will be especially beneficial for Member States with less deep and diverse capital markets, and I call on Member States to implement the recommended policies as swiftly as possible once the CMU strategy has been published.

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: The next item is the own-initiative report by Sirp Pietikäinen, on behalf of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety, on resource efficiency: towards a circular economy (2014/208(INI)) (A8-0215/2015).

name: Sirpa Pietikäinen
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, I guess that all of us understand that you cannot overconsume your limits all of the time in the economic sector. As we know from the Greek crisis, if you become overly indebted, sooner or later you are going to go bankrupt. With bankruptcy, it is very hard to get yourself up and running again. However, if you bankrupt nature, then it is not only twenty years of suffering – it may even be the end of the game. This is the background for the whole resource efficacy debate, because we are bankrupting the planet. Each year, we are using up 1.5 planet’s worth of resources, and this figure is growing because there are more people, more needs for resources, more products and shortening life-spans of the products. It is not a question whether change is going to happen or not – it is a question of how it is going to happen. Is it going to be an extreme crisis – economic, welfare, health and humane – or can we create a true business opportunity out of this change? Indeed, this is a huge paradigm shift and a huge systematic change that we are facing. But while Europe is the most resource-dependent of all regions, we can benefit from resource scarcity or be hit hardest by it. We need to get the things right now. This enormous, hidden business opportunity can only be created by new business ecosystems and business models, like the lease economy and businesses working together in the zero—waste society, where the ends of some processes are resources for someone else. But to make this happen, legislative, economic, information and cooperative actions are needed. Firstly we need a proper set of sub- and whole indicators and targets. It is like accounting in companies: if you do not have harmonised, agreed and binding methodology, you lose all comparability and there is no point at all to the whole effort. We need a review of existing legislation, including financial legislation, because our linear history has ensured that our legislation fails to incorporate the value of ecosystem services. There are a lot of points that actually prevent the new business models of the circular economy. We need a product policy designing out of waste, and so we need an ambitious broadening of the scope and revision of the Ecodesign Directive. We need to make this happen soon, because we need predictability for investors in our economies. We need a renewal of the base directive, and we need a special focus on certain areas, such as sustainable buildings, since buildings represent 40% of our energy consumption. As this is a very slow—moving sector, we need to start by taking the decision now to make our building sector sustainable within 30 years. And, Mr President, we need to support all this through our public procurements possibility for a pull effect, because that is 20% of our GDP.

name: Frans Timmermans
text: First Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, I will only take a few minutes of your time to tell you a few things before Vice-President Katainen takes over. First of all, this Commission remains strongly committed to presenting – before this Parliament and before the end of the year – a circular economy package which has a holistic approach on the issue – yes, on waste, but also on the re—use of finite materials and on other proposals that would create the environment for a new economy for Europe. Why do we need this, and why do we passionately believe in this? Because the future of the European economy is not in competing on low wages; the future of the European economy is not in competing on creating stuff with finite resources. The future of the European economy is in the circular economy – in reusing, in putting things back into the economic cycle, and in thinking in terms of cradle to cradle. Funnily enough, businesses have got this more – and got it better – than we have as politicians. Businesses are leading on this, and we should be leading, as well, as politicians. Why? Because we know where we are. We also know where we need to be, which is in the circular economy, but we do not know well how to get from where we are to where we need to be. And here is where politics needs to lead; here is where government comes in, and here is where the European Union is an essential link in getting us from where we are to where we need to be. I passionately believe in this transition. I believe this year, by presenting our package, we can make the first important contribution to this transformation (which is inevitable), and the report we discussed today is an important building block for what we are going to do. Indeed, we will look at the Waste Package, as I have said, and we will work on it so that we can present the new Waste Package before the end of the year – and, essentially, we will look at all the other issues we need for the circular economy. I believe in this because it is a huge business opportunity for European businesses. It is also a huge opportunity for the European economy and for jobs. That is why Vice-President Katainen and I work on this closely with all our colleagues – Commissioner Bieńkowska, Commissioner Vella, and many others – because we take a holistic approach. I would encourage Parliament to look at this, not within silos, but as something we have a common interest in, because a circular economy is not something we do just for the environment. Sustainability, of course, has an environmental angle, but sustainability has, especially, an economic and a social angle. If we do not take the three elements into account – economic, social and environmental sustainability – we will not succeed in creating the right conditions for the circular economy. I want to stress this. Why are businesses interested in this? Because it is the most interesting business model for the future; because they know it is sustainable; because they know it will lead to growth; because they know this is where Europe can lead worldwide. We should use that opportunity to integrate the three elements of sustainability – economic, social and environmental – and then, I believe, we will be successful. You can count on the Commission to take this holistic approach; you can count on the Commission to work closely with you. I am sure that we can look at the elements, particularly starting with analysing the situation in Member States and having comparable analyses from them, so that we can take it from the zero situation to the higher levels in the next couple of years. The Commission will certainly be part of that transition.

name: Jyrki Katainen
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, honourable Members, thank you very much for giving us the chance to discuss this very topical and important issue. As you heard, the Commission strongly believes in the circular economy. The circular economy will be a megatrend in the world economy similar to globalisation. The current linear model is not sustainable or reasonable from an economic, environmental or societal point of view. For instance, if you look at the car sector, the average car is parked around 90% of the time. If you look at office buildings, office buildings are empty some 50% of the time. So we have to look at the economy from a different angle than we have done before. As Vice-President Timmermans has just said, we have to look at the circular economy from a wider perspective. It is not only about recycling or waste, but we should focus on this as a complete concept in the market economy. That is why we need to find the right incentives for the business sector to further develop their business models. We also we have to find the right incentives for consumers to change their consumer behaviour and, by doing so, lead development by their own choices. At the moment the business sector is leading the circular economy, and this is a very good thing. As a regulator, we have to find the right things to support this development. We need the input of stakeholders in order to define what needs to be regulated – or even deregulated; how we can use the tools we have at EU level to promote better use of our resources and how we can strengthen the circular economy as an integral part of the dynamic market economy. We must also be careful not to overregulate everything. This is often a problem for a regulator, who may, even in good faith, sometimes do so. The ‘Report on resource efficiency: moving towards a circular economy’, as approved in the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety (ENVI) last month, sets the bar high. We appreciate and take note of your ambitious proposals. I would like to comment on some of the many issues your report raises. Let me start by what we call the other half of the circle. The Commission shares your view that product design is of paramount importance in getting things right from the start. There is the potential for an increased focus on circular aspects in order to design products that are made to last and that can be remanufactured and repaired easily, thus facilitating high-quality recycling. We are looking closely into this matter. We see a strong role for public procurement in creating demand for sustainable products, and we are examining the contribution that can be made by green public procurement in this respect. On buildings, we thank Parliament for its support for a more holistic approach to resource efficiency throughout the full life-cycle of buildings. To avoid burden shifting, we need to look at overall impacts beyond energy efficiency. The upcoming revised legislative proposal on waste is expected to focus on stepping up implementation on the ground and to take account of different levels of current performance in individual Member States, while keeping a high and achievable level of vision on recycling. It will be essential to base this work on sound evidence. Another important viewpoint is that Member States and stakeholders see real added value in cooperating at EU level to tackle food waste. To that end, we will closely examine possibilities for preventing food waste. To conclude, my mandate is to look at all the work we are doing in the circular economy from the perspective of growth, jobs, competitiveness and investment. I know that, if designed right, we can enable a triple win. First, there are economic gains to be made from using raw materials and resources more efficiently and being less dependent on imports. Secondly, there are environmental gains in moving away from a linear economy where we throw away products that could be repaired or recycled. Thirdly, there are social gains to be made from preventing waste and further improving local waste management, recycling, repair and reuse services.

name: Tiziana Beghin
text: Draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, it is widely believed that an economic system can grow indefinitely: but any economic system is always within a closed ecological system, our planet. First we will understand it and first we will understand that gross domestic product and its growth rate are indicators designed to reflect a linear consumer model that has destroyed our land. We need to understand that prosperity and growth are two quite different things and that you don't necessarily have to increase consumption to live better. This is the basis of the circular economy.  I had the privilege of being the rapporteur for this dossier on the circular economy in the Committee on Labour where we took a clear position to facilitate the transition: to shift taxation from work to the use of resources, to differentiate VAT, reducing it for goods recycled or prepared for recycling and to prepare our countries for the new jobs that will be created by the circular economy, places widespread in the territory and in small and medium-sized enterprises. The circular economy is the future: we must rethink, innovate and prepare to welcome all the opportunities that this future will bring us.

name: Benedek Jávor
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy. – Mr President, as rapporteur of the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy (ITRE), I would like to say thank you to Sirpa Pietikäinen, rapporteur for the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety (ENVI) report, and I would like to stress that the ITRE opinion, which was accepted with a huge majority, is clearly in line and supports everything which is included in the ENVI position. I would like just to point out some important elements of our opinion. The first part is that we clearly need an ambitious new package from the Commission as soon as possible, which includes quantitative targets, not just wishes and also which has legislative parts. We need clear targets and legislative proposals to step ahead in the circular economy. Concerning some specific issues in the ITRE Committee, we would like to emphasise the importance of the following: incentivising both reuse and preparations for reuse through quantitative targets; a fiscal framework in accordance with the ‘polluter pays’ principle; addressing the production side (which was mentioned already by Commissioner Katainen); better production design standards to make products more durable and easier to assemble, and so on; and the fight against planned obsolescence in order to protect consumers.

name: Karl-Heinz Florenz
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Mr President, Vice-Presidents, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for her excellent report, which is a very I was very pleased today that you made a clear commitment to the circular economy, Mr Timmermans, which was not quite so evident in the turmoil of the election of the new Commission. I am all the more pleased that you have both pointed out here today that, in the end, it is not a simple waste directive, but that this is really about much more: a circular economy. I can only say to all my fellow Members who think that they could rip something here with one percentage point or another: you are wrong. There is much more at stake. Ultimately, as Mrs Pietikäinen has already said, it is a question of us being one of the largest continents in export. But we have – my country, for example – only a bit of cement and a bit of cheese, and then it is already at the end of our raw materials. That is why we need to deal with this natural capital – I am personally a farmer and I know quite well what I am talking about – much better and more attentively. We are obviously on this path, because so far we are still depositing 70% of our raw materials in landfills in Europe. They are lost, so you can use technologies as you like. So I am pleased that at some point it will be a matter of recognizing from the ore mine to the bicycle: what have we needed, how have we dealt with it, how often can we recycle it – certainly more often with aluminium than with paper. We do not want to throw the baby out with the bath, but the important prerequisite is that we realise that we have to work on it. And that's where one or the other percentage - unlike my colleague - is supposed to be. Nor do I believe that we need to have binding figures in this paper. But we need to get people to this process of consciousness. If we succeed in this, Commissioners, I congratulate you today. We will support you with your ambitious ideas today and we will continue to accompany you in the process.

name: Massimo Paolucci
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Consumer Policy has adopted by a very large majority, with the positive contribution of all the parliamentary groups, a courageous, credible and highly innovative document, a document containing precise indications for the European Commission, which will have to present a package of legislative proposals after the summer.  The circular economy is not a dream, but an urgent necessity, a great opportunity.  This is urgently needed, because the Earth's resources are not unlimited, because it worsens the environmental quality of the planet, because the warming of the Earth does not stop and because a dramatic food emergency is becoming increasingly apparent. It is a great opportunity for Europe, because we, as the world's leading economic power, the world's leading consumer market, cannot depend 60% on imported raw materials and recover only 5% of this material. With a bold transition to a circular economy, it is possible to develop good jobs, increase Europe's wealth, become leaders in strategic sectors. Only the like and the deaf continue to ignore the fact that environmental quality will increasingly become an essential factor in the development of our economy.
