The cultural change, in lifestyles, in the methods of design and production that we want to achieve, is based on a simple principle: the raw materials present in the products must no longer be considered waste to be thrown away after a short life cycle. "From cradle to cradle" said the Commissioner: that is right. We want and must move from the culture of waste, the practice of disposables, from unbridled consumerism to that of reuse and recycling. That is why it is necessary to support innovation, research, the companies that innovate.  That is why we need a breakthrough in the design and production of consumer products, in construction, in the organization and operation of our cities, new regulations of public procurement in food production and consumption.  And here are few essential objectives: to increase our resources by 30%, by 2030; produce the same products with 30% less resources; to define parameters and indicators, binding targets on the reduction of municipal waste, strict limitation on the incineration of non-biodegradable waste.  These are the objectives that we, as Socialists and Democrats, support and I hope that Parliament will be consistent and consistent with the choices we made in the Committee on the Environment.

name: Mark Demesmaeker
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. Thank you very much for your very good introduction, Mr Vice-President. Remember, Mr Timmermans, 'trash is cash' you said recently, quite rightly by the way. Who the hell is throwing away valuables? Well, we produce five tons of waste per citizen per year. We're barely recycling a third. We throw away valuable resources. To think that Europe is particularly dependent on third countries for the import of its raw materials. The switch to a circular economy brings environmental benefits, but above all it is an economic necessity. Many companies, including at my home in Flanders, have already understood this well. From Europe, we need smart measures that remove barriers, stimulate innovation and new business models, provide long-term legal certainty. We need tools to effectively measure and reduce the use of raw materials, a well-thought-out product policy and smarter waste management. To me, these are the key messages of the report. If we want to make progress in the real world out here, and not just on paper, we need to reconcile ambition with a sense of reality. In this sense, there are still a number of points for improvement in the text. Only then will we send a strong signal to you, Commissioner. (The speaker agrees to answer a "blue card" question (Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: "blue card question." – Mr President, I would like to ask colleague Demesmaeker a question, and this will be short: When you talk about waste measured in a ton, do you include the amount of waste that can be expressed in a ton but is released into the air?

name: Mark Demesmaeker (ECR)
text: "blue card" answer. – No, I didn't think so, colleague.

name: Gerben-Jan Gerbrandy
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, let me start by thanking our rapporteur Sirpa Pietikäinen, and the two Commissioners for their work and opening statements. As we are discussing the circular economy here, China is at the same time constructing artificial islands in the South China Sea. For what reason? For one single reason: to secure resources. The single pillar of Chinese foreign policy is to secure resources for its large population. And what about the EU? What are we doing in our external policy? Not a lot. It is close to nothing, although we are the most vulnerable region in the world where resources are concerned. We provide only 30% of the resources that we use for ourselves, so in external policy, resource efficiency is absolutely absent. But of course – and this is the main focus of today’s debate – resource efficiency also has a very strong internal dimension: the efficient use of resources in Europe itself. On this matter, I have to go back five years in time to 2010, when then Commissioner Potočnik presented his roadmap for a resource-efficient Europe. I must say it was a brilliant document and a very strong analysis, with a roadmap on what Europe should do to become resource efficient. There was a lot of legislation. It was not only about the environment but was maybe more about the economy. It talked about recycling, about better design, about creating economies of scale for the reuse of materials, the recovery of precious minerals like phosphates, and working on alternatives for our chemical industry through biomass. All that was in this brilliant document, and my question to the Commission is: what will be the difference with the action plan that will be part of the circular economy package? Is it just a delay of five years, or will it be a real improvement gained after five years? Finally, let me thank the two Vice-Presidents for being here representing the Commission. I hope that shows the importance of the topic in political terms. Thank you, and I am very much looking forward to your proposal later this year.

name: Kateřina Konečná
text: on the part of the GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, let me also thank, above all, the rapporteur, who has taken on her task really responsibly, and I think that it has not always been easy with us as shadow rapporteurs. Nevertheless, it has produced a document and a report that is very ambitious – and I firmly believe that the Commission will adopt it in this way – and will be a real basis for what we will be discussing here in the European Parliament in the coming years. The Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety therefore approved this report by almost a majority of votes, and this also shows that we may have found a compromise that is possible. However, let me also say a few critical words. I have been dealing with the issue of waste management quite intensively since my time in the national parliament, and I myself know how complex and treacherous this issue is, and that, especially with this legislation, there is an old lesson that "the road to hell is paved with good intentions". I would therefore like to stress once again here that realistic real-time objectives must be set, i.e. only those that are determined on the basis of appropriate scientific evidence and analyses. Let me raise one objection now. It's not just percentages. Some of you have already talked about this, but there is nothing worse than setting values and targets within percentages that will simply be circumvented by the Member States, because they are unable to practically meet them without causing large-scale economic problems. And they are not able to fill them mainly in the time frame. I ask that the Commission adopt impact studies for all Member States individually on this very binding document. If we want to implement it, we must implement it in such a way that the Member States take it for their own purposes and not take it as some kind of regulation from us in Brussels.

name: Claude Turmes
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Mr President, I would like to thank the Thank you for the kind words. That sounds much better than in December, January, and perhaps there is a change from Saul to Paul. We hope so. We need rules on a planet where we will be ten billion. What worries me a little in your speech, including from Mr Katainen, is that you say 'no over-regulation'. But what does that mean? How do I intend to steer the economy in one direction in the long term – as you rightly recognised, Mr Timmermans – if we do not have tough objectives? Why are we making progress on climate policy? Because we have tough goals. That is why I assume that if you say that we are going to go long term, you will also be in favour of binding tough targets in 2030. Without it, there will be no direction for the economy. The second thing we need is to remove dangerous substances from the economy. I can't do meaningful recycling with dangerous substances. That is why REACH needs to be deepened rather than watered down. REACH is not over-regulation. We need less dangerous substances in order to make recycling possible in the first place.  The third reason why we are making tough laws is unfair competition from outside. In the case of tyres, new coated, i.e. very environmentally friendly tyres are more expensive in Europe than new Chinese tyres. If we do not have any laws, how do you intend to survive before the WTO in any way, and then, almost without rules, to protect the better European products or better products worldwide against dumping products? Perhaps you can be a little clearer in your answer afterwards.  Of course, we also want the Waste Framework Act not to be watered down now under this holistic rhetoric. We need strict rules there too.  One last thing: we have tailwinds in Europe, in Italy, in France when it is about food waste. Unique: The English House of Lords wants Europe to do something about food. It is unique that we finally have a tailwind for new laws from there. I think you should pick up that ball.

name: Piernicola Pedicini
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, before I begin, I too would like to thank the rapporteur, our colleague who has done a great deal of work on this issue in the Committee on the Environment. We worked with her but I have to say that she has done a really great job. We are talking here today about the circular economy, and in two days' time we are voting on this important own-initiative report in which Parliament calls on the Commission to make its proposal on this subject, which we consider fundamental, not only to begin to build a new Europe, to begin to build a Europe of the peoples, a political Europe – the one that is lacking today and we see it in the case of Greece – but also to begin to build a different Europe. , a better society, a society of the future, the society that we expect and in which our children will live. That is why we say that this is a formidable opportunity to get out of that ideological dogma which sees development and profit at all costs at the centre and to get out of that infernal logic of growth. We hear more and more of this word. We expect the Commission's proposal to focus on something other than technological progress as the only basis for the cult of economic development, this kind of religion, where economists are great priests who invite us to the West to expand more and more. We expect this proposal to put an end once and for all to this utilitarian voracity, which requires unlimited growth, even though we know that resources are limited, which imposes the ruthless competition of all the Member States and which therefore forces us to increase the debt burden, which imposes and increases the disaster of migratory flows and which requires all of us to suffer the seriousness of the social consequences. We must also overcome the concept of sustainable development once and for all, because it is not enough to make the mega-machine better or less polluting.

name: Mireille D'Ornano
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the use of resources in our economy is at the crossroads of many problems that the rapporteur rightly raises: waste, dependence on the outside world for the importation of raw materials and energy, or the lack of the recycling economy. While the importance of short circuits is highlighted and the report purports to draw a new paradigm, this text does not propose any real structural changes that would give Member States the tools necessary for a sustainable circular economy. Indeed, the intensification of international trade is not in question. However, it is one of the main vectors of overuse of resources and pollution.  Moreover, the text seeks to strengthen a regulatory framework that already suffocates our producers and artisans every day, who are nevertheless the pillars of local economies and the hopes of an entrenched circular economy. Yes, the local level is paramount and we need to take that into account in our analyses. For this reason, the Member States are legitimate and functional. Finally, in the area of hydrocarbon imports, I would like to remind you that the Union's diplomatic missteps are hurting this circular economy project. Our nations' ties with the producers of the Persian Gulf are still too strong, while continental relations with Russia are further crumbling.  Let us be realistic, ladies and gentlemen, the future of the environment is our terroirs and the great European continent.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI). Mr President, I think we all agree that the issue of resource efficiency and the transition to a circular economy are extremely important issues. But the approach is again indicators, changing perception, measuring progress, zero waste; targets that are in practice unlikely to be achieved.  But I wanted to dwell on a specific point in the report. It says that small and medium-sized enterprises should be put at the heart of the effort to make efficient use of resources. But it is these businesses that are being destroyed by the policies of the Union, a deeply undemocratic Union controlled by a bureaucracy willing to destroy not only small and medium-sized enterprises but entire peoples when they dare to resist its mandates. We witnessed an attack like this last week. Those who, with their memorial policies, have weakened the Greeks and President Schulz himself have intervened in an attempt to terrorize the Greeks in order to comply with the wishes of Brussels. But the Greek people were not afraid and yesterday gave a very strong message. Let us therefore ensure that the Union listens to the wishes of European citizens, otherwise the people will be exhausted before resources are exhausted.

name: Pilar Ayuso (PPE).
text: – Mr President, Commissioners, this Commission proposal on the circular economy is explained for a number of reasons. First, the growing demand for resources due to economic growth in third countries. The second, the shortage of raw materials on our continent, mainly one of the most valuable, since we only have exceptional deposits and difficult access. The third reason is our willingness to make environmental impacts minimal on the slope of natural resource exploitation and also on waste management. The objective is to reintroduce waste into the production cycle, thus generating a virtuous circle of efficiency, waste management, emission reduction and, in general, environmental protection. Very laudable task, but very difficult. That is why I thank and congratulate the rapporteur on the work she has done and which has not been easy at all. We must be aware that, in this matter, a good part of the effort has to be done and that companies and, ultimately, consumers and citizens have to pay for. I am in love that the new legislation in which the Commission works is ambitious, but at the same time realistic. On the basis of the waste hierarchy, the important thing is that Member States continuously improve the quality of waste management. In this way, we will be able to achieve our true objective, which is nothing more than to reintroduce the greatest amount of waste into the circuit of the economy and to make those eliminated without revaluation the least possible and, to be, none.

name: Matthias Groote (S&D).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Sirpa Pietikäinen's report delivers exactly what Europe needs at the moment: jobs, sustainable development and, at the end of the day, reliability in terms of legislation, where the direction should go. I must also repeat myself – as colleagues have just said, the two Vice-Presidents were here today. Apparently, the Commission then understood what was at stake, which perhaps was not the case at the beginning, but now we are really giving full force forward so that we can get a package – at the end of the year, it has been said. It is important that we first set up fixed quotas, voluntary measures. I have been a Member of this House for ten years. I've seen so many voluntary measures, they've all crashed into the wall, it didn't help anything. Robust legislation must be put in place, that is what matters, and that will also lead to the effect that we all want at the end of the day, namely a circular economy. We need a 360° approach at this point. If you're tinkering with this package, taking out a piece of cake here, taking out a piece of cake here, it's not going round. Then the circle will not work. In this respect, we should really give thought to this. Even if the Commission then needs more time until December, then we really need this package for sustainable development, that we conserve resources, save resources and really give a in the area of recycling, that nothing is deposited. After all, a ban on landfilling is also climate protection at the end of the day, because I prevent methane. What is very important to me is the marine environment. We should ensure that we really do take a serious approach here, so that less reaches the seas. And at the end of the day – as has already been mentioned – food waste: this must stop. It is a huge scandal that we in Europe are throwing away so many tonnes of food. We need to get better here. The Commission must also reflect on this, let it go through an impact assessment procedure again in every legislative procedure, whether this leads to food waste or to a reduction in food waste.

name: Julie Girling (ECR).
text: – Mr President, I agree that the circular economy is vital to Europe’s future economic viability, and I also agree that we need to be ambitious. So I have no complaint at all with the thrust of Ms Pietikäinen’s report. But I find myself in some difficulty, as indeed I did in committee, in terms of supporting the report in its entirety as it stands. This is for one reason only: whilst I passionately believe in all of these things, I also believe in evidence-based policy-making, and in setting out a credible legislative framework. So, before we start setting absolute numbers in our targets, we should carefully examine the impact of doing so. I have seen so often before that an own initiative report like this becomes not just indicative but somehow binding, with Parliament, in examining the legislative report when it comes forward, seeing any variance from these numbers as an unacceptable lessening and loosening of its position. A good example of this is the call for 70% recycling and reuse for municipal waste: very laudable – I support it. But before such targets can be considered, they must be underpinned by indicators to assess and measure improvements. There needs to be an impact assessment – we need to make sure that this is done properly – and I regret that we were unable to get some of these absolute numbers, rather than principles, removed from what is an own initiative report.

name: Nils Torvalds (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, Madam Pietikäinen has written a very good report, but we still have some doubts. Firstly, by regulating the streams too strictly in a fast-moving technology, we – and not the market – are picking the winners and the losers. Secondly, technology is easily one or several steps ahead of law-making. The smartest stream today may not be the smartest stream tomorrow, but the laws we will write may prevail, even if they are not the smartest. Thirdly, the production of and demand for certain waste streams do not always match a hierarchy. The streams are not always exhausted at the most preferable level. Finally, and perhaps more fundamentally, all streams are actually a problem of definition. What are waste residues and end products in essence? We know that the report that Madam Pietikäinen has written is going to be waste by the end of the week, as will this speech.

name: Merja Kyllönen (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, I very much welcome Mr Pietikäinen's report on the circular economy, which is certainly not downshiting or light recycling, but the arrival of the circular economy is a real transformation that changes the way we both consume and produce, improves productivity, significantly reduces environmental pollution, saves resources, then talks about money, food or natural resources. There are apps everywhere. Today, in particular, I would like to highlight our current methods of producing and consuming food, which are completely unsustainable. In western countries, up to 30-50% of food never ends up on a plate and food is thrown away three times the amount that would be enough to eradicate famine in this world. A real development policy, if that is what we want. And we pay for throwing food in the trash. The circular economy aims not only at the efficient use of natural resources, but also at creative solutions for the utilisation of food waste and surplus food.  We need swift and ambitious action. Our nation, our economy and our environment are not waiting.  (The speaker promised to answer the blue card question under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure).

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: blue-card question. – Ms Kyllönen, yes, it seems that we are going to see heaven on earth with the circular economy. This might be true, but do you not think that, first of all, we need innovation? Without innovation, this circular economy is not going to function. First of all, we need innovation and a high—efficiency circular economy. Only societies that are going to base their economies on innovation are going to win in the future.

name: Merja Kyllönen (GUE/NGL)
text: answer to the blue card question. – Thank you to my colleague for a good question. Of course we need innovation, but above all we need common sense. Yes, I would argue that in this world we are bringing a piece of heaven in front of people who are looking at the food stain, which we Europeans, for example, are pushing into the bin today. All it needs to do is common sense, not much innovation, but it is enough to be able to put our consumption into reasonable proportions.

name: Reinhard Bütikofer (Verts/ALE).
text: Mr President, Mr Vice-President of the Commission, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent work and for the work she has said. I am pleased with this Pietikäinen report because, by setting ambitious targets, it actually provides a good benchmark for what the Commission has promised by the end of the year. Not only does he formulate such targets in detail, with regard to waste prevention or recycling quotas, but he also places this in the context of greater prospects for an ecological civilisation, for example by saying that we must make our economy sustainable by 2050, for example by saying that we must reduce our resource consumption by 30% by 2030. However, if it becomes concrete towards the end of the year, Vice-President Katainen, we will have to look again at your slogan of over-regulation. Nobody can have anything against over-regulation. The only question is: what is over-regulation? I would like to warn against believing that over-regulation already exists when any industry or company is complaining. You know as well as I do that there are companies and industries that can and want to make business successes out of this circular economy and that are leading the technological and innovation, and others who are on the brakes and believe that a competitive solution will only be achieved if we succeed even if we refuse to accept the environmental transformation goals. We need to clarify that. To tolerate the latter is not to combat over-regulation, but to lose the objectives.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD).
text: – Mr President, the rapporteur addresses the need for the European Union to become more competitive, to create jobs, increase productivity and improve its use of resources: all worthy aims. However, to achieve these objectives, she states the European Union should avoid exceeding the earth’s resources, which would also mitigate climate change. There has been no discernible global warming for the last 18 years, even if you support the IPCC theory. How can anyone still believe that the key to making the European Union competitive is to establish a new legislative framework? For example, the proposal for an eco-design directive will impose EU ecological design requirements on products. How can anyone still believe that a new European policy framework would deliver legal certainty to investors? Who can afford to invest in such an environment? Nonsensical over-regulation from the European Commission will not help our economy or industries. It is now clear that regulatory uncertainty is one of the biggest threats to investment and production. New legislation imposed by the unelected in Brussels will not ensure the re-industrialisation of Europe. We need to reinvigorate the declining EU economy with a new competitive approach.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I agree with you that the efficient use of our resources is an urgent necessity. The concept of circular economy aims to establish this imperative as a development doctrine. But is it possible to move towards such a model when priority is given to the most anarchic liberalism, to compulsory globalization at all levels? A true circular economy is about being able to live, produce and work in this country, and prioritize technological research. It is also about empowering citizens rather than imposing even more regulation and constraints on them.  It is not by strengthening the regulatory prerogatives of the European Commission, or by shedding a tear on food waste, that we will be able to preserve our environmental heritage and limit malnutrition in the world as well as poverty in Europe.

name: Andrzej Grzyb (PPE).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by The proposal for a sustainable circular economy is perhaps one of the most far-reaching and important projects undertaken by the Union. It can and should properly rebuild the entire economy on the basis of the principle of resource efficiency. It can be an opportunity for the Union, for all Member States, for growth and jobs. However, we must take into account that the objectives it contains must be chosen realistically and, in particular, taking into account the principle of subsidiarity. I would like to appreciate the efforts of my colleague Sirpa Petikaïn, who is the rapporteur for this report, and his author. She has put a lot of work into this, but I must admit that some of the objectives that have been outlined here in a specific time context – because in a moment or in a few months we will get a proposal from the European Commission – it is supposed to influence the european Commission's proposals, it seems to me that we are introducing targets that are tearing down the current regulations, such as the issue of waste incineration; new installations built with, among other things, national money and EU money – and they are to have a reduced waste stream. We need to sort it out in some rational way. The requirements of the Ecodesign Directive are problematic; it is not the ecodesign itself that is difficult, but the requirements that will be placed on small and medium-sized enterprises, among other things, and yet we want them to develop as well. I think what is perhaps most important in this whole concept is what Karl-Heinz Florenz said – we should speak to the awareness of the citizens. If citizens do not help us, we will not be able to introduce this concept of circular economy into the European Union.

name: Daciana Octavia Sârbu (S&D).
text: – Mr President, in 1900 the population of the planet did not exceed 2 billion. By 2050, it will exceed 9 billion. The current pace of resource consumption is unsustainable. This consumption generates not only a negative impact on the environment, but also other effects, including increasingly difficult political tensions to manage.  We waste food easily, although malnutrition and hunger suffocate parts of the world. We make geopolitical compromises for expensive energy, but we ignore the opportunity to use renewable energy more. We have access in stores to fruit produced thousands of kilometers away, but we do not always find easily on the same shelves and fruits produced by local farmers.  These are all forms of waste. The transition to more responsible consumption is absolutely essential. The principle of a circular economy, with a greater emphasis on reuse and recycling, is a fair one. It would remove pressure on finite resources and generate opportunities and jobs in the recycling industry.

name: Jadwiga Wiśniewska (ECR).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by I agree that we should consider a circular economy where waste is recycled and reused. This is a great opportunity not only for the environment, but also for the economy. However, I think we should set ambitious but achvable targets. For example, I believe that increasing the recycling rate of municipal waste to 90% by 2030 will be very difficult for many Member States to achieve. The current level is 27%. I therefore call for caution not to over-regulate: over-regulation is stifling the economy, and I hope most of us are aware of this. It is also worth strongly shaping citizens' awareness, supporting states on this issue. And I ask that we create European law with caution.

name: Anneli Jäätteenmäki (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, Parliament's circular economy conference is a step towards a more sustainable way of producing and consuming goods. The circular economy is a shift towards the use of resources within the limits of the earth's carrying capacity. I welcome this circular economy report, but with some reservations. They mainly concern the setting of strict numerical targets at a stage when this large dossier is only being pushed in. I agree with the urgency of things, but the assessments behind the figures need to be opened up. The child must not go with the bathwater. My second reservation concerns strict recording of the so-called cascade use of biomass. Increasing the processing rate of products is an integral part of the circular economy, but detailed regulation has its challenges. The euro is a good consultant, but the command economy has not worked in the history of the world, and it is not working now.

name: Eleonora Evi (EFDD).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, for decades we have been talking about the circular economy, both in the scientific community and in civil society, and among social movements. At last, the European Parliament is also talking about this issue, we are talking about progress, basically we are talking about what the future of our economy will be.  Mrs Pietikäinen's report is a report which contains measures that we can very much support and which really looks in the direction of a circular economy, but in which there is a gap, in my opinion: we do not talk about circular economy as long as we talk about incineration. This practice, in addition to being a source of pollution dangerous to human and environmental health, also undermines the possibility of implementing a waste reduction policy, which is one of the most important measures in the management hierarchy of municipal solid waste. Although incineration is a clear practice of linear economics, other political groups in the Committee on the Environment did not support the amendment in which the 5-star Movement called for a general ban on incineration and landfilling. From this point of view, the measures proposed in the resolution risk being distorted and reduced to partial and incisive measures, which do not allow the full achievement of a circular economy.

name: Birgit Collin-Langen (PPE).
text: Mr President, Mr President-in-Chief of the Commission, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent work and for the work she has done. We have heard it, and it is obvious: the circular economy is one of the very big issues facing the European Union. The own-initiative report by Sirpa Pietikäinen is a good way of defining our parliamentary view in this regard. I think – and we have just heard this through almost all the speeches – that there is a very large majority here that is committed to an effective circular economy and resource efficiency. We must do this ambitiously, but – and Here I would like to pour a drop of vinegar into the beautiful wine – we must also do it in a way that is realistic! The measures to be taken must not lead to over-standardisation or over-regulation. Mr Bütikofer, you have just asked: what is over-regulation? For example, for me, over-regulation is when we talk here about ambitious, binding targets in public procurement law, which we only amended last year and where we have just introduced these green points of view as a way of taking account of procurement law that has not been the case before. I also think that we must be careful to include the inclusion of environmental risks in ratings and capital requirements. The revision of the Ecodesign Directive should also be carefully reconsidered. Hence the request to the Commission: it is a comprehensive, good report. In many places, I also agree 100% with Sirpa. However, we should also ask the Commission to present what it is presenting with a sense of proportion and with the feasibility of the time.

name: Guillaume Balas (S&D).
text: Mr President, Commissioner, the debate is clearly about the need to impose binding targets or simply set indicators. Indicators have been around for a long time. The Commission has been dragging on a lot, let us say, before tackling the issue of the circular economy, and we now see that, on the specific issue of waste - I am talking here about municipal waste - if we do not have a firm ambition, nothing will happen.  That is why we, the group of the Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats, are now supporting the idea of goals. They have to be realistic. It should not be over-regulation, it should be good regulation, and it is up to you to implement it. We trust you and we will support you in this direction.  Second, the circular economy can be beneficial for employment. Indeed, once a product becomes competitive - because a discarded product is less competitive - it creates jobs and innovation. We believe precisely that today the territories must be able to practice this circular economy in order to fight globalisation. We have to put the means to it. There is a budgetary aspect to it and it would be nice if the European Fund for Strategic Investments, which is part of the Juncker plan, could have a strong interest in it.

name: Marcus Pretzell (ECR).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which The throwaway society has been promoted for decades to promote, accelerate and bring whole industries to life. The speed with which technological progress through updates or new developments today has already eliminated products as outdated has also increased immensely and plays into the hands of a throwaway society. On the other hand, there is a need for action in this highly sensitive arc of tension between progress, economic success and resource conservation. But how much intervention, how much regulation is needed? The paradigm shift has long since taken place. The industry has recognized that today's customers are asking for and preferring sustainable products. In addition, the efficient use of all raw materials used is an important factor for industry in achieving its economic success. Isn't that all motivation? Circular economy is undeniably a sensible approach to more effective exploitation of valuable resources. It is therefore all the more surprising that state bodies themselves have a very preventive effect here, for example by refusing permits for industrial installations, which would ensure that the separation of substances is as pure as possible, which in turn is an indispensable prerequisite for the effective recycling of expensive natural raw materials. How often do state or EU institutions, regulations with their excessive bureaucracy, stand in the way of efficient use of raw materials and environmentally friendly recycling? Ladies and gentlemen, do we not have to hold our own mirrors? No, that is not what resource conservation looks like.

name: Angélique Delahaye (PPE).
text: Mr President, Mr Vice-Presidents, ladies and gentlemen, I am delighted that Parliament is once again calling on the Commission to leave the legislative package on the circular economy.  Nevertheless, we must remain cautious. If we want to set an example to the rest of the world, we risk shooting ourselves in the foot, killing the competitiveness of our SMEs and our businesses. We must not pit the environment against the economy. We should be talking about the efficient use of our resources, rather than the misuse of our resources. These concepts are present in this report and I regret that, because they are biased and not proactive. We need to make economics and the environment work. That's why it's important to support our companies, especially the most innovative ones.  But it is also fundamental to support research effectively, and that is how we will lead by example. I hope that the Commission's proposals will go in this direction. We need a global vision for effective legislation, a European vision of the circular economy. Before setting a European waste target, we must have harmonised calculation methods for all Member States. Without that, I do not see the point of such objectives. Finally, I would like to focus on a more specific proposal, in the context of the fight against food waste. The Commission must include provisions in its proposal to promote, at Member State level, the establishment of conventions between supermarkets and food aid associations, so that they can benefit from the unsold goods. I hope that this proposal will be widely supported by my colleagues and that the Commission will take up it.

name: Simona Bonafè (S&D).
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the circular economy is a unique opportunity to contribute to economic and social launch and to project Europe into a new phase of sustainable development, a phase in which waste is a resource, companies are at the heart of the sustainable revolution and production and business models are, in fact, circular because they put raw material and its efficient use back into circulation. But we would be wrong if we confined the circular economy only to an environmental policy. So you understand that the circular economy is not just what we want to do with waste, so it's not just what percentages of separate collection we want to achieve, where we want to deliver it.  The circular economy is undoubtedly the revision of waste legislation, which is an essential part, but it is much more than that. We must see it as a strategic axis of economic development and – let me tell you – even European industrial and even social, because it means, for example, wanting to design and produce products in such a way as to increase their durability, recyclability and repairability, supporting the secondary raw materials market and changing, and at the same time reorienting, business and business models. So what is to be done? It will be important for the European institutions to identify areas where there are clear legislative and economic and financial barriers to transition and to act there with clear and pragmatic rules. (The speaker agreed to answer a blue card question (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Piernicola Pedicini (EFDD)
text: Blue card question. Thank you, Mr President, wonderful words, Mr President, we agree with everything you have said; But, here, can you talk to Prime Minister Renzi about this? Can you tell him that this thing that you said completely refutes the 'unblock Italy' decree which doubles oil extraction and frees up waste incineration? Can you tell him, please? Because that's how it seems to us that you just take us for the fondues.

name: Simona Bonafè (S&D)
text: Answer to a blue card question. But you see, Mr Pedicini, thank you for these considerations. However, I would also like to point out to you that perhaps we are in a for a which it is not really the Italian Parliament; I would therefore try to hold the debate at the level of European regulations, which are regulations, moreover, on which we are also going to outline a new model of development. I would therefore stick here to what we want to do for the future of our continent.

name: Pirkko Ruohonen-Lerner (ECR).
text: – Mr President, the overconsumption of the earth's resources is a common problem for all of us, which is also being tackled by the circular economy. We need to raise awareness among all people. Recycling, equipment maintenance, repair and reuse save raw materials and money in industry and households.  As an example, I would also like to emphasise the responsibility and obligation of industrial companies to manufacture high-quality and durable household appliances and other appliances. Over the decades, I have personally found that many new and modern devices do not last like similar devices until 20 or 30 years ago. I have therefore considered the reasons why this might be caused. Do industrial plants make a lot of profits from the sale of spare parts, which is why they use certain weak parts for the products, which need to be replaced a few years after the device is put into service.  I believe that modern technology could produce even better household appliances than they did decades ago. I believe that the question should be given to whether, for example, the guarantee periods for household appliances could be extended by a few years in order to improve their quality and extend their service life.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE).
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would of course also like to thank the Vice-President for being here for this interesting debate and sincere thanks to Mrs Pietikäinen, who has worked hard to bring together a series of proposals and requests from all the political groups, which we will vote on Wednesday to give the European Commission a direction of action to put us in front of us by the end of the year. , as Vice-President Timmermans said, a more ambitious proposal on the circular economy. But, if I may, Vice-President, I would like to highlight a couple of points which are essential. We want a circular economy and no longer a linear economy because we also want a more competitive business system. We are convinced that, in order to have a greater sustainability, in the long term, of the industrial system, there is a need to reuse everything that can be reused in the production process. We cannot think of throwing away what can still have value in the system of companies for new production.  That is why we are strongly calling on the Commission – and we asked before we did not withdraw the proposal on waste – to present a more ambitious proposal, a proposal that can take us even further, on the one hand, to make the economic system competitive and, on the other, to have a sustainable system, that is, a system that can be maintained in the long term.  We ask the Commission in its proposal with our report.

name: Paul Brannen (S&D).
text: – Mr President, resource efficiency and the circular economy are exciting opportunities to deliver benefits for the environment, promote new ways to tackle climate change and create jobs. To focus on one element of the report we will, hopefully, adopt on Wednesday, the 2050 horizon for sustainable use of resources in the EU contains a provision to implement the principle of cascading use of resources, notably in the use of biomass. ‘Cascading use’ means prioritising the most advanced applications of resources before burning them for fuel. This is particularly true of wood, which can be used in construction, manufacturing, textiles, the automotive industry and even food production, all of which have the potential to create jobs. In regions such as my own in the north-east of England, this report will help companies such as Robertson’s, which specialises in wooden frames for houses, reopen their factory in County Durham, providing a vital boost for the local economy. Put simply, resource efficiency means more jobs.

name: Annie Schreijer-Pierik (PPE).
text: – We are talking today on an important subject. Ultimately, it is about the re-utilisation of our raw materials, which will become scarce. We need to think about how we can continue to deal with our raw materials and waste, because there are certainly great opportunities and challenges here in the coming years. We are already a long way off with the proper reuse of our waste. The waste incinerators already recycle a lot, especially in the Netherlands. Incineration, residues are released, including valuable raw materials. The suggestion is made that burning in particular is very unhealthy. But the technology used today is different and can also contribute to the circular economy, for example. The business model of reuse and processing makes combustion in a good mix of great importance. Phasing out too quickly makes no sense if the landfill ban is not properly enforced in the rest of Europe. Everyone should be able to come. In the Netherlands, garbage is not just thrown together. Waste is separated before it is incinerated or recycled. An informed decision. Billions have already been invested in waste disposal. If we change the frameworks, companies may be in trouble. And if valuable innovation is lost, we will run backwards. Finally, another point. For the agricultural sector, too, the use of the circular economy between farmers is essential. Recovery of scarce phosphate and other valuable raw materials from manure must be made possible in Europe. So finally allow the use of mineral concentrate, include it in a fertilizer order and remove it from the waste law. This is the only way in which Europe can create a credible picture for a real circular economy for our farmers and our citizens.

name: Karin Kadenbach (S&D).
text: Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for his excellent work and for the work she has done. Resource efficiency towards a circular economy: I do not believe that we can discuss this issue without also going into the area of food production, the area of agriculture. We have already heard today that not inconsiderable parts of our food end up in waste again. In other words, we must also include agriculture, agricultural production and food production in the thinking processes for this circular economy, as it has a very large impact not only on the environment, on people and on public health, but also on animal welfare and animal husbandry. In other words, I would ask that recital R, which has been incorporated into this really very good report by my colleague, also be taken into account in the development of the proposal.  Today we are discussing an own-initiative report. A few days ago, I had the opportunity to report in a school that we wanted to move towards a circular economy. The students' question was, with big eyes, why don't we have them yet?  Commissioner, Commissioner, I would ask you to give these pupils an answer as soon as possible as to why we do not have them. I want the answer. We have a proposal that we can discuss here again.

name: Carlos Zorrinho (S&D).
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, the concept of sustainable growth is key to regulated, environmentally friendly and people-centred globalisation. Without growth we cannot meet the expectations of millions of people – expectations of access to essential goods, employment, individual achievement and community.  In the deregulated globalization we live in today, we have seen two very worrying trends. On the one hand, inequalities and the severity of outbreaks of poverty have increased. On the other hand, climate change has been generating disasters, hunger, desolation, and requires clear, strong responses with concrete results. In this context, the commitment to a circular economy that allows the creation of wealth by incorporating waste management into the value chain is a smart and urgent bet. The path is clear, and also to some extent circular. We must set an example in Europe, through international, trade and other agreements, and make this vision extended to the global economy, so that when we say that we want sustainable growth, this is not just rhetorical, a future strategy, good for people and good for the planet.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D).
text: – Mr President, resource and energy efficiency is not just a 'green' issue. The competitiveness of the European economy and industry today depends primarily on what progress we can make in the area of energy and resource efficiency. The increasing and wasteful use of resources and europe's increasing dramatic use of energy can push us into an economic imperfec. We are already at the fortnour of Europe being the world's number one importer of energy, with imports already more than half of our total energy needs. This type of energy dependency can only be reduced by joining forces between Member States and in alliance with Europe. This is particularly true in the area of energy poverty, which is a growing problem, particularly in Central and Eastern Europe. I am therefore convinced that improving energy efficiency and creating a common European Energy Union can lead to persistently low and sustainable energy bills, not regulatory price regulation for domestic consumption by individual Member States, which is why we must support the Commission's proposal to develop an EU measure of energy efficiency.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE).
text: – I welcome my colleague Sirpa Pietikäinen's report on the circular economy, as well as the fact that we have two Vice-Presidents of the European Commission here in the Chamber today, and their position on the European Commission's ambitious circular economy plan, which is to be delivered at the end of the year. Europe is a continent that looks most ambitiously at environmental objectives. And that is why it is right that the circular economy is one of our great priorities. It's about saving resources, recycling, reusing resources. In adopting this way of managing resources, it is very important that we involve local authorities and regional authorities in this process. Without their active role, there will be no results. Real life takes place among people. However, it is also important to involve young people in this process and to spread awareness through the education system of the importance of saving resources. I wish the Commission every success and wish the Commission the most ambitious report at the end of the year.

name: Viorica Dăncilă (S&D).
text: – Mr President, Europe is working to integrate environmental and social risks into financial legislation, to better target capital towards adequate services in the areas of ecosystems and biodiversity. I believe that environmental degradation, excessive use of resources and lack of appropriate measures can lead to undesirable long-term effects.  On the other hand, it is necessary to pay greater attention to the efficient use of resources in buildings and buildings, given that at European level 40% of the European Union's total energy consumption is responsible, which generates 36% of total carbon dioxide emissions. Europe needs sustainable buildings, but for this it is necessary to have smart and sustainable land use planning, complemented by appropriate territorial planning and transport solutions.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). Mr President, the efficient use of resources is now urgent for environmental reasons. The transition to a sustainable and circular economy must be combined firstly with the promotion of decent work, secondly with the protection of the environment, thirdly with strong social parameters and fourthly by ensuring safe working conditions. The adoption of new waste targets should also be intensified, as this could create a hundred and eighty thousand jobs and reduce the demand for costly resources in order to make Europe competitive. But while we are talking about the circular economy, in Greece the economy has disintegrated. Thousands of small and medium-sized enterprises have put a padlock on it. The banks are closed. The Troika in negotiations with Greece continues its failed policy, which has filled my country with armies of unemployed people. But the Greek people in yesterday's referendum said a deafening no to unemployment, not to international economic control, not to the troika ultimatums. Eurozone leaders should take this seriously at their summit tomorrow.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE).
text: – Mr. President, I want to express at the outset the strong support to the Commission on this document and the proposals we expect and of course to the rapporteur who has already warned us at the beginning about a number of high-quality details.  However, I also want to give a few details and mention that first of all, I think we need to take a good look at the problems of cross-border cooperation, or rather, cross-border use of waste and resources. This is a problem we face in the European Union, because we do not have the same situation in the Member States, we do not have a similar policy and I ask that cross-border cooperation in this report and the Commission's reflections be seriously involved.  I also expect the opportunities of candidate countries and potential candidates to be included because we have high pollution, among other things, due to the lack of involvement of these countries in the Processes of the European Union and, of course, to involve local and regional authorities.

name: Josu Juaristi Abaunz (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, this is a report with good criteria and objectives, such as energy efficiency, sustainable product life cycle and zero waste. In my view, it rightly calls for binding targets where they are needed, such as reducing waste generation, and with whom it is needed, involving local and regional authorities in the development of the circular economy package. It fully bets the report on selective collection and calls for mandatory targets, and proposes to limit incineration strictly to non-recyclable and non-biodegradable waste. In much of Gipuzkoa, a territory of Euskal Herria, we have been walking that path for several years, and we have met, in 2015, objectives that are set here for 2020. Gipuzkoa demonstrates that it is feasible to double recycling rates in four years and transition to that 70% in ten years, i.e. that the binding objectives needed by the approach advocated by this report are perfectly possible.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE).
text: – It is an ambitious document, which, of course, is the basis for the draft document to come up with a more concrete - Commission proposal. It is certainly about things that need to be supported. A circular economy is an opportunity for everyone – for economics, for jobs, but above all for the environment and a healthier approach to understanding the economy.  However, I think that in this document, which the Commission is preparing, it needs to be more clear about what its objectives are. And these objectives must, of course, be binding. Because if there are no binding targets, it will not really be possible to establish a circular economy system, because we are still a long way from the 'polluter pays' principle. We still have too many of these wild landfills, too much waste is being deposited, not recycled, and I think that more needs to be invested in data management research or waste. And, of course, these objectives must be monitored and taken appropriate action. And let us also, of course, also forget the responsibility of polluters.

name: Rosa D'Amato (EFDD).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, changing the pattern of development means abandoning the exponential growth in the consumption of goods, energy consumption and therefore in the consumption of natural resources. It means being aware and being consistent and taking action to close incinerators and landfills; close the production of steel with integral cycle, because it consumes raw materials, and favor the recovery of steel because it is a recyclable material. It means closing plants that have an impact on health and the environment and are often lethal. An example of this, the Ilva steel works in Taranto, an old and uneconomic plant. I call on this Parliament, and my Italian colleagues in particular, to be consistent, not to fill our mouths here with industrial ecology, with eco-design, with the shared economy, and then not to act against eco-mafias and eco-slys but, on the contrary, to support governments that issue acts to save the profit of large murderous companies. I am referring to the eighth salva Ilva decree, which once again gave a licence to kill a plant already under investigation for several European infringements. I call on Parliament and the Commission to be consistent and to act immediately against the Italian Government, proceeding as soon as possible with the conclusion of infringement procedures and imposing compliance with European directives, as well as with the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Mr Katainen, Vice-President of the Commission, I would like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent work Your colleague, Mr Timmermans, has told us today that the Commission will present an ambitious package on the circular economy by the end of the year. That is very welcome. He has also said that he pays particular attention to the input of waste management, namely the industry in waste management, and also takes a sense of over-regulation. That is a good thing. However, I would like to say to you: do not forget to take account of the impact assessment and please, do not forget to quantify the objectives for the package. It has already been said today. This is particularly important for the Committee on Industry. Europe could therefore become a global best practice for the circular economy. This creates jobs, it creates competitiveness internationally. And at the end of the day, it's about steering against a trend that we see internationally. Namely, the waste of resources, the consumption of resources is increasing. By 2050, it will triple, with the G7 countries alone needing 40% of total resources. It would be good to send out a signal and promote resource-efficient products and industries based on the principle of sharing economy companies such as BlaBlaCar, Uber or Airbnb.

name: Jyrki Katainen
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, thank you very much for this very good discussion. I would like to thank the rapporteur, Sirpa Pietikäinen, for a very good and interesting paper. As both First Vice-President Timmermans and I have said, the Commission takes this exercise very seriously, we are passionate about this issue, and we also recognise the big challenge ahead of us, because the circular economy is not a simple issue at all. We want to be very humble with this large entity in order to choose the right things which need European-wide regulation. We also have to recognise where we do not need European-wide regulation. Many colleagues here asked what I meant when I said that we have to avoid over—regulation. What I meant is that there are very good examples in Europe even now, especially in the industrial sector, of business models which represent the circular economy. If we over-regulate something, it means that those good examples will be killed, and we have to avoid this. Our aim is to set a target, and we want to be flexible on how to get there because the target itself is the main issue. For us, the circular economy is a matter of competitiveness; it is a matter of innovation; it is a matter of job creation, investment and growth. As Europeans, we need to find a way to create a better environment for the circular economy. In the United States they do not necessarily have that need, because they have some points they can rely on, and on which to build their competitiveness, but when looking at Europe, we have an economic necessity, an imperative, to be successful in this. When looking at Asia, especially China, they have an environmental necessity, similarly to us. So this is a competition situation – whether Europe is ahead of, for instance, the Chinese, when creating incentives to business and consumers to boost the circular model of our economy. So let us continue on this file. This is also very important from the internal market viewpoint. If we manage to create an internal market for used raw materials or a secondary market for raw materials, then we can again build incentives for healthier, more environmentally, socially and economically sustainable development on this issue. The public consultations will last until 20 August. I hope you will all pass a message to stakeholders to be active, because we need good examples, we need assistance and advice from the private sector – but also from the NGO sector – on what is the best way to boost the circular economy on our continent.

name: Sirpa Pietikäinen
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, first of all I would like to thank my shadow rapporteurs and other colleagues for the very good and constructive cooperation and work, without which this result would not have been possible. Secondly, a couple of comments on this discussion. To those of my colleagues who have fears over a regulation and think that voluntary actions alone would work, here are just a few reminders: why do we have regulations on ownership and paying taxes? Why do we not just say, OK,  taxes are a useful thing, so let us leave things on a voluntary basis so that everybody pays their right share, right? Or why cannot civilised people just agree among themselves whether they drive on the right or left, or whether they own something or they do not? Why do we need regulations on that? Because regulations give legal certainty. We do not have that legal certainty at this point about our circular economy, like we do not have it about the digital agenda or data security, because these phenomena did not exist about 20 years ago. But we have a lot of wrong kinds of incentives and regulations, and if we do not tackle this, nothing will happen. Thirty years ago we did not live in caves. We did already have the first indicators of resource efficiency. The Interface carpet company started leasing carpets, and we had a whole concept about resource efficiency and inefficiency, and the need to make the economy circular. Look what we have achieved in 30 years – very little. Alongside the good examples and knowledge, the use of resources has only been increasing. 30 years from now we will be living in 2050, and either we will need four planets or we decrease the use of resources from those of one and a half planets to within the limits of one planet. The choice is for now, and it is our choice. We have the information and we need legal certainty and regulation to make it happen.

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: I close the debate. The vote will take place on Wednesday 8 July 2015. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. With the report we are about to vote on, the European Parliament can give a strong impetus to profoundly changing the approach to the economic model to which we have become accustomed, namely the 'take, produce and throw' approach. Change can be made and the request to the Commission to set binding targets this year to increase resource efficiency by 30% by 2030 compared to the situation in 2014 shows that Parliament has high expectations of the action of the European executive.  I also consider the reference to the proposal announced by the Commission on the revision of waste legislation to be fundamental: the Commission must feel obliged to present it by 2015, including clear and unequivocal definitions, the development of waste prevention measures, the application of the 'pay how much you throw' principle and the strict limitation of incinerators.  I hope that the Commission will be able to grasp these inputs and will be able to push The Member States towards a paradigm shift leading to an economic system in which the materials and energy used to manufacture the products maintain their value for as long as possible, thereby reducing waste and the use of resources and at the same time creating economic opportunities and competitive advantages on a sustainable basis.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. – The logic of the circular economy is absolutely central to our planet and very dear to the 5 Star Movement. It is very important that resources are exploited in the right way, through conscious and sustainable use. The lack of this prospect is at the root of enormous environmental damage, with often non-reversible effects, which are seriously jeopardising the survival of our planet as we know it today.  In addition to the environmental damage, there are also the economic damage; Just think - to make a reference close to us - of the floods in Italy, Romania and Bulgaria. Some aspects of the circular economy can also be a source of employment, thus having additional advantages. In conclusion, a paradigm shift involving everyone is absolutely necessary, and I very much hope that Parliament will be able to give the right impetus.

name: Jørn Dohrmann (ECR)
text: Written. – There is no doubt that waste management and waste is a major challenge that all Member States are grappling with in one way or another. Therefore, it is also welcome that the focus is on making the best use of our resources. The report contains some good elements - including that new products need to be more long-lasting. In this way, both the environment and consumer safety can be strengthened. Similarly, the call for harmonisation of measurement methods and definitions throughout the Union is a healthy element and a much-needed tool for gaining an overview of the ability to deal with waste , both at Union and national level. However, I am concerned that the demands of the European Union will be too extensive. In Denmark, waste incineration is still widespread in cogeneration, which is why the report also becomes a showdown with the way we handle our waste at home. In Denmark, we are already implementing a waste strategy to ensure that less waste is burned in favour of more recycling. I am concerned that the new EU rules will be so comprehensive that they will do more harm than good, to initiatives that are already under way through national legislation.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. "Our planet is generous in resources but it is finite. And the physical limits of this planet are constantly being confronted by the largely dominant economic and social system on a global scale – capitalism. A system that we know has known since Marx uncovered the laws of its development, either grows and accumulates or dies. Some may try to paint it green, but what they can't do is change their predatory nature.  Overcoming capitalism is not in itself a guarantee that we will have a harmonious and sustainable relationship between man and nature, but it is undoubtedly a necessary condition. (Perhaps some confuse the circular economy with something closer to a spiraleconomy...). As far as waste is done, its reduction and re-use, its good management, what is required is a strong presence and role of states in this area, ensuring the prevalence of the public interest and public services over private business. This is the opposite of what is being done in several countries, such as Portugal, where, against the position of the people and municipalities, progress has been made for the privatisation of the waste sector.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: Writing. – It is undoubtedly time for society to realise that we are increasingly exceeding the planet's limits and that if we continue to do so, we will not avoid negative ecological changes in the future. If we want to preserve a healthy and viable planet for future generations, we need to find a way to reduce the consumption of minerals, fossil fuels and biomass, which are constantly growing as a result of population growth, the expansion of product diversity compared to the past, and the reduction in their lifespan. If the global economy continues its current set-up, we will reach an impasse around 2050. It is necessary to create a market for secondary raw materials in Europe, because valuable raw materials and materials that we obtain at a high environmental and social price end up in incineratories and landfills. We must focus on promoting innovation and streamlining the use of resources and focusing consumers' attention on such environmentally friendly products. Efficient management of resources requires the intermission of many factors. The European Union must develop a binding resource efficiency indicator. We need to set clear, clear and ambitious targets for resource efficiency and create an environment of legal certainty that ensures wide opportunities for innovative business models and policies.

name: Elisabeth Köstinger (PPE)
text: Writing. – Our raw materials are becoming scarcer, crises are making it difficult to trade resources, and at the same time our throwaway society is growing. The signs of the times are therefore clearly on the circular economy, sustainability and resource efficiency. These are principles of the eco-social market economy, which I am committed to: it aims to combine ecological sustainability with the economy, to decouple our consumption of resources from growth and to establish a bioeconomy. Even if we cannot change our economic model overnight, our aim must be to finally strike a balance between the consumption of raw materials and the use of renewable resources. I therefore hope that Vice-President Timmermans will keep his promise and present the circular economy draft by the end of 2015. However, what steps we are taking in this future strategy must be considered carefully. Paternalism is not the right approach here. There is no point in imposing strict, binding requirements on the Member States, which they will then be unable to achieve. Rather, we should seek subsidiary solutions – by defining targets and incentivising them, but by giving member states flexibility in achieving them. In the end, balanced cooperation between the different sectors must be at all levels, so that resource use, waste management, sustainability and efficiency are seamlessly integrated and the circular economy not only remains a noble objective, but develops into a real principle!

name: Emilian Pavel (S&D)
text: in writing. – First of all, I would like to congratulate the rapporteur on his excellent work on this dossier. This legislative package can transform Europe's economy towards a sustainable system and also create new jobs, especially among young people.  In addition to the benefits of the circular economy, I believe that greater attention must be paid to the regions and the workforce adversely affected by this transition, such as the 350 000 jobs in the mining industry in Europe. I therefore call on the European Commission to work with the social partners to create solidarity mechanisms, such as financial compensation, retraining and retraining. I also believe that an efficient and job-generating transition must necessarily be supported by educational and vocational programmes and strategies for the development of specific skills and knowledge.  I think it is very important to ensure that this transition also includes ensuring healthy working conditions and safety for employees. I hope that all colleagues in the European Parliament will unite and, drawing on the studies and opinions of experts, fight together for a European circular economy.

name: Theodor Dumitru Stolojan (PPE)
text: in writing. – The circular economy is beneficial for both the economy and the environment. That is why it is welcome for the European Parliament to affirm its position on the content of a future draft European legislation, which the European Commission will prepare.  There are great differences between the Member States of the Union as regards the state of a circular economy, in particular in the recovery and reuse of waste from technological processes and household waste. I therefore argue that future European regulation should contain clear standards and targets for each Member State.

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: The next item is the own-initiative report by James Nicholson, on behalf of the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development, on the prospects for the EU dairy industry – review of the implementation of the milk package (2014/2146(INI) - A8-0187/2015).

name: James Nicholson
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, I would like to begin by thanking my shadow rapporteurs for their constructive input throughout this whole process. They say that a week is a long time in politics, but certainly I have to say that a year has been an extremely long time for dairy farmers over this last 12 months. Since last year, global supply has continued to outstrip global demand. We have seen the Chinese pull back from the market; we have seen the Russian embargo, and we have seen prices continue to tumble. We need only look at last week’s global dairy trade auction to see that volatility is wreaking havoc in the dairy market. The auction’s 5.9% decrease is the eighth decrease in a row and marked the lowest average price since 2009. Fact. The continuing fall in prices can no longer be dismissed as a blip. All the indications point to a dairy sector in crisis. I have repeatedly said that the Commission has failed to recognise the scale of the problem, despite assurances that were given in 2009. Commissioner Hogan may finally be starting to grasp it. In a recent interview on the BBC, he said he hoped the second half of 2015 would produce some evidence that we are coming out of this crisis. So I hope he will address that tonight and admit that there is a crisis in the industry. I hope that this is a long overdue recognition of what dairy farmers have been saying for some time. Is the Commissioner prepared to clarify his remarks and acknowledge that the sector is in crisis? In any case, Rabobank’s most recent report has made the Commissioner’s prediction look very optimistic, forecasting a recovery in the first half of 2016 at the earliest. Commissioner, dairy farmers cannot wait that long. Dairy farmers cannot wait until next year to see things turn. The Commission must act now. One measure that could make a real difference to dairy farmers in the short term would be a review of the current market intervention threshold. My report calls for a realistic safety net that accurately reflects production costs and market prices. In my own constituency, processers are paying an average base price of 20 pence per litre, with the average cost of production in Northern Ireland around 26.5 pence per litre. It does not match up. With the intervention rate so low, prices have fallen below the cost of production, and that is not unique to my area alone. We need to put a flow in the market to ensure no further decline arises. Another short-term major sector is the Russian ban. Mr Putin has now extended that embargo for another year in response to the latest round of EU sanctions. The onus is on the Commission to stand behind dairy farmers who continue to suffer the consequences of political decisions beyond their control. The Russian ban has emphasised the pitfalls in relying too heavily on one trading partner. Diversifying export markets is crucially important to the countries like my own, and we need to ensure that we diversify the markets and expand the markets that are already there. The Commission has made good progress in sourcing new outlets for our own quality European produce, but there is always scope to improve that. We also cannot ignore the longer-term challenges in the dairy sector. We need to look at imbalances in the supply chain between producer, processor and retailer, as well as own—brand labelling and the use of liquid milk as a loss leader by large supermarkets. We need to look at the possibilities of futures-market and fixed-term contracts, as more predictability would allow producers more flexibility. While these are major issues, I believe the single greatest challenge facing the dairy sector is volatility. Unfortunately, it is here to stay.

name: Phil Hogan
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I am very pleased to have the opportunity to participate in this evening’s debate. I welcome the fact that this is a full debate which reflects the importance of the European milk sector. It is a critical element of the EU agricultural sector, which is in itself a key driver of jobs and growth, contributing significantly to the Commission’s jobs and growth agenda. I want to convey my particular thanks to the rapporteur, Mr Nicholson, who has used his long experience in the sector to draft a report that is a very useful contribution to the debate that has surrounded the long-awaited and historic expiry of milk quotas just three months ago. But as he has said, this particular issue is not confined to that period of time. I read the report with interest, and I share most of the report’s assessment of the challenges and opportunities that lie ahead of the sector. Before commenting on some of the specifics of the report, I would like to say something about the current market situation. Perhaps not surprisingly, maybe even inevitably, there has been some price volatility following the end of quotas. This volatility, which has been contributed to by a global oversupply of milk, has led to downward pressure on milk prices, with the effects being felt most acutely in some Member States more than others. The EU average price in May was 30.48 cents per kilo. In absolute terms, and if applied consistently across the EU, this would represent a reasonable return for most farmers. However, I acknowledge that the variation in prices paid to farmers in different Member States can be quite significant. I am concerned about these developments, and I therefore instructed my services to assess the market situation more closely in terms of the Member States that have a very low price presently. In the Union, in 2014, we produced 4.5% more milk than in the previous year, while the other main world suppliers increased their output in the area of 2%. In 2015, and in spite of the limited reduction in deliveries during the first quarter, we are already on par with last year, and projections indicate that, in spite of moderate prices, we will end the year with an overall increase of 0.9%. Outlets have to be found for these quantities of milk. While we have some challenges to face, we are fortunate that we can count on a complete toolkit of measures available to the CAP to address these challenges, thanks to the work on the CAP reform by Paolo de Castro, Michel Dantin, Jim Nicholson and others.
