These are available, and these measures include the safety net tools, including the public buying-in of butter and skimmed milk powder as well as private storage aid schemes; the possibility to intervene in exceptional circumstances, as in the case of the Russian import ban; direct payments to support farmers’ income, including coupled support up to 13% of the national envelope; rural development policy, which allows farmers to finance investments, be better trained or receive compensation for being located in areas of natural constraint; the possibility to implement risk management tools; the milk package, which is yet to be fully exploited, and which can strengthen the integration of the producers in the supply chain; and the strengthening of the Milk Market Observatory Board, with more timely meetings and more time data available now, providing signals in the marketplace on a monthly basis. Dairy farmers can also benefit from the quality policy and from research and innovation, which are particularly relevant for producers oriented to niche products. We have more money in the promotion policy budget to accompany dairy operators in their search for new customers, and the identification of new markets is a personal priority for me. I have heard some suggestions recently that the Commission is doing very little to support dairy farmers. Any objective analysis of this matter certainly does not stand up to scrutiny. Let me illustrate the reality: the safety net measures – intervention in private storage, both for butter and skimmed milk powder – have been available to EU operators since last summer. By its rapid action, the Commission has provided economic actors with certainty and security. Special targeted support, for a total amount of EUR 40 million, was granted to dairy farmers from those Member States most directly hit by the Russian ban – the Baltic States and Finland in particular. After beef and veal, dairy is the second—largest recipient of voluntary coupled support, with 20% of the total amount, amounting to EUR 820 million in 19 Member States. As regards the Milk Package, which I said earlier has yet to achieve its full potential, we should not underestimate the huge progress that has been made. 13 Member States have provided for compulsory contracts. The number of recognised producer organisations is growing. What is more relevant is their impact on jointly-negotiated volumes of milk deliveries. In Germany and the Czech Republic, more than one-third of deliveries are negotiated by these organisations. In France, this figure is some 17%, and in Spain – 12%. Other Member States are following this welcome trend. The Commission recently approved 41 new programmes to promote agricultural products in the EU and in third country markets, worth EUR 130 million over three years. Some EUR 24 million are devoted to specific programmes on dairying. School milk schemes: last school year, 19 million children participated, with more than 300 000 tonnes of milk and milk products distributed for a total EU expenditure of EUR 66 million. As I mentioned, they have strengthened the role of the Milk Market Observatory. The economic board meets on a regular basis so that all actors can benefit from more timely and complete market information than ever. Some voices claim that increasing intervention prices is the solution. It is one of the options that are certainly mentioned in Mr Nicholson's report. In my view, this could be counterproductive, because this product has to be put out on the market in the future, and it is apparent that farmers and economic operators follow market signals. Let me also be very clear about proposals to increase intervention prices. This would do nothing but delay the inevitable – a necessary adjustment – and make it even more painful in the future, in our view. And as we move towards a market-orientated policy, which is the policy agreed by the legislators, such a move would give the wrong signal. There is a need to change our mindset. The goal is not to produce as much as we can, but as much as we can find a market for. While I accept that there is a short-term difficulty (being experienced in the milk sector – and I hope my words will not come back to haunt me, Mr Nicholson, in relation to that statement), I believe that we should concentrate our energy on helping the European dairy sector reap the full benefit of the long-term positive prospects in terms of world consumption.  This is a sector with enormous potential. There is an increased global demand of 2% and an increased middle class in the Far East. We must all work together to ensure that we get our main share of this particular market and achieve our full potential.

name: Petri Sarvamaa
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Budgetary Control. – Mr President, first of all let me salute the rapporteur for this very extensive report. There is hardly anything that is not mentioned, and it is very balanced. But I will not use my sixty seconds just for that. The most important thing that we have to understand is that we are not just talking about the price of milk or counting who gets how much – we are not counting milk drops. We are talking about a whole culture, and the disadvantaged regions in Europe deserve special attention. This has been pointed out in the report as well. In the Committee on Budgetary Control report that I drafted, I pointed out that that the price evolution does not actually seem to be homogeneous across Member States, and that the evolution of milk prices in real terms and its causes could have been strongly highlighted originally. This is something that we really have to pay attention to.

name: Gabriel Mato
text: PPE Group. – Mr President, Commissioner, I am intervening on behalf of Mrs Esther Herranz to highlight something that you know well. The milk-producing sector is living in very hard and nervous times in the face of the decline in market prices. Russia's announcement to extend the embargo against European exports of milk and other agricultural products has recently been added to the abolition of the quota regime last April. The sector has been dragging on difficulties in dealing with production costs and rising price volatility for years. Now, the situation is of great uncertainty and therefore needs the support of the European institutions. I believe that the European Commission and the Member States should listen to Parliament's complaints in the report we are going to vote on this week, in which we have tried to find solutions for the future. The European Union should be equipped with more appropriate and operational instruments than those offered by the current common market organisation to address the problems of the sector. For starters, the current safety net should be improved as it is completely inoperative. There should be an update of intervention prices that takes into account the reality of the market. On the other hand, a real crisis warning system must be put in place accompanied by the management tools necessary to prevent the collapse of the prices levied by farmers. It is of no use to have a European press observatory if it is not used in real time to alert you to the arrival of critical situations. To make efficient use of this observatory, it would be necessary to define crisis levels, in accordance with the indicators established for the whole European Union, which should include the loss of economic margins by dairy farms. It seems to me, moreover, that producer organisations should be endowed with greater bargaining power in the face of the links in the food chain in order to reduce the level of great helplessness in which farmers often find themselves. In many countries, like mine, the market is dominated by raw milk, so it is also necessary to encourage the improvement of the added value of production and innovation measures. Measures must be taken to prevent the use of milk as a claim by commercial establishments. The dairy sector is of great... (The Chair withdrew the floor to the speaker)

name: Ricardo Serrão Santos
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Commissioner, Mr Rapporteur, milk prices have been in free fall for more than a year, and current measures do not encourage the necessary generational renewal and investment. It is true that we want a competitive sector capable of orienting itself to exports, but not to the cost of abandoning production. Conditions need to be created for the resilience of dairy activity in the internal market in order for prices to compensate for production costs and to promote territorial cohesion. This needs to be ascertained the behaviour of industry and the large distribution in the value chain and the consequences for prices paid to producers.  I also call for the Commission's commitment to develop instruments for supply management, and others to protect against sharp reductions in income. In the short term, I call for a specific approach for less competitive and milk-producing regions, such as the Azores, in particular in identifying market disturbances.

name: Richard Ashworth
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, the end of milk quotas heralds a new era for the dairy industry. It is an era of great opportunity, but it will not be without its problems. Our rapporteur is right that the best way to help the industry is to create an environment in which the industry is best able to help itself. Immediately, we have to deal with the consequences of the Russian trade ban but, as is so often the case, this coincides with other factors, such as a very steep downturn in the global dairy market. Market volatility will remain a constant threat but, by encouraging and empowering farmers to cooperate, we can help them access opportunities. By strengthening the role of the European Milk Market Observatory, we can help the industry be better informed. By ensuring transparency in the food chain, we can help farmers to get a fair return from the market. Finally, we must be there to help the industry ride out the storm from the unpredictable and the unavoidable. Threats such as trade embargoes, volatility, extreme climate and the ever-present risk of disease will always be there. If we want to build a sustainable and competitive sector, we must be there to support them in times of difficulty.

name: Ulrike Müller
text: Mr President, I would like to like to take a iendled with the ALDE Group. Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has It was right to assess the milk package and to critically question what works and what needs to be improved in this regard. Within the EU countries, this package has been implemented in very different ways, and many have not taken advantage of the opportunities to set up producer organisations and pool milk producers. Even during the quota system, different milk disbursement prices of eight to ten cents were normal within the 28 Member States. The price of milk has never been uniform, and the dairy structure and the different production ranges would never have allowed it. Now, after the end of the milk quota, the situation on the milk market is very difficult. There is great uncertainty among farmers, not least because the Russian embargo was a political decision. We must not leave farmers in the rain here. Personally, three things were particularly important to me in this report: rapid data collection from the Member States in order to monitor the market in a timely manner and to take swift action, special protection for the less-favoured mountain areas – the importance of the dairy industry for rural areas and the cultural landscape is very high here – and, thirdly, to use the super-levy funds – EUR 900 million this last year – for specific purposes in the milk sector. The current situation in the dairy sector clearly shows that an effective safety net is essential to preserve family farms. The possible market measures are not enough. In addition to private storage, a moderate increase in the intervention price may also be necessary. In addition, the income-generating direct payments of the first pillar will continue to be an important addition in the future. I am very concerned about inequality in the supply chain. All Member States are called upon to support the possibility of bundling. I would like to thank the rapporteur, whose words I am happy to agree with. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: "blue card question." – I would like to ask Mrs. Representative whether, in addition to the many measures that have been put in place, she could support the obligation to conclude contracts between producers and processors, because I think most of the market uncertainties also stem from the fact that only half of the Member States currently have this mandatory contract system in place.

name: Ulrike Müller (ALDE)
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. Mr President, I would like to thank my colleague for his work Of course, I support any kind of contract between milk producers, between market partners and between dairies. This is done all the time in Germany. We now have really excellent dairy structures, which then also guarantee prices to farmers.

name: Matt Carthy
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, I get a sense that the consensus that had developed around the entirely positive prospects that the post-quota regime was going to bring about has abated somewhat. I believe that the caution that has now been expressed and the acceptance of the need to introduce a crisis-proof mechanism to protect farmers in what is likely to become an increasingly volatile market are very important. I want to commend Mr Nicholson for his work, but I would have preferred Parliament’s report to have been more adventurous in issues that would address price volatility, particularly around the issue of an intervention price. An intervention price is a strong tool to balance a volatile market, but the intervention price has to reflect the cost of production. Otherwise, by the time we reach it – unfortunately for many small and medium farmers – their livelihood is gone. I believe that the instruments have to sufficiently address the risks to farmers. Without the introduction of these safety nets, as outlined, we are seeing a bleak future for many of our dairy farmers.

name: Maria Heubuch
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Mr President, I would like to thank the Many thanks also to Mr Nicholson. He has certainly done his best to reconcile these different opinions in this report. There are also some elements in it that are right and important. However, I cannot speak in favour of this report because the overall orientation of this report is wrong. It continues to rely on an export strategy and relies too heavily on international markets. You have just described the problems we have with this, Mr Nicholson. It continues to build on rationalization and industrialization. These are developments which I consider to be very dangerous. Even more thousands of cowsheds are simply not accepted socially. Nor is there any balance at all in this report between animal production and plant production, and there is a complete lack of animal welfare. We need to bring milk back to grassland. We must bring milk to regions where milk production is reasonable, and that is precisely what the report has not sufficiently included.  We are now back at the beginning of a crisis. In Spain, 20 000 litres of milk have now been sprayed on the fields again. In France, dairy farmers are already mobilising again. In Spain, the aim is to reduce the price to eighteen cents. This is a situation that is not sustainable. With us in Germany, the German Farmers' Association is again asking for liquidity support. So we are crying out for money from the state, even though we have other instruments. At that point, Parliament was already further ahead. Mr Nicholson, you yourself said that we should not produce the milk that we cannot sell. Then we have to think again about supply management, and that is what I would ask you to do afterwards.

name: John Stuart Agnew
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, Jim Nicholson’s report gives a good overview of the present situation, as one might expect. What is absent is a clear strategy for the industry to ride out the current market pressures. Action is called for on symptoms without always a clear understanding of causes. The report highlights that the CAP has failed in its intended social outcome to keep farmers viable regardless of their size. However, this is not a reason to start market interventions with consequent trade distortions.  Calls for a cost-of-production formula assume that there is a single magical figure. In reality, cost of land to rent or for mortgage, repayment on loans for farm buildings and equipment, proportion of unpaid family labour, access to cheap by-products for feed, the impact of nitrate-vulnerable zones (NVZs) and other regulations make a single cost-of-production figure quite impossible. And of course, some producers concentrate on low-cost milk but have to accept lower prices, and some vice versa. If we want to keep farmers on the land for purely social reasons, then Pillar 2 is more appropriate. Current market pressures are affecting large farmers just as much as smaller colleagues, but the rush to expand, post-quota, is not always based on objective business planning. Despite these low prices, agricultural lenders tell me that they have plenty of requests from clients to fund dairy expansion. I would urge dairy farmers to look at the pig, poultry and egg sectors, because that is their future. In other words, a tightly-knit supply chain, intense communication from start to finish, and a willingness to adapt to consumer preferences, labelling of country of origin and persuading retailers to commit ... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Philippe Loiseau
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Mr President, the end of milk quotas leads to the concentration of farms, job losses and the destruction of rural areas. In 30 years, the number of dairy farms has been divided by five and 20% of dairy cows are located on farms with more than 100 cows. As a result, one in three farmers is at risk of disappearing in the coming years. Agriculture without a peasant, as survivors are obliged to obey the laws of free trade productivity, this is what we have been denouncing for 30 years.  Our farmers must also suffer the consequences of your diplomatic vassalisation with the Russian embargo, not to mention the consequences of your transatlantic treaty on the dairy sector. Your text therefore increases the supervision of producers vis-à-vis banks and private capital. Since the reform of CAP 92, farmers have been left with their feet tied to the laws of the market.  We have seen this again, most recently, in France, where producers' anger at mass distribution is becoming more and more despairing. Your plan is suicidal. It is the futures markets that are killing farmers, and you want to build on that mechanism. Also taking advantage of price volatility to increase competitiveness, as you ask in your project, is to have the will to sacrifice the least profitable farms on the altar of free trade. Smaller farms could also concentrate on the internal market, thus promoting local circuits and food independence, especially in disadvantaged areas, which would also be a means of preserving the territorial balance, as desertification threatens rural areas.  I would just like to finish, Mr President, to tell you that I am outraged by what Mr ... (The President withdraws the floor from the speaker)

name: Diane Dodds (NI).
text: – Mr President, I welcome this review of the milk package and offer my thanks to Jim Nicholson for his work on it. However, the immediate crisis facing the dairy industry in Northern Ireland is one of continuously low farm gate prices. In April 2014, dairy farmers in my constituency were receiving 28p per litre. In May 2015, they were receiving 21p per litre – a 23% fall in prices. The EU average has fallen by around 19% in the same time. Commissioner, you must confront the short-term reality facing the dairy industry. Farmers are constantly producing milk below the cost of production. If you do not take steps, the long-term outlook will include far fewer farmers and reduced production capacity. Yes, Commissioner, it is true that intervention has been opened, but I am disappointed to hear your negative view of reviewing intervention prices – prices that were set years ago with no relation to current... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Albert Deß (PPE).
text: Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has Milk production is one of the most important sources of income for many farmers in our European Union. The current price trend is a cause for concern. My cooperative dairy is still paying out more than 31 cents for June and more than 49 cents for organic milk, but what is to be done in the next few months is of great concern to me. Trade will demand prices that will bring dairy farmers to the brink of their livelihoods. Commissioner, we need tougher measures here. We were unable to decide on this in the context of the milk package. If now the milk price is at the bottom, then the trade demands price fixing for a whole year. If it is concluded at this lower level, but the market develops better again, we will be bound for a year to deliver to trading at this low price. I would suggest here that prices should be allowed to be concluded for a maximum of six months. This would mean that you would be back with us even at better times and not have to deliver a whole year at the lowest price.  The report mentions – and I am very grateful for this – the special situation of milk producers in the less-favoured areas, in mountainareas, on the islands and in the outermost regions. Accompanying measures are also needed here, which must be done through the second pillar. Commissioner, you also mentioned the situation following the Russia boycott. However, the Commission – you are not responsible for this, you have not yet been in office – has reacted far too late to help the farmers concerned in the Baltics and Finland.  When such situations occur, rapid action is required, and we must not wait for the child to fall into the well. That is why the issue of milk will continue to concern us, and we will also have to take other measures so that we can stabilise the situation for milk producers.

name: Clara Eugenia Aguilera García (S&D).
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, I believe that the majority of Members have agreed in the analysis of the current problems. Basically, I want to highlight the problem of price volatility. A Member has referred to Spain before – I am from Spain – what they are offering milk producers in my country is 16 euro cents. If that's justice, I don't know where we're going to be. I therefore highlight price volatility, ongoing crises that prevent them from growing, investing and marking a future, and the problems of the functioning of the European dairy single market. The safety net is absolutely ineffective, but I would like to talk to you about the dairy package. In my country it was carried out with compulsory one-year contracts and with that obligation. Three- and six-month contracts are now being made and are being breached. The situation is unfortunate, and this weekend for a purchase of 20 euros have offered me, I have been given... (The President interrupts the speaker)

name: Beata Gosiewska (ECR).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by I wanted to thank the rapporteur for this report for addressing such an extremely important problem. Although the Milk Package proposed by the Commission and its mechanisms are bureaucracy, not real aid. In many European Union countries, including my own country, Poland, the proposals for producer organisations have not worked. Meanwhile, the condition of dairy farms continues to deteriorate due to the Russian embargo, price volatility and imbalances in the supply chain. We are discussing support for milk producers here today, and yet the European Union has contributed to the degradation of Polish producers by imposing too low milk quotas, resulting in huge penalties destroying many producers in Poland.  I call on the Commission to present a legislative proposal as soon as possible... The President took the speaker's vote.

name: Jan Huitema (ALDE).
text: – The introduction of the milk quota in 1984 was a response to agricultural policy, which kept the milk price artificially high. Overproduction ensued and the policy of buy-back and export subsidies became far too expensive. However, politicians did not dare to drastically adjust price support and thus switched to volume control. Agricultural policy has become more market-oriented. The price of milk has been determined by supply and demand for the last seven years. Volume control by Brussels was from then on unnecessary. It is good that the milk quota has been abolished. Dairy farmers on the other side of the world told me that the European milk quota is the best thing that has happened to them. Milk prices are currently under pressure due to an unfortunate confluence of circumstances: demand failure in China, the Russian boycott and a hard landing of the milk quota. But to speak of a milk crisis at the same time, I think it's an exaggeration. 2013-2014 was a record year for dairy farming and the long-term prospects for the dairy market are rosy. I cannot support the call for a new system of volume control or an increase in intervention prices. We will lose our connection to the world market. That makes us less competitive. Moreover, direct payments will have to be reduced, which I cannot explain to other agricultural sectors. The common agricultural policy already has tools to support farmers. Don't make it too complicated and give farmers the space to compete on the global market.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, on the 17th in my country, in Galicia, there will be a major demonstration by milk producers and producers to demand solutions to this crisis, which is responsible: the Council, the Commission and all those Members who, in their day, approved the liberalisation of the sector, the abandonment of public dairy policy and the 'dairy package'. The "dairy package" that is not giving any answers. The solutions proposed here today, both the Commissioner and Mr Nicholson's report, are not a solution to this crisis. We need to return to a public dairy policy based on the regulation of production and the market, based on minimum prices covering costs and production work, which prioritizes the domestic market and is based on a production model linked to land and pastures. It's the only way out of this crisis.

name: Martin Häusling (Verts/ALE).
text: Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has I was just a little horrified because you are still not talking about a crisis, but about price fluctuations in the market. What are the 650 000 dairy farmers supposed to think of when their prices fall by 30%? Price fluctuations? I think you are far from any reality. We are in a real crisis, and this has to do with the liberalisation policy of recent years. You should finally acknowledge that.  You do not have the courage, or you do not want to think again about introducing market rules. What remains in this policy in the end is that we are again paying export refunds – the taxpayer is financing the export. Why do you shy away from a discussion, but think again about really regulating supply? I believe that strengthening milk producers over dairies and trade is really an instrument that has not yet been achieved. There are still far too few rights for dairy farmers, and we have a critical situation for all dairy farmers in the mountain regions. You must finally consider emergency aid, and we cannot wait for that.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, 31 years after their creation, milk quotas were abolished on 1 April. The situation is urgent and I believe that this report is timely. Admittedly, he is shy, but at the same time he is right. Timid because the proposals deserve to be stronger to support milk in Europe. Let's take the example of viticulture. Today, I think we can apply to the dairy sector what happened with viticulture. The regulation of planting rights has been won by winemakers. What we have achieved for the wine growers in favour of planting rights, why would it be different for milk? The dismantling of milk quotas in favour of the "milk package" is insufficient.  Parliament has prioritised the interests of multinational milk companies over the defence of small producers. I think it is urgent today to try to model viticulture to work on the milk sector.

name: Czesław Adam Siekierski (PPE).
text: – The situation on the milk market is extremely dynamic. There were regulations, there were quotas, there were crises. Now we have an embargo. What to do? When and how to intervene? Early intervention sends the wrong message, bad news for farmers, for the market. Too late intervention means high costs, brings losses to farmers and undermines their confidence in the common agricultural policy. We must not allow a serious crisis, so we need to reach for old, proven instruments. I think this is not against the free market. These instruments include an increase in the level of intervention prices for butter and milk powder, subsidies for the storage of selected cheese species, export subsidies and perhaps even direct financing of farmers, milk producers, if this situation proves as difficult as it promises.  Finally, we must work towards milk consumption in our countries. Not only to observe and support exports – which is important – but also to support consumption in the country. Finally, we need to look at the problems of guarantees, insurance – these are the new financial instruments that will support the market.

name: Eric Andrieu (S&D).
text: Mr President, Commissioner, European dairy farmers are experiencing a new crisis, which is leading to increased market instability and greater price volatility. This laissez-faire policy also promotes concentration of production and penalizes farms in the most fragile regions. I hear your optimism, Commissioner, but I cannot share it. I think we need to act, and we need to act quickly.  I call on the Commission to present regulatory tools to control supply and manage crises through responsive and effective safety nets. I insist that milk production be preserved in all territories, thanks to the support of rural development and a rebalancing of the aid of the first pillar. Finally, I call for a refinement of the current 'milk package' by strengthening the bargaining power of producer organisations, making contracts compulsory throughout the Union, incorporating binding clauses for buyers and extending them to distribution.

name: Jørn Dohrmann (ECR).
text: Mr President! Thank you to Mr Saunders. I would like to thank Mr Nicholson for his report on the prospects for the EU dairy sector and the opportunities of the agricultural sector. The milk sector employs many people, both directly and indirectly. Economic life has changed with large price fluctuations and capital costs. It is important to future-proof our dairy farmers. In this context, we are facing some challenges with regard to the Russian import ban, but also in terms of policy decisions and decision-makers - what is being imposed on farmers. It is the farmers who are paying the price. Mr Nicholson's proposal can help to shed light on the various challenges we face, but also on whether EU legislation is geared to ensure milk producers in the future. That is why the framework conditions will be one of the things we will be discussing in the future.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE).
text: - Mr. President, what is definitely a common characteristic of the milk market in the European Union is the obvious crisis. Obviously large milk production, higher than the market need.  However, the medicine for this milk market situation in the EU is not the same in every country. I am confident that various drugs can be found to resolve this condition. Speaking and coming from Croatia whose milk production is also in crisis, I am convinced that if milk producers were very stimulated in terms of milk processing to a higher level of products and if it were eu, Croatian and logal regional authorities policy, as I once tried to do in Istria, then we can come up with results. After all, in some other countries one may be able to do something similar to that in the field of fisheries, disincentive milk production, i.e. stimulate to convert production into something else.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL).
text: – As is acknowledged, the milk package has failed in its attempt to bring improvements in the position of milk producers on the market. Even with contracts integrated into organizations, milk producers are unable to negotiate an acceptable price for their product with industry. On the other hand, and without any alternative mechanism for regulating supply, this package is unable to respond to the increasing price instability of unpredictable nature.  We believe that supply management and pricing cannot be done so only in a mercantile logic. We therefore propose, from the European Milk Observatory, in conjunction with the national authorities, the introduction of sustainability criteria that take into account the production costs and economic and financial viability of the holdings.

name: Alyn Smith (Verts/ALE).
text: – Mr President, there is a sense of déjà vu in this debate. Grizzled old lags like myself and, perhaps, Mr Nicholson remember the debates with Mrs Fischer Boel as Commissioner a number of years ago. Colleagues, there is a structural problem in the European milk market, and as long as our farmers remain price takers, the sector will lurch from crisis to crisis. Commissioner Hogan, I very much appreciated your robust defence of the range of tools available to the Member States to intervene in their own markets and rebalance them in favour of primary producers, and I was very much struck by your phrase that the milk package has yet to achieve its potential. I absolutely do agree with you, so perhaps a bit of impetus from the Commission in naming and shaming those States that have not taken advantage of compulsory contracts, local processing, producer organisations, local labelling, school milk schemes, would help us have some clarity domestically on the fact that the solution to our milk crisis is very often closer to home. Could I suggest that if you are looking to be naming and shaming, then you start with the United Kingdom, because there are plenty of Scottish farmers who are suffering, as we do not have the tools to rebalance the market in Scotland ourselves, but London does.

name: Elisabeth Köstinger (PPE).
text: Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for his excellent work and for the work she has done. Thank you for the opportunity of this debate today and, above all, for our rapporteur, Jim Nicholson, for his report. I believe that he has done an excellent job here, because the dairy sector is a very sensitive area, which is also very different in Europe. We are called upon to take this into account. I would like to draw attention very briefly to those farmers who produce in Europe in less-favoured areas and in the mountainous region, who produce and produce milk under very great difficulty, not as museum farmers, but as very productive farms that bring high-quality products to the market – such as mountain cheese, mountain yoghurt and other things. We need specific measures and support here. It will not work differently in these areas and will not be any different, but only with specific measures. And I believe that Europe must not look the other way. We need these high-quality products, and above all we also need the services of farmers in these areas, which really guarantee comprehensive milk production in Europe. And here again my demand – and we have also discussed this in some debates – is that the revenue from the super levy, which really comes from the sector, should be returned to the sector for specific purposes. This would be a huge relief, especially for investment and the like, if it were to cost the European taxpayer nothing, because it comes from overproduction and it is a matter of fines for farmers. In that case, it would really be justified to return the payments.

name: Jean-Paul Denanot (S&D).
text: Mr President, the Commission explains to us that European farmers are now strong and armed enough to face international competition, to conquer new markets and to bear price volatility, which would be contained by what miracle. Elected from a rural area, I am concerned. I fear a territorial concentration of supply at the expense of small farms in fragile areas. I was able to point that out here five years ago when the dairy quotas were abolished. Unfortunately, what was planned happens today. Regulation is necessary for productions that have too volatile a price. I think it is necessary today to do this work. I am also concerned about the consequences on beef cattle farming, the collateral effects that could have on this farm too great difficulties in the dairy sector. Commissioner, I think we need to work harder and prepare a new producer organisation.

name: Zbigniew Kuźmiuk (ECR).
text: – Commissioner, i would like to thank you for your comments. The dairy sector in my country, Poland, is in a clear crisis as a result of the Russian embargo, as well as the lifting of milk production limits. The purchase prices of this raw material have already fallen by around 20%, while farmers are also being fined for exceeding production limits: €150 million this year, the previous €50 million. Despite the Commission's decision to spread these payments over three years, these will be a serious burden for Polish milk producers, accounting for almost 70% of the current price of a litre of milk to be collected. I therefore ask the Commissioner once again to take an interest in the situation of dairy farms in my country, because Poland, as Russia's only neighbour, has not benefited from the milk package aimed only at the Baltic states and Finland.

name: Hannu Takkula (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, first of all I would like to thank the rapporteur, James Nicholson. He raises very important issues in this report. All of us who have followed Parliament for a longer period of time know that James Nicholson knows this area.  I believe that Commissioner Hogan will also listen to Mr Nicholson's views on the agricultural and dairy sectors. I also think that the opinion of the Committee on Budgets, led by Petri Sarvamaa, was very sleazy. It is very important that the milk market is closely monitored and analysed in Parliament. It is important for us Finns that the report specifically highlights peripheral and disadvantaged areas. These regions are the first to suffer from the fall in milk prices, as the abolition of quotas will lead to an increase in production and, as a result, often to a reduction in price levels. If, on the other hand, the price level is low, the profitability of milk production will deteriorate, especially in less-affected areas, as production costs are higher than in areas with better natural conditions. I am also pleased that the report emphasises cooperatives and their role.

name: Luke Ming Flanagan (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, thank you very much, and congratulations to MEP Nicholson on his report. I will not be voting in favour of it. I am sure you are all aware of the story about the emperor’s new clothes and how it took a little boy to point out that actually the emperor was not wearing any clothes: he was stark naked. Well, we now have a situation here whereby we are told, let us say, for example, in Mr Nicholson’s territory, that it will cost you 26 cents per litre to produce milk and all you will get is 20 cents in return. So what are we going to do about it? Well what we are going to do is this: we are going to give loans to farmers who already cannot cover their costs to make up for this. It is fairly obvious what is going to happen down the line. You are going to have problems because they will not be able to pay back these loans. Also, the concept that additional Pillar 2 funds should be used to support the dairy sector will have a negative knock-on effect. As national governments use this government support to protect a previously unprofitable sector, it is obviously going to affect them too. I will be voting against.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE).
text: - Madam President, Mr Commissioner, I welcome this report by Representative Nicholson, which speaks unsubsidously of the pressing problems in the dairy sector. The sector is the most sensitive sector in agriculture, so it deserves special attention. Dairy producers are particularly vulnerable to the differences in revenues and risks that the market brings, and the demands for greater competitiveness of products are broken right across their backs. Manufacturers have high market energy production costs and prices are volatile. Ultimately, production costs often exceed milk sales prices, which leads small family farms to ruin. If we add to this the unfair trading practices and the Russian embargo faced by milk producers, then it is clear that it is necessary to take targeted measures and adopt a crisis program.  I call on the Commission to adopt a crisis programme, as without it milk producers will be in an even worse position and milk purchasers and large corporations will gain more power. I therefore emphasise the need to oblige milk purchaser to conclude longer-term contracts on an integrated supply chain, forward contracts and fixed margin contracts, in order to allow the milk price to be fixed corresponding to the actual production costs for a fixed timeframe. This is important because in many areas with difficult production, mountainous and island areas, milk production is the only generator of family income and employment and the continuation of milk production is important to avoid leaving the country and to keep young people living in the countryside.

name: Maria Noichl (S&D).
text: Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the Commissioner for his excellent work and for the work she has done. We all knew where the journey was going before the end of the milk quota. Commissioner, you knew, Mr Nicholson, you knew. Prices are falling. We have partly minus 30 percent compared to the previous year, and the trend continues. We are dealing not only with uncertainty in agriculture, but with a crisis, and this must also be clearly stated here. The solutions, Mr Nicholson, are lacking, and there is also a lack of strategy. Your report is really an expression of helplessness. They point to the horizon, where the promised land would be: overproduction, more exports, opening up new markets, more competition, more soft, more and more growing and softening. That is your horizon, that is where you are interpreting – without appropriate regulatory mechanisms, without appropriate intervention mechanisms for milk producers and without a real strategy.  But you are doing this with the knowledge that the crisis is costing farms in Europe every day. This crisis, when we go back to export, also costs farms in the countries of the South.

name: Daniel Dalton (ECR).
text: – Madam President, I would also like to thank the rapporteur for an excellent report, which I think was particularly well researched, particularly in the beginning. Times are tough for dairy farmers. They face extra costs, notably with regard to access to feed, and the decisions they make are often long term as it is not easy to turn on and off production. Many farmers in my region are struggling with TB as well. It is a tough industry to work in and they face volatile times. But quotas and supply management are not the answer. We cannot hold back the whole of the EU just because of a few small farms in the mountains or in islands. However, we do need to make sure that farmers remain on the land in all parts of the EU. I think this is down to the Member States. They have the tools in the CAP. In Pillar 1 they have coupled payments, LFA payments and redistributive payments, and they also have rural development programmes. I think the key is rural development programmes for the future, and that the Commission should be more proactive in helping Member States design such schemes and, if necessary, change the rural development rules.

name: Stefan Eck (GUE/NGL).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Thank you, Commissioner. The phasing out of the milk quota will further increase intensive livestock farming in this area. This will lead to a dramatic decline of small farms throughout the Union. They have no chance against automated livestock farming. In short, without a quota, there will be no market stabilisation, and the crisis will continue.  And how can it be that one can speak in favour of the abolition of the milk quota and thus of more production, even though it is now whistling the sparrows from the roofs: milk is a product that makes us human beings sick. Talk to nutritionists! Milk is extremely harmful to the environment and, incidentally, milk production is an unacceptable animal cruelty. Finally, have the courage to take an ethically ambitious approach: less milk from turbo cows, less milk-related diseases, less environmental and groundwater pollution from manure and from feed cultivation in huge monocultures and more animal welfare!

name: Annie Schreijer-Pierik (PPE).
text: Mr President, thank you to our rapporteur. In the Netherlands, the milk price currently stands at 30 cents per kilo. The actual cost in the family business is at least 40 cents per kilo of milk. As a result of the fall in the demand for dairy products from China and the Russian boycott, dairy production is no longer cost-covering in the Netherlands. The sector is under pressure. Last year I warned of the potential risks that the end of the milk quota could pose to our family and family businesses. As the dairy sector faces an uncertain future, we need to see what instruments we can use if the current situation persists. This also applies to other sectors. A fair sandwich for farmers and farmers at the kitchen table and the preservation of the dairy sector in Europe are of great importance. Dairy farming plays an indispensable role for our countryside, our food security, the economy, tourism and agricultural nature management in the Netherlands and in Europe. This may cost money, but we must be careful not to take hasty measures that distort the market. (The President deprives the speaker of the floor.) The European Commission is finally providing scope for closing the cycle, of which the innovative mineral concentrate is also an indispensable part. This is essential for the preservation of the vital agricultural sector in the Netherlands and in Europe, especially for dairy farming, because manure sales are the biggest expense in the Netherlands. Commissioner, you will be able to take steps here at no cost.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, European milk producers are operating against a background where economic crisis, falling domestic consumption and the Russian embargo are creating an unsustainable situation and the increase in milk production at European level, following the end of the quota system, can only have serious repercussions on the collapsing price and on the margins of producers that are becoming increasingly reduced. We therefore need new supply management tools, not comparable to those of the previous ones, to counter extreme price volatility.  The new agricultural guarantee model, presented by the European Investment Bank (EIB) last March, could be used by Member States to create new financial instruments and facilitate access to credit for dairy farmers. Eib intervention to manage the end of the milk quota system could be an important step: financial support from the EIB, in synergy with rural development programmes, would enable the dairy sector to achieve a multiplier effect in terms of growth and income. And among the many problems there is also some light. I am referring to the increase in world demand for milk and cheese, which is growing on European markets: new markets are opening up and it is therefore essential to encourage exports in order to guarantee the future and protect the income of European farmers.

name: Sofia Ribeiro (PPE).
text: – Madam President, Commissioner Hogan, we are again discussing the situation in the milk sector at European level and we all recognise that milk has cyclical crises. However, this is not a normal crisis, as not only is it not expected to resolve it, but its impact is being stronger than expected. We are also all sure that the Milk Market Observatory must have crisis management mechanisms, and for this you need to work with constantly updated data, which has not always happened. This extremely negative situation runs through the sector across Europe, it is true, but it is a particular focus on the Azores, an outermost European region whose milk production accounts for 46 % of the regional economy, in which its producers are looking to us to ask for help, given the distressing situation they are experiencing. We are talking about a drop of between 9 and 14 cents in the price of a litre of milk, which is equivalent to an estimated loss so far of around EUR 20 million. It is a very sharp break that becomes urgent to mitigate. Commissioner, we are all well aware of the importance of this sector for the Azores and the extremely difficult situation it is experiencing in this scenario of milk market liberalisation. I have heard him acknowledge our difficulties, and this House has also recognised them by voting positively for many of my proposals to protect the sector in this report. In this regard I ask you for help, on behalf of the producers of the Azores, so that we can maintain the traditional milk production in our region, with all the social and family benefits, environmental, economic and other. I am counting on your help to implement two of my proposals adopted in the Committee on Agriculture quickly – I am finishing – such as creating a mechanism for the Azores, transitioning to the end of quotas, and increasing POSEI.

name: Laurențiu Rebega (S&D)
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to stress once again that, over time, it has become increasingly clear that the price of milk and farmers' incomes have not been supported and stabilised sufficiently effectively.  I agree with the rapporteur that the implementation of the measures introduced by the Milk Package is patchy in the Member States and I am very concerned for small producers. For example, the elimination of quotas will lead in Romania, according to estimates, to the imminent disappearance of some 800 000 small local producers. I believe that the European Union's policy on the dairy production of small producers should be supported to prevent it from being abandoned, and that is why I recall some of the threats facing the sector: the closure of the market with Russia, the invasion of some markets of cheaper products from some countries in the European Union, unfair competition and food fraud on the agri-food chain , on the milk line, large social disparities in rural areas, lack of alternation in rural jobs. The European Commission must strengthen the stabilisation of the retail market in order to regulate the making of profits by small producers and support the strengthening of small producers' associations, especially in Eastern Europe. I hope, Commissioner, that you are considering this.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE).
text: Madam President, I would first like to thank Mr Nicholson for his new work on milk, three years after the report which prepared the 'milk package'.  Commissioner, when we designed this 'milk package', very few wanted contracts, let alone long contracts. We had to fight to enshrine these contracts in the European texts.  I see that today, as a result of the crisis, things have changed a little. These tools must no doubt be consolidated and a framework that has real visibility for both producers and other players in the dairy sector. When the price of milk was good for producers, we were told that we should not make contracts, that it was much better like that; the industrialists themselves did not want contracts. Today, the tone is changing, industrialists are also finding that it would be better for them to have volumes guaranteed over time. I believe that this policy must be pursued, but at the same time we must remember that milk is a tool of land use policy.  The observatory we have set up gives us important elements. It must be completed on the charges component. I would remind you that in the CMO we have now introduced a criterion which allows the Commission to intervene when producers' expenses reach a price that is no longer in relation to the market price. There is probably a way to explore.  You told us, Commissioner, in a previous speech, that the Commission had taken export action to counteract the Russian problem. I think we do have to continue on that path. The industrialists tell us that they need help to conquer new markets and when I talk about industrialists, I also think of cooperatives. The Commission must completely fulfil this role of VRP alongside them, to help them sell not only milk and milk powder, but also cheeses, processed products and high value-added products.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE).
text: – Madam President, the milk sector is one of the most vulnerable sectors in agriculture. I congratulate Commissioner Phil Hogan on his work, but at the same time I believe that there needs to be a more vigorous concern on the part of the Commission so that the most effective means to protect this sector are identified.  The disappearance of milk quotas seriously and unacceptably exacerbates the imbalances between large and small farmers, so that the existence of the latter is seriously jeopardised. The embargo imposed by Russia on dairy products and beyond is likely to cause market changes, generating imbalances in countries that did not have direct trade relations with them. Thus, in some countries, including Romania, the price of milk has reached ten eurocenters per litre, well below the cost price, with small farmers on the verge of imminent bankruptcy.  In view of price volatility, the Commission must immediately introduce measures into its work programme to strengthen and protect this sector at European level, and finding new markets such as that offered by TTIP, as well as developing existing ones, must be a major concern. Mechanisms, including tax facilities, should also be created to stimulate the establishment of associations and producer organisations capable of processing milk into finished products and further to create their own outlets to manage. Only then will we be able to talk about security in the milk sector.

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE).
text: – Madam President, the milk sector is a key sector of agri-food production and the Czech Republic is no exception. However, the sector also has great potential for employment, as has already been said here. But he has big problems today and we have to deal with that. It is clear that the Commissioner is also looking for a positive solution and has stressed the importance of a market mechanism. I agree with him, but at the same time we must see that milk producers have difficult conditions, demanding ecological and hygiene requirements, facing the effects of the Russian embargo, a very volatilityd market and low milk purchase prices. I therefore agree with the European Parliament's call for the European Commission to come up with new instruments that will help stabilise the situation on the milk market and make milk production more attractive. The new measures should aim at strengthening producer organisations and strengthening their competitiveness.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D).
text: – Madam President, dairy farmers continue to be hard hit by the combination of the ending of the milk quota regime and the effects of the Russian embargo. I congratulate my colleagues from the S&D Group who put emphasis on the situation of the primary producers and particularly those operating on a smaller scale on family farms or from more remote areas. The risks of further concentration of milk production in more competitive areas is still a lurking threat for such farms, and the report now contains a set of proposals and demands which could form a minimum set of safeguards. I am confident that the S&D Group Agriculture Committee members will remain in close contact, and if the situation deteriorates we will ring the alarm bells again in the future to ensure primary dairy production is safeguarded. Finally, I believe it is important to strengthen the Milk Market Observatory to give producers more timely access to accurate market information.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). Madam President, the common agricultural policy must aim at balanced territorial development from an economic and social point of view. This means that livestock farming must continue to be productive and sustainable, especially in remote and mountainous areas.  In Greece in particular, dairy production in the Aegean islands has been hit. In addition, island and mountain regions have increased costs of producing, collecting and marketing milk and milk products. Special care must be given to livestock. PDO products must also be given effective protection, in particular the Greek feta cheese facing unfair competition, both in the European Union and in third countries such as Canada. Moreover, the dairy sector has suffered enormous economic damage as a result of the Russian embargo.  Finally, the troika with its policy in Greece dissolves the primary sector, increases the cost of production and supplies. But the troika got the answer it deserves with the massive no of farmers in yesterday's referendum.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE).
text: – I am really pleased that this issue is being discussed today and I thank my colleague James Nicholson for his work, but I want to say that, unfortunately, this problem is only growing and exacerbating. This is a very important issue for the village. And I want to say that processors are already so arbitrary that , for example, last week in Lithuania for twelve euro cents refused to buy all the milk and farmers were forced to pour part of the milk into the cramps. These are absolutely intolerable things. And I believe that if we do not want to regulate at European level, then we must, as soon as possible, enable the Member States to do so. And for those countries where milk buying prices are significantly below the European average, we need to provide support as soon as possible, otherwise the huge Amount of European money invested will simply lose out. That's what we then invest if we don't then make it possible to protect those investments.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: – Madam President, in one minute it is difficult to cover all aspects of the problem under investigation, i.e. the fall in milk prices. I would dare to draw attention to only one aspect. It is pointless to push the market if the market is working properly. If it doesn't work, I think some action is needed. I would like to say that the reaction at European Union level should concern the adjustment of the intervention price for milk and the extraordinary introduction of export refunds in order to find new outlets for surplus milk on the European market. Of course, this is a cumulative effect, with the Russian embargo pushing milk out of this market, and this surplus should be addressed by finding adequate new markets. I think that would be the Commission's main task, which is why I hope that the Commissioner will continue to address this issue.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR).
text: – Madam President, the abolition of milk quotas has been met with great reservation and visible concern in a large number of small producers because they fear that such a move will lead to a decline in the competitiveness of their production in relation to large production structures in the dairy industry. I share this concern of theirs, but not because I consider the quota system particularly good, but because I believe we have not done nearly enough to ensure a level playing field for small producers.  The rapporteur is heading in the right direction with his recommendation to encourage short supply chains and give local production benefits, especially in the island and outermost regions. I also consider it very important that Member States provide their small milk producers with maximum support in informing and educating them to make better use of european funds.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE).
text: – Congratulations to my colleague Nicholson for his excellent report. He can be seen to be a good connoisseur of this area and has pointed to virtually all the problems we face at the moment when, on the one hand, we have abolished quotas and, on the other, Europe has also benefited from the Russian embargo on food imports. In some areas, these problems are all the more severe because the production conditions are due to small farms, due to the difficult conditions of cultivating on mountain farms, so much heavier and the cost price is higher and the price pressure is greater by the day. That is why the report also shows well in the area that talks about better integration of farmers, the search for new markets and, of course, the search for quality products that will also be able to achieve better prices in local care, tourism complexes, better prices, and – especially for farms with more difficult conditions – also a reasonable income.

name: Mairead McGuinness (PPE).
text: – Madam President, just a few points in relation to the actual report itself. I would be concerned about the conflict between paragraphs 22 and 24, and I hope that the vote will clarify the situation. The one thing that producers want – well two things – are good prices, which they are not getting at the moment – we all accept that – and policy certainty. We have therefore told producers that quotas are gone, and they are working and planning on that basis. On the price side, all I would say to the Commission is: do not do what happened the last time and intervene too late. Let us be very clear on that. We need to do more on the retail side within the European Union. Fresh milk is disregarded by retailers; it is sold at a low price, and that needs to be looked at. I look at that in my report, and I know that the Commissioner has an interest in that as well. Finally, I do not think it is an issue about large and small producers, because large producers are more at risk in times of price volatility. I think we need to look at the future for all dairy farmers.

name: Phil Hogan
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I want to again thank Mr Nicholson as rapporteur of this report and to thank all the contributors to this debate. I want to acknowledge that there are challenges arising from changes in policy, but also that in the market place there is considerable volatility, and that has been acknowledged by me and indeed other speakers in this debate. So we are as one in terms of acknowledging that there are challenges in that area at the moment. But there are many tools that I have outlined in my contribution earlier, that have been used to cushion incomes for dairy producers. And one of the ones I mentioned was the voluntary coupled support, where EUR 820 million has been spent, and is being spent over the next few years, in helping dairy producers in 19 Member States. I will give you some examples in terms of how it is impacting farmers in some Member States: this turns into EUR 74 a cow in the mountainous areas of France that Mr Andrieu mentioned, up to EUR 530 a cow in Finland, EUR 300 a cow in Hungary, EUR 114 a cow in mountainous areas in Spain, EUR 250 per cow in Romania, EUR 65 a cow in Croatia and EUR 145 a cow in the Azores under the POSEI scheme, in addition to whatever the regional government wishes to give under the rural development programme. I give those as examples of where policies are being put in place to cushion the incomes of dairy producers, which has often been ignored: the contribution and the choices that you as legislators have given to Member States and regional governments in order to do that. Market intervention thresholds always come up but, as I mentioned in my contribution, the product that goes into intervention has to be put on the market at some place in the future. It is interesting at the moment that skimmed-milk powder is not going into intervention, and it would be interesting to analyse the reasons why. I am very conscious of the Russian ban and its impact on agricultural exports from dairy, and I am looking into how we can actually assist producers and, in taking account of some of the measures that have been made already, how we can roll those over in the future. I hope to be in a position to come back to those particular measures for farmers and for people in sectors other than dairy in the future. New markets are very important. In fact, butter products have achieved a buoyancy in 2015: up 8% in the first quarter, while skimmed milk powder has gone up 17%. Other products, like cheese, have gone down. So there are certainly some measures where the glass is half full. There is certainly a need for more promotion, and the budget has been increased in order to find third-country markets. In terms of volatility, there is a structural issue (I think Mr Smith is quite correct about that) in some Member States, particularly in the United Kingdom. I think that we need to look at ways in which we can assist in the establishment of better contractual relations between farmers and the industry and how some coops – in fact in some Member States – are establishing a lock-in price over a period of time at a very reasonable price. There are structural problems, I agree. At the European Investment Bank, in spite of what my friend Mr Flanagan said, it is not a compulsory option to take out a loan, but there are opportunities for people to get access to finance whether they are young farmers or whether they are people who want to expand. The food chain continues to be a source of concern, and we are watching carefully what is happening in the United Kingdom and Spain in order to give us some experience, and we look forward to the report of Ms McGuinness later this year, which will give us more information and explanation about what action we can take in order to improve the situation for the producer here. Super-levy instalments are the only policy vehicle at my disposal, because it was agreed by legislators back in 2003, confirmed in 2008 and again in 2013, that we were going to have a super levy. Farmers produced more milk in 2014 knowing that they were going to have to pay a super levy. The Council of Agricultural Ministers could not reach an agreement on a soft landing in relation to the super levy payments, so I did what I could, which was to apply a three-yearly interest-free instalment arrangement for the payment of that money. I will do what I can to maintain as much of that money as possible in the agricultural sphere. These are important issues that have been raised here this evening. I can certainly say, in the context of the Russian ban, new markets and volatility of the food chain, that we are making considerable efforts to implement measures that will meet the concerns you have expressed. There are direct support provisions which have not been mentioned too loudly here tonight, but I am bringing to your attention the fact that a considerable amount of expenditure – EUR 820 million – is cushioning farmers, even though the price of the product is reducing. I again want to thank the speakers – the rapporteur in particular – and the shadow rapporteurs for their input, and it has produced sufficient information for me to be able to take cogniscence of measures that can perhaps be taken in future on many of the areas that have been mentioned in the report.

name: James Nicholson
text: rapporteur. – Madam President, can I first of all take the opportunity to thank everyone who participated in the debate. I think what it has proved here tonight is that there are many problems facing the dairy sector throughout the European Union. They may differ in different regions, and there may be different problems, but certainly the problems are there. There is not much doubt about that. I would also like to thank the Parliament services for ensuring that we had a full debate on this report tonight. That has proven to be very worthwhile as well. I am totally in agreement with many of the things that were said. The report covered wide issues, and none more than the needs of people in mountainous areas and peripheral areas. I tried to address that, and it is not an easy problem. It is a very serious problem, and it is more difficult for those who actually live in those areas. I have to be honest, Commissioner: I think that the Milk Market Observatory is not fit for purpose as it stands. You are going to have to do more, and you are going to have to do it more quickly. I would hope that, by autumn, you will come to the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development (AGRI) with proposals as to what you are going to do there. Now is not a time to be following in Europe – we should be leading in Europe. I also believe that the money collected in the super levy should be kept within the industry and should not be taken by any other parts of the industry or given to any other parts of the Commission. Everybody speaks about volatility, but nobody has really got the right idea about how we actually deal with it or how we handle it. It is a very difficult subject. I would like to echo what Mairead McGuinness said: do not leave it too late. Mariann Fischer Boel promised us in the AGRI Committee, when she was in your position, that never ever again would dairy farmers have to wait so long for support. Do not leave it too late. Commissioner, I fear your honeymoon period is coming to an end. I noticed in my local agricultural press at the weekend that my local minister said that you and your staff were living in ivory towers in Brussels. I would not say that about you, because I know you are a much cleverer man. You will take on board the many things that have been said about the Commission here tonight. However, we do need the Commission to take action, to take these views on board, and to do something in the name of the dairy farmers who are suffering hardship at this present moment in time.

name: La Présidente. –
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Tuesday, July 7, 2015 at 1 p.m. Written statements (Article 162)

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. – Dear Colleagues, the report on the prospects for the EU dairy industry is extremely important for countries such as Bulgaria, where the dairy industry provides many jobs, especially in the least developed regions of the country. I would especially like to thank rapporteur Nicholson, with whom I had the opportunity to discuss the problems of Bulgarian dairy farmers and processors, as well as the position of the Bulgarian Government on this dossier. I am pleased that following the discussions and negotiations on the dossier, the proposal pays special attention to the impact of the Russian embargo, as well as the assistance of the most affected countries such as Bulgaria. The second main argument in the proposal is that previous decisions on quotas must be maintained in order to avoid further market volatility. The abolition of quotas risks an additional concentration of milk production for the benefit of the largest dairy farms and is detrimental to the smallest ones, such as producers from Bulgaria. I fully support Mr Nicholson's work and wish him every success in future negotiations.

name: Viorica Dăncilă (S&D)
text: in writing. – The current context on the milk market after the expiry of quotas requires particular attention to be paid to milk producers, who are facing a new state of affairs. Price volatility is an essential aspect that needs to be taken into account, given the experiences so far, but also the increasing competition in the milk market. Manufacturers should be able to foreshadow some price margins in order to develop a market strategy tailored to the actual market requirements.  I believe that a revision of the reference price for the products subject to intervention is necessary so that the measures adopted so far by the Commission are effective and more attractive. I believe that the Milk Market Observatory could be improved by equipping it with a set of indicators for better market monitoring. These indicators should provide information on price margins and include both the Member State and the regional dimension, without increasing the administrative burden. However, this transparency should protect the interests of the various entities on the milk line.

name: Norbert Erdős (PPE)
text: Writing. – Following the end of the milk quota in April, dairy farmers are even more exposed to fluctuations in milk prices on the world market and to commercial practices in international food chains which in many cases harm producers. The European Union therefore needs to focus on protecting the interests of dairy farmers and strengthening the dairy sector. My fellow Northern Ireland MEP James Nicholson has put a producer-focused report on the table. I agree with him that the milk package's policy based on producer organisations and the strengthening of producers' bargaining power in negotiating are the paths on which we must move forward. Specific efforts should also be made to protect dairy farmers in disadvantaged areas and mountainous areas. The amounts withdrawn by the milk production levy should be kept within the agricultural budget and used for the competitiveness of the dairy sector.  The powers of producer organisations need to be further strengthened and their influence on the establishment of collective supply contracts should be further increased. The performance of the Milk Market Observatory still needs to be improved. Both of Hungary proposals to increase the effectiveness of crisis management have been included in the report. The European Commission should be called on to adjust intervention prices to the real market price and production costs. Furthermore, in the event of a major crisis, the application of export refunds should be activated on a temporary basis. These proposals shed light on the fundamental shortcomings of EU crisis management and concern the market functioning of all product pathways.

name: Владимир Уручев (PPE)
text: in writing. – Dear Colleagues, the situation in the milk sector in a number of Member States is alarming – the buying-in prices of raw milk and cheeses continue to fall. Since January this year, the buying-in prices of milk in Bulgaria are at the lowest levels in 5 years. In addition to the abolition of the quota regime on milk and milk products, the extension of the Russian embargo by another year further complicates the situation in the sector. I welcome the report as it proposes a number of measures to strengthen the bargaining position of dairy farmers and their ability to withstand market crises (strengthening contractual relations, stimulating association in the sector, risk management tools). Price volatility, as a consequence of the abolition of quotas, requires further action to preserve the livelihoods of the most vulnerable – small producers, producers in mountainous and disadvantaged areas. I therefore call for the return of superannuation funds back to the sector, providing for temporary emergency support to EU dairy farmers if the situation continues to deteriorate. The Russian embargo showed the shocks of losing a particular external market. The challenge now is to optimise domestic consumption, which can be promoted through various promotional measures, guarantee schemes, additional payments for the products concerned (e.g. cheese) as well as through the school milk scheme.

name: La Présidente. –
text: The agenda calls for one-minute speeches on important political issues (Article 163 of the Regulation).

name: Mairead McGuinness (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I just wanted to raise the issue this evening of the Falsified Medicines Directive and to say that, from 1 July, there is a requirement on all registered pharmacies in the European Union to have a logo so that people buying medicines online can be sure of the provenance of those drugs. We know that over 60% of drugs bought online by citizens are falsified, and some of these drugs have caused the deaths of citizens in the European Union. At the moment a young man’s death in Ireland is being investigated because of a product he bought online. However, I think we have a bigger problem with websites outside the European Union. The Commission needs to look at other ways of informing citizens, as well as tackling the issue of websites that are offering not only medicines, but prescription medicines – very dangerous products – with those who are buying them being unaware of whether they are safe to consume. So it is a warning to consumers. Watch for the logo.

name: Jude Kirton-Darling (S&D).
text: – Madam President, our global climate talks in Paris this December are a critical opportunity which we should not miss. A strong, comprehensive and globally-binding deal will provide a clear signal to citizens and governments worldwide that we are committed to the massive transition needed to tackle climate change. But for any agreement made in Paris to be truly meaningful for working people, here and abroad, the concepts of change management and a just transition must be included in the global deal. It is only by creating decent jobs in up-and-coming industries, inspiring people to innovate through their participation at work and ensuring that social security systems guarantee protection in times of change, that we will win public trust and support for the transition. We urgently need to tackle dangerous climate change. This opportunity should not be lost. It must be grasped.

name: Marcus Pretzell (ECR).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which The Greeks voted. A people decides their own policies, not the troika, not the Chancellor, nor the President of this House, Martin Schulz. Now the Eurogroup is desperate and has three problems. Firstly, it has a hammer, but no nail, because Greece does not want to be a nail. Secondly, Greece is insolvent, but there are no rules for that.
