Thirdly, no country can be kicked out of the euro, the EU treaties do not allow that.  The result: the Greeks can tell us not to implement the austerity programmes; they just did. Secondly, they do not want to repay their debts, they have started with the IMF; this is called insolvency. Thirdly, you want to keep the euro; this is called a huge disaster for all Euro-saviours.  Their concept has failed. What do we learn from this? Absolutely nothing! For the AfD and other Euro-realists in Europe have long predicted it. And the majority of this House? Tomorrow, too, you will be incomprehensible about your mistakes at the expense of the peoples of Europe. Shame on you!

name: Илхан Кючюк (ALDE).
text: – Madam President, honourable Members, I take the floor in the one-minute speech procedure to introduce you to the already publicly acquired case of "Bullet Mosque", City of Sofia. Karlovo, Republic of Bulgaria. Under the pretext "Let's reveal the scientific truth" the local government of karlovo municipality tries to oppose institutions, leading historians and the public. Being aware that a Muslim necropolis from the early 19th century was discovered at the beginning of the excavation, we insist that scientific studies are not an excuse for the de-ation of these graves. The frantic digging around a building, the subject of a fierce legal dispute, suggests that the procedure for granting permission to carry out the excavation has been carried out.  From the grandstand of the European Parliament, I address the Bulgarian Minister of Culture.  Mr Minister, please carry out due diligence on compliance with the procedure and make its results public. In addition, in case of discovery of artifacts related to the Muslim religious and secular tradition, the Muslim confession of the Republic of Bulgaria should be notified. Graduating, I sincerely hope that you will not give me further reason to speak out on this and other similar occasions. (The President took away the speaker's word)

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, another programme document signed by the five presidents, five protagonists of this European tragicomedy, has recently been published, a document which represents another piece in the neoliberal deepening of the European Union. This document leaves us perplexed. There are now 125 million people in the European Union at risk of poverty and social exclusion. That's 24 million unemployed. The youth unemployment rate doubled between 2007 and 2014. But the crisis is not an exclusive one of the countries of the South. Finland, the true mecca of neoliberalism, is sinking with three years in a row of recession and a cumulative drop of 5% of its GDP.  When one would expect a deep reflection on the model of European integration, we see the publication of another document that reveals complete blindness and insists on the same recipes, killing the patient with healing. Fortunately, events show us more and more people who are beginning to believe that this model is not a fatality. Another Europe is possible, and it is to be built by the people.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE).
text: – Transparency International Slovenia is a non-governmental and non-profit organisation with a status in the public interest, part of the largest international anti-corruption network in the world - Transparency International.  For the purpose of setting up anti-corruption tools and raising public awareness, they themselves have gained more than half a million euros, liaising different institutions from abroad and providing jobs for 5 experts. These jobs are now at serious risk because Slovenia still does not have a direct funding system in place for the work of NGOs in the fight against corruption.  In the event of further non-financing, it could face a complete downs and slovenia would thus become one of the few countries in which there would be no representative of the largest international anti-corruption organisation in the world. There is an urgent need to find appropriate solutions to enable such an important organisation to continue to operate, as public confidence in the functioning of the state is increased in the case of greater transparency.  This is crucial for the good functioning of democracy, which is why the European Commission also highlights the need to strengthen the fight against corruption, further reforms in the area of public procurement and the integrity of the public sector.

name: Margot Parker (EFDD).
text: – Madam President, lately we have seen the President of the Commission trying to bargain as to how many migrants he can ship out of Italy and across the borders into Member States. The bargaining has been masking the fact that child migrants are already being shipped across borders in their thousands. An investigation by CNN has shown that thousands of migrant children that arrive in Italy are disappearing into the drugs trade and sex trafficking. Free movement in the Schengen area makes this easy. A child can be taken by a trafficker in the infamous Termini station in Rome and put into a car, and there will be no responsible official to stop the trafficker and save this small victim anywhere between Rome and Stockholm. A Europe without frontiers means child sex trafficking without checks of any kind.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF).
text: Madam President, as you know, on 11 May a hearing was held, following the European citizens' initiative Stop Vivisection, which has gathered more than 1.2 million signatures.  This initiative calls on the Commission to repeal the 2010/63/EU Directive in order to make a new proposal that would put an end to animal testing and make it mandatory for biomedical and toxicological research to use data relevant to the human species. That would go in the right direction!  The Commission does not intend to present a new proposal. She is only embarking on a vague conference in 2016. As if that were enough. Until recently, France has authorized the extension of a primatery in Alsace, about which animal associations reveal that the primates held come from intensive breeding and live in terrible conditions. This cruelty to animals does not even have the excuse of being beneficial to humans, because the animal model is not transposable to man. Indeed, contrary to what some lobbies say, make us believe that the drugs for Alzheimer's disease tested ... (The President withdraws the floor from the speaker)

name: Janusz Korwin-Mikke (NI).
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab The stupidest system in the world, democracy, is constantly being praised in this Parliament under the heavens, but when you saw the action of democracy in Greece, no one said it was the fault of democracy, you are just trying to come to an agreement with the people.  Well, ladies and gentlemen, people do not understand why democracy is a bad regime, people do not understand why Mrs Thatcher called the European Union a "sick idea of left-wing intellectuals", but people know that they are poorly ruled.  Greece is invalid, you will see Brexit, you will see Fraexit, then we will see who will turn off the light. One thing I have to say is that I think the European Union must be destroyed.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I would like to remind you at the beginning of my speech that today is an extremely important day for The Czech Republic, the Czech Republic. We commemorate the 600th anniversary of the burning of the important church reformer Master Jan Hus. Honor his memory! However, I want to talk about another topic. I have mentioned several times the Czech Law on Electronic Communications, which, in the opinion of most experts, harms the rights of consumers, citizens who use the services of mobile operators. In the opinion of experts, the law is contrary to the Universal Service Directive. I drew the Commission's attention to this in my written observations. Now it turns out in practice that a particular operator in the Czech Republic abused this amendment, abused this law and changed the rules of the game towards citizens and did not ask them at all whether they agreed with it or not. I would therefore like to call on the Commission at this point to look into this and to consider whether the Czech legislation complies with the European Directive.

name: Clara Eugenia Aguilera García (S&D).
text: – Madam President, I would like to bring the voice of two citizen platforms from my city, Granada, and the province of Loja, so it is taking place in relation to the high-speed connection in my region, in Andalusia. This high-speed connection has been carried out by different governments in my country and yet, now that it is in its completion phase, to connect with the eastern part of the region, the high-speed line is completely being altered. It is not being carried out for the city of Granada, but the connection is the railway improvement. But these platforms whose voice I want to bring here today, both from the city of Loja and the city of Granada, are seeing how their demands are not being considered. And these works that are carried out, if not interrupted, will start in two the neighborhoods through which the high-speed line will pass.

name: Jozo Radoš (ALDE).
text: – Madam President, colleagues and colleagues, these days marks the 20th anniversary of the terrible crime that took place in Srebrenica, the most serious crime that took place in Europe after World War II. In those days, those days of July, Bosnian Serb forces killed about 8,000,000 Bosniaks, adult men, boys and children in a zone protected by the United Nations and with the presence of United Nations forces.  Here today, in the European Parliament we pay tribute to the victims and show solidarity with their loved ones. But for the future it is important to establish the truth, to acknowledge responsibility and to bring those who have committed crimes to justice, because this is a prerequisite for understanding, for trust, for cooperation and before that for reconciliation. Therefore, the European Parliament must not have an understanding for attempts to avoid a clear speech on Srebrenica, and I welcome today's decision to open a debate on Thursday and adopt a resolution on Srebrenica.

name: Josu Juaristi Abaunz (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, on 11 June, in the Victor Hugo Chamber of the National Assembly, a standing ovation hosts the Euskal Herria Peace Manifesto just read by Judge Serge Portelli, which gives way to Bertie Ahern's speech. The Paris Peace Conference in Euskal Herria applauded efforts to create conditions for conflict resolution, praised international involvement, URGED ETA to bring its disarmament process to an end, and urged Madrid and Paris to get involved in the process. It also called for an end to the dispersion of prisoners within a reasonable time, the application of prison benefits to the person responsible and the release of seriously ill prisoners. And he encouraged action to provide recognition, compensation and assistance to victims. The text calls on the Spanish and French States not to miss this historic opportunity and to be involved in resolving the conflict, promoting the necessary actions to achieve peace.

name: Karima Delli (Verts/ALE).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Uber is a problem in many European countries. Last Friday, Uber decided to suspend its Uber-Pop app in France. Some already see it as the victory of taxis, which have expressed their anger, and of the state, which has advocated its ban. But this response is only short-lived and cannot be used as an example for neighbouring countries.  The trap would be to avoid any sustainable regulation of this growing sector. Uber and other start-ups have recently shown their speed of decision to take advantage of the blind spots of our legislation and will therefore come back by one means or another. This suspension is therefore only a reprieve for the state and taxi drivers in France. In addition, Uber today announced its intention to invest in driverless cars. This will be a blow to the drivers' profession and therefore to taxis, VTCs and Uber-Pop. To turn a blind eye to this reality is to continue to lie to professionals in the sector, all over Europe. I therefore call on the Commissioner for Transport to act as soon as possible, because a European response to this problem will be needed.

name: Kristina Winberg (EFDD).
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for I would like to raise the issue of the migration situation in the Mediterranean again. What is the EU actually doing to try to prevent people from going on non-seaworthy boats for an uncertain future in Europe? Why do we not hold the governments to account in those countries that, with an irresponsible immigration policy, are luring people to this dangerous journey?  I am thinking, in particular, of my own country, Sweden, where a government with an extremely weak mandate from its own people is pursuing a policy that makes it enough to claim that you are from Syria, you get permanent residence permits. Of course, this leads to widespread cheating among the migrants, but above all it leads to people in the hope of benefiting from Swedish welfare taking great risks and turning to people smugglers. Who is holding the Swedish Government and its co-conspirators to account for this devastating signalling policy?

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Europe is currently experiencing a gigantic invasion of immigrants. By the end of June, Austria had 28,152 more refugees than in the whole of 2014. These crowds pose major problems, especially in terms of localities and finances, but they are also increasingly powerless in coping with the everyday difficulties of cultural differences. So I had to tell the media that there were riots because of the food in a Linz asylum center – cooked by the Linz police kitchen, which also cooks for the policemen. Of course, pork-free cooking is done, and of course this food is also given in accordance with ramadan. There were suicide threats because there were no free tobacco products. There were riots because the clothing issued was obviously not branded. And the population – we also have a lot of poor people in Austria – is, of course, slowly making doubts about the actual need for help. This raises the question of European solidarity, on the one hand, in the reception, but also the question: where is the effective protection of external borders? It is quite understandable that the desire of Europeans to suspend ... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Andor Deli (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I would like to draw attention to the conditions in the port of Calais and at the Eurotunnel freight terminal, where thousands of migrants attempt to cross the English Channel by forceing their way up to the lorries waiting there, endangering the physical integrity of the drivers, damaging the cargo and, in many cases, putting themselves in danger. This clearly threatens the safety of people and the free movement of goods and services. I believe that it is necessary for the European Commission, as the edi clearer of treaties and core values, to act urgently on this issue. Together with more than 20 fellow Members of the People's Party, last week we referred an emergency question to the Commission requiring a written reply and took the initiative to hear a resolution from the Commission already in this plenary session. Unfortunately, it has not been put on the agenda, which is outrageous, because many much less worrying topics are easier to find their way to plenary and to the European Commission.

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, 'lead by example': this is the imperative that every organisation should give itself before proposing virtuous policies to its employees or, in the case of public institutions, to the rest of society. On the issue of gender equality, this good practice is perhaps even more important, given the need to demolish a shared culture that struggles to give women decision-making roles in the coming months.  In the coming months, the Economic and Social Committee will have to be renewed and the issue of correcting an unacceptable situation will be put right: in fact, it leaves no room for the plenary of the European Economic and Social Committee, the body representing civil society, last year forty-six thousand votes were cast by men and only thirteen thousand by women.  They look like marginal things compared to the big events that are overwhelming us these days. Instead, we cannot miss them: we cannot miss opportunities, large or small. It is only by grasping them all that we show in practice that we have really made gender equality a priority.

name: Dariusz Rosati (PPE).
text: – Madam President, last Monday, on 29 June, President Obama signed a Trade Promotion Authority which grants him the power to negotiate international trade agreements and then send them to Congress for a simple up or down vote. The goal of this fast-track mandate is to facilitate the legislative process to avoid amendments or delays so that the often long-lasting negotiations are wrapped up within a few months. While the two most important trade agreements of the Obama administration seem to be the Trans-Pacific Partnership and the Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership (TTIP), it is only the first one that is currently in the spotlight in the US and therefore more likely to be finalised soon. Hence I call on the Commission and the European Parliament to seize this opportunity and move substantially forward with ambitious TTIP negotiations, benefiting from the broad mandate now in President Obama’s hands. This is a great opportunity for Europe that must not be wasted.

name: Laurențiu Rebega (S&D).
text: – Madam President, on 7 August 2015 it is one year since Russia imposed bans on food imports from European Union countries. According to the analyses of financial institutions, at the end of the first year of prohibitions the European Union loses 6.7 billion euros and about 130 000 jobs. In this economic war, Romania is struck twice. If the first effect was that of the loss of export contracts with Russia in the milk processing industry, where production decreased by a quarter compared to the period before the ban, and the pork industry had to lower prices by 25%, accumulating huge losses, Romanian producers also had to cope with the influx of goods coming to the Romanian market from the countries of the European Union , also subject to the same prohibitions. In the context that a decision by Moscow to extend the embargo by at least one year is predictable, the European Union must find a formula to support Romanian producers as soon as possible. In the absence of this support, the forecasts are quite alarming and go as far as the total bankruptcy of the two Romanian production sectors, with disastrous consequences on the fragile balance of the labour market, but also of the Romanian budget.  This is the time when Romanian producers must...  (the President interrupted the speaker)

name: Cristian-Silviu Bușoi (PPE).
text: – Madam President, today the European Commission has published a study on the recruitment and retention policies of medical personnel in Europe. The migation of the health workforce from the central, eastern and, more recently, southern European states, to states such as France, Italy, Germany or the Nordic States due primarily to financial reasons, then better working conditions and access to state-of-the-art medical equipment and technologies, raise awareness of the health systems of these countries of origin and, by implication, , is a risk factor for patient safety. Labour migration in the field of health creates a shortage of health care personnel and, together with unequal access to innovative treatments, financial barriers that block the effective application of the right to cross-border health, shape the European Union of health inequalities. I believe that the time has come for migration and the shortage of medical staff to be put on the European agenda. We need policies to detain medical personnel within the Union and a balance of migration within the Member States.

name: Paul Brannen (S&D).
text: – Madam President, across the EU there has been a growing monopolisation of arable land by large corporate agricultural enterprises – a process referred to as land grabbing. It is edging out small family-run farms and pushing the young out of farming. In the past eight years, around three million farms, or 20% of the total, have been lost in the EU. The entry into the market of these large agri-businesses, particularly in eastern Member States, is causing concern. Fewer and fewer workers are employed, while farming based on monocultures, flex crops and a greater reliance on chemicals and antibiotics has worrying implications for our biodiversity, ecosystems and the richness and variety of EU food cultures. The reasons for land grabbing are complex. However, if left unchallenged, this manifestation of unregulated capitalism will see the landscape of Europe change forever, to the benefit of a few, with the price paid by the many.

name: Tunne Kelam (PPE).
text: – Madam President, the great multitude of national cultures is the common riches of mankind. This is especially true for Tibetan culture. Today we celebrate the 80th birthday of the Tibetan spiritual leader, the Dalai Lama. May it be an occasion to express our solidarity with his nation, their religion and their culture. Dalai Lamas must show peace, nonviolence and compassion, and his call to guarantee the survival of Tibetan identity needs our strongest possible support. His best birthday present would be for Ms Mogherini and EU politicians to mainstream, on all occasions, the demand that the Chinese government guarantee Tibetans genuine autonomy and treat them with the full respect that this unique culture deserves.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D).
text: – Madam President, the Commission has recently provided help to the Hungarian Government in order to manage the flows of migrants entering the country. This aid package includes more than EUR 8 million in financial support. As Commissioner Avramopoulos said, this support comes in a spirit of European solidarity. Meanwhile, the Hungarian Government has conducted a nationwide billboard campaign against migrants, foresees building a 175 km fence on the Hungarian-Serbian border and has led a panic-mongering police action in the refugee camp at Debrecen that has a maximum capacity of 800 persons but is currently hosting 1 900 refugees. As Hungarian Prime Minister Orbán has stated that he does not wish to develop refugee camps – on the contrary, he has promised to close them – what will the EUR 8 million aid be spent on? Will the Commission raise the same question?

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE).
text: – Many countries within the euro area have been hit hard by the financial crisis. In Spain, Portugal, Ireland, responsible governments have put the country at the forefront of party interests, ahead of the interests of individuals - politicians. And these countries have got rid of the worst grip of the crisis. Greece, led by Mr Samaras's government, was also on a similar path. His government paid the price of implementing emergency reforms and lost the election. With the new year, the Greek government took the helm of the leftist Communist Party of Siriza, with the political president, Mr. Cipras, who in six months managed to destroy the progress made by the previous government.  Misleading, frivolous and irresponsible promises and promises of the impossible led to Sunday's referendum, which is a real political Russian roulette that threatens the euro zone, and above all, the social picture in Greece is deteriorating day by day. It is time for sobering and responsible politics, because in this political poker, Mr Cipras cannot be the winner, but they are the losers themselves.

name: Claudia Tapardel (S&D).
text: – Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, it is very clear that the Greek people's choice in Sunday's referendum is for a strengthened European future. In my opinion, our mission is to highlight that the negotiations must continue under the sign of solidarity. If we say "no" to austerity, logically we say "yes" to solidarity. However, economic prosperity and regional security are closely linked to predictability and stability in Greece, and these days are very important.  Given that the greatest contribution to Greece's GDP comes from tourism, solutions to restore confidence in the area must not be delayed, because there is a directly proportional relationship between a sense of security and economic prosperity, especially when we talk about tourism. Many tourists preparing to go to Greece ask questions. Is Greece still a safe zone? Does tourism services still work under the conditions of bank closures? Does public transport, the health care system or the police still work?  The Greek and European authorities must quickly come up with answers to these legitimate questions, and to my call to Mr Junker, Mr Tusk and Mr Schulz, but also to the Greek Government, is to dialogue, solidarity and thrift.

name: n/a
text: Madam President, the President of the European Commission has rightly and repeatedly stressed the importance of dialogue and social consultation. These are essential elements for democracy. Economic and social democracy is protected by tools such as the European Social Charter or ILO conventions. All workers must be able to benefit from these rights. Yet some of them, and moreover, those who have the mission of protecting citizens and democracy, sometimes do not take advantage of all these rights. I am talking here about police officers who, in some Member States, are being undermined and have their right to expression and trade union representation limited. That is not acceptable. Police officers are workers like any other, they must be able to benefit from decent working conditions, support measures, protection of their health and safety, and have the right to speak, like all other workers.

name: Alojz Peterle (PPE).
text: – I would like to tell you the unasutering and non-political news that last week in Slovenia at the age of 86, Mr Slavko Avsenik, a legendary Slovenian musician, died with his brother Vivic and his ensemble for half a century, ousting Slovenia, Europe and the wider world with over 1,000 songs, starting from the Slovenian folk music tradition. His music went to more than 32 million records, and over 10,000 bands play it worldwide. His composition Na Golica is considered to be the most performed track in the world. Tomorrow we will gratefully say goodbye to the man who enriched us with an extremely high-quality and extensive musical oeuvre.

name: La Présidente. –
text: This item on the agenda is closed.

name: La Présidente. –
text: The agenda calls for Jan Zahradil's report, on behalf of the Committee on International Trade, on the external impact of EU trade and investment policy on public-private initiatives in third countries (2014/2233 (INI)) (A8-0182/2015).

name: Jan Zahradil
text: rapporteur. – Madam President, I welcome the opportunity here to present a report which has already been adopted by the Committee on International Trade (INTA), with contributions from the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection (IMCO) and the Committee on Development (DEVE). The report looks into the European Union’s common commercial policy and its impact on so-called public—private partnerships (PPPs). As everybody knows, PPPs are arrangements where the public sector and private sector act together in order to deliver certain types of services of general interest to the public. Those services could be, for instance, infrastructure, like roads, public transport, power plants or water treatment plants. They could also be some kind of social services, like health care or education. Last, but not least, in recent years, they could be realised in the field of innovative high-tech sectors. What is important to stress is that they are not current practice in well—developed countries, but they are becoming more and more important and widely used by donors in developing countries. PPP projects account for roughly 15% to 20% of total infrastructure investments in those countries. The report concentrates mainly on two aspects of PPP projects. One is, of course, the EU’s own interests, which means promotion of EU trade interests. Participating in PPP projects provides EU companies with a great opportunity to grow and to gain new markets, if we take into account the current market conditions, slow economic recovery and the remaining high levels of unemployment in Europe. We can all agree, I hope, that European companies can achieve growth only if they go international and enter other non-European markets. Therefore, we have to build success stories, models and good practices concerning PPPs to encourage our companies to go there. We also have to create things like one-stop shops or user-friendly platforms. We should use the good experiences of institutions already engaged in those projects, like the European Investment Bank and others. At the same time there is another goal, namely pursuing our development agenda. This is a crucial point. I think that we can create synergies with our development objectives by pursuing PPP projects. We all know that massive investments are required in developing countries in terms of infrastructure, energy supply or access to water. A substantial part of this funding will need to come from the private sector, where PPP can play a crucial role. Of course we also have bad examples, particularly in some developing countries where PPPs were in trouble. There were badly designed projects, engineering problems, too much bureaucracy, delays in realisation and poor project management. That is also why it is so important to work towards a common approach to tackling all those challenges. I think that this report could play a positive role in that. This report, I need to stress, does not make any attempt to establish new legislation or bureaucracy or anything like that. It just urges the EU institutions to take the necessary steps on the existing playing field to promote the participation of EU companies in PPP projects. It has been prepared in a spirit of very good cooperation between the political groups and committees. I hope that it will be received as well by the plenary of the European Parliament.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D).
text: – Madam President, public-private partnerships in third countries will have many positive effects on job creation, competitiveness and productivity in Europe. I strongly believe that the European Union trade policy should work towards ensuring market access for EU companies abroad, where they still face substantial barriers in procurement markets. Small and medium-sized enterprises should easily be able to access these standards and make a number of recommendations in this regard, including the formation of consortiums. The legal framework for public partnership programs should be reinforced, with a view to establishing a clear, predictable and legitimate institutional framework supported by competent and well-resourced authorities. Adequate human resources should be ensured to enable the administration to properly design PPPs and oversee their implementation. Efforts should also be made to raise the capacity of public administration in developing countries.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). Madam President, first of all we must point out that the European Union must apply the principle of cohesion to trade, investment and development policies. However, while the European Union has kept public procurement markets open to international competition, Union companies still face barriers abroad. On the other hand, multinational companies in the European Union must work in accordance with the current OECD guidelines.  In addition, the UN guiding principles on business and human rights within and outside the European Union should be applied. Development companies must also ensure that public development funding is not channelled to the various multinationals, but is used to support local economic networks. Finally, if the European Union wants real growth and investment in developing countries, the debts of developing countries to the International Monetary Fund, the World Bank and the African Development Bank must be erased.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE).
text: – Madam President, there is no doubt that a public-private partnership can produce very good results, it can give good effects, especially when it comes to modern infrastructure. There are, of course, negative examples, there are also situations that have not yielded ideal results or have even put some projects in trouble.  However, Mr. Commissioner, please take on an obligation and see one project that stands in the drawers of the European Commission concerning Croatia. It is the construction of the Istrian Y, a road transport route in Istria, Croatia, which is based on a public-private partnership, Croatia and the French company Bouygues. There is no reason why this project should stand, not to be fully realized, because we simply need the construction and completion of the Istrian Road Y, so in this context I ask you to really take the obligation to look at and help keep this project from being blocked in the drawers of the European Commission.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, public-private partnerships today represent a symptom of this model of capitalist integration and a cause of the current crisis for many countries. This model of European integration with a single currency and all budgetary constraints leaves states without room to be able to make public investments, and they are now dependent on large enterprises, not only on large transport infrastructure, but also in key areas such as health, energy, or education.  In Portugal, spending on public-private partnerships grows exponentially, unlike all social expenditures. In other words, austerity is only for some, not for large economic groups, which increasingly benefit from public rents. What is needed is to protect Europe against the openness proposed by the TTIP. It is a question of combating, not extending, the validity of an instrument that has become a cancer for our democracy.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD).
text: – Madam President, when I read the title of the debate, ‘External impact of EU trade and investment policy’, I first expected that we would be talking about the negative impact the EU can have across the world, where our trade policies can impact on the poorest nations. While we help with one hand, we stamp down with our foot at the same time. Then I read through the report and saw that it is all about public-private partnerships. The danger is that, as the experience in the UK shows, they often cannot work, as we have seen in the British NHS. We can see them combine the worst of both worlds, where we get all the inefficiency of the public sector combined with the narrow profit focus of the private sector. We need to remember that there are dangers with this approach and that we need to be relatively cautious. Nevertheless, I would commend the rapporteur specifically on the point that he recognises that these are decisions which must be taken sovereignly by the Member States themselves.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D).
text: – Madam President, I am acting as shadow rapporteur for the S&D Group and first of all I would like to thank the rapporteur for this report's attitude, which is collaborative and participatory. But we Socialists are advocing for a reform of the legal system that precisely minimizes the risks that public-private partnerships, or IPPs, may have, as they are known by their acronym. We believe that an PPP should never be chosen because it is a method that accountingly benefits the Administration by not computing in deficit, but because it is the best way to provide a public service in the most efficient and cheapest way possible, and for this it is essential that risk transfer is redefined very well. We will never support a model of public-private collaboration that allows economic benefits to be privatized and losses to be socialized through public coffers. Never should an PPP be a first step towards the privatization of a public service, and that is why we want a very clear, very transparent legal framework that also provides resources to administrations: technical and financial.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR).
text: – Madam President, Europe must strive to develop quality public services within its borders, but also with its international partners. Raising the quality of life of citizens must be one of our top priorities, and the only way to achieve this, with the obligatory responsibility when managing taxpayers' money, is to encourage private capital entry into projects of public interest. The growing external debt of most countries and the apparent lack of money for infrastructure projects open up space for the popularisation of public-private partnership both inside and outside the European Union. Popularising this model in partner countries is an opportunity for European SMEs to expand their businesses and boost exports of goods and services.  I therefore call on the Commission to ensure equal treatment of our companies in public procurement procedures and open access to public-private partnerships under all trade agreements signed by the European Union with third countries.

name: Phil Hogan
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I am here tonight representing Commissioner Malmström, our Trade Commissioner, and she would like to thank the rapporteur Mr Zahradil and the Committee on International Trade (INTA) for their valuable work on this report. The report underlines the high importance of public-private partnerships as a tool for economic growth, innovation and job creation. This has been the case in the EU and is increasingly true in our neighbourhood and in developing countries further afield. The report also underlines the opportunity provided by EU Trade and Investment Policy in negotiations to promote public-private partnerships in third countries and thereby increase the market access of EU companies in this area. The Commission welcomes the report’s call for improved transparency and fair competition in public-private partnerships in international trade relations. We will continue to strengthen efforts to include public-private partnerships to the greatest extent possible within the government procurement chapter of international trade agreements. Indeed, there are many points expressed in the report with which the Commission fully agrees and certainly welcomes. I want to give you some examples. Firstly, that public-private partnerships can foster innovative solutions and mobilise long-term private finance, facilitating complex projects in the public interest, notably in the infrastructure sector or other capital-intensive sectors. Secondly, that cooperation between the private and public sectors can foster innovation, research and development through increased competition. Thirdly, the importance of facilitating the participation of SMEs in public—private partnerships. Finally, PPPs give opportunities abroad, which can increase European companies’ market access in government procurement in countries outside the EU and redress the asymmetry between EU and other countries’ levels of openness in government procurement. At the same time, these represent great opportunities for developing countries to create wealth and develop the infrastructures that are needed for business. The Commission had welcomed the references in the rapporteur’s draft report to the positive synergies of public procurement and investment protection policies. In this regard, the Commission would have preferred a more explicit acknowledgment of the need to employ the EU’s investment policy to ensure that assets invested by EU investors in the context of long—term projects in third countries are effectively protected, including by negotiating adequate and impartial means of resolving potential problems. The Commission will be taking careful note of all of the recommendations made in this report and will continue to strengthen its efforts to ensure that the opportunities provided by PPPs can be best utilised. Be assured also that I will pass the comments that you make today to my colleague Cecilia Malmström who, as I mentioned, is the Commissioner in charge.

name: La Présidente. –
text: The point is closed. The vote will take place on Tuesday, July 7, 2015 at 1 p.m. Written statements (Article 162)

name: Dita Charanzová (ALDE)
text: in writing. – As the Rapporteur of the IMCO opinion and ALDE INTA shadow rapporteur, I welcome the very good and balanced message sent by this report. The key point for me has been to focus on how to improve Public Private Partnership projects and how to support the work of European companies in foreign and developing markets. I believe we have achieved this. PPPs are a major potential source of growth for our European companies and in the case of development PPPs, a way that our European companies can help to do good works in the world. We have to work to encourage fair and transparent access to external PPPs for our firms. This is especially true for our SMEs, who should be encouraged to take part in the sub-contracting chain or as part of consortiums. The EU and our Member States must be more proactive in our trade and investment policies on PPPs. This should be clear in our agreements with third countries. I ask the Commission to also work to increase the use of PPPs in our EU development aid policy. PPPs could be an effective way to spend development aid while allowing our limited budgets to go further.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – The PPP strategy as a mechanism mainly designed and used as a tool for market access, deregulation and liberalization of public services and public procurement in third countries, especially developing countries, and to divert development founds to private companies must be rejected. There is a link between PPPs and the risk of debt unsustainability. PPPs are often the way to transfer the risk from rich private companies to taxpayers in poor countries. A binding framework which ensures that EU companies contribute to a socially inclusive growth and are accountable for their actions in developing countries as regards standards in respect of human rights, social protection, gender equality, decent work, union rights, environmental protection, universal access to quality goods and public services, paying particular attention to public services is needed.

name: La Présidente. –
text: The agenda calls for Nuno Melo's report, on behalf of the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development, on the fruit and vegetable sector since the 2007 reform (2014/2147(INI)) (A8-0170/2015).

name: Nuno Melo
text: Rapporteur. – Madam President, Commissioner, as soon as the late hour already justifies, I would like to say the importance of this report, given that there are around 1 600 producer organisations recognised in 23 Member States. There are large differences in the rate of organisation between Member States, but they reflect different starting points, and which therefore cannot justify the failure of policies. Increasing the organisational rate should remain a priority for the fruit and vegetables scheme.  The Commission's report and a study by Wageningen University draw attention to the lack of legal certainty, which is a significant obstacle to the development of POs, and I welcome D'Hogan's commitment to simplifying the fruit and vegetable regime.  We also draw attention to the need for funds to address the management of producer organisations. In direct contact with many of your representatives, we realize that there is a lack of qualified managers, and the fact that you are a capable producer does not mean that you are a good manager. And therefore, easing the organizations of producers of funds that allow to hire capable managers is a novelty that I would bring to this report. There also seems to be a consensus that crisis prevention and management tools are not being used sufficiently, and it is good to see that crises can arise not only because of market conditions, but also less often because of health problems or even for political reasons as in the recent case of the Russian embargo. We know that farmers are not at the root of the political crisis with Russia, and for this reason the European Union must continue to support all sectors suffering the consequences of the embargo.  In the report I also call on the Commission to step up its efforts to protect farmers from the unfair commercial practices of large retailers, large areas, which crush and impose prices which often make activity and, consequently, the association of producers unattractive. And one of the problems for which I have tried to draw much attention in the European Parliament has to do with the need to renew agriculture generationally, to ensure that the younger ones see agriculture as an activity that is appealing. So this report draws attention to the fact that only 7.5 % of farmers in the European Union are under 35 years of age. If producer organisations are more effective and more attractive, younger people will certainly find an alternative to their lives there as well. It would be a great deal, Madam President, that I would have to say about this report, but, as I said, the night is going long, the hearing is no longer overwhelming either, and certainly that, if not, tomorrow in the vote we will try to assert our views.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE).
text: – Madam President, first of all, I congratulate Representative Nuno Mel on an excellent report and I think it is necessary to simplify European and national procedures for setting up producer organisations and also to reduce the administrative burden imposed on them.  It is also important to increase the overall level of support to producer organisations and give a greater incentive to set them up, as the purpose of the merger is to increase competition and higher earnings for farmers, and as far as we can see, the realisation of this goal is so far absent.  The rate of organisation remains low and producer organisations are small and only a limited number of fruit and vegetable producers are members of the producer organisation. Therefore, most producers are excluded from the direct benefits provided by the European Union regime, and on the other hand fruit and vegetable imports are growing, domestic fruit and vegetable producers are exposed to unfair competition and unfair trading practices.  The procedure is too complicated, the same situation is in Croatia, so I call on the Ministry of Agriculture to adopt a national program and provide Croatian farmers with a better regime.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D).
text: – Madam President, to strengthen the position of producer organisations (POs) in the supply chain by creating incentives for mergers, associations and transnational cooperation is a very important action that we must support.  Producer organisations have become essential for European cultural policy and should be encouraged to develop at all levels, especially in Member States where the number of organisations is still low. I believe that POs could be effective tools to combat unfair trading practices in the food chain, ensuring better remuneration for growers. The fruit and vegetable sector has been severely hit by the Russian ban on EU exports, and this will continue next year, as Russia will extend the ban to 2016. I believe that the EU should continue all the support measures for this sector until the normal market situation is fully re-established, but the European Union should also continue to impose sanctions against Russia.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). Madam President, the Greek producers of fruit and vegetables, although they have been badly damaged by the Russian embargo, nevertheless took crumbs as compensation. Also, the poor Greek fruit and vegetable producers have suffered enormous damage to their production this year because of the natural disasters that have hit my country. At the same time, they continue to be exploited by the greats. The troika, with its proposals, dissolves the primary sector in Greece and calls for the abolition, firstly, of special schemes for farmers and, secondly, of refunds on motor oil, while promoting an increase in the tax rates on farmers' profits, all although the income of Greek farmers has been reduced by one and a half billion euros and the taxes paid have increased by 150%. Particular support should therefore be given to the fruit and vegetable sector in Greece, as without this aid it is extremely difficult to support and move forward with new fruit and vegetable producers.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE).
text: - Madam President, Dear Mr. Rapporteur, I would like to draw your attention in some way to the two elements you presented in your report, which are particularly close to me. Namely, your ambition that Europe must play the quality and quality standards of fruit and vegetable products, fruit and vegetable products and all that makes up the sector, I think is something that is crucial.  I would like you to include here, in any case, authenticity, i.e. autochthonousness, i.e. protected European products in the field of fruits and vegetables, i.e. their originality. I think it's something europe can play as strongly as a winning card.  And the second theme is young. It is your great desire to include young people in the agriculture sector. I think it's our great need for our agriculture to really have a good future, as it has so far.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, the situation is paradoxical. We have a decline in agricultural areas for fruit and vegetable production, but we have a consumption that continues to decline and is below who recommendations in some countries. We really have a model where large multinationals in the food sector continue to determine the diet of our young people today.  Producer organisations are key. We continue to advocate greater flexibility for their recognition, depending on the specific reality of each region. On the other hand, more support is needed, as well as the extension of eligible expenditure, in order to create conditions for its sustainability. However, it is good to say that we cannot feed into the illusion that it will be possible with greater POs to be able to deal with the serious problems of the sector, such as the dominance of large distribution. In this sense, we continue to maintain great reservations in the face of the trend, this trend of complete liberalisation of the CAP, which continues to bet on market solutions that will not bring anything good to our farmers.

name: Jordi Sebastià (Verts/ALE).
text: – Madam President, first of all I would like to congratulate the rapporteur, Mr Melo, on his excellent work. This report, which is very important to us, makes it very clear what are the two main problems in the fruit and vegetable sector. On the one hand, unfair competition from third countries that produce with environmental and social conditions that are not allowed in Europe, and to whose products we allow entry. And, on the other hand, the pressure of the large distribution chains, which suffocate the producer and pay him prices of misery. The sector is mainly located in southern Europe and is very threatened, even though we are in deficit in fruit and vegetable production. This report makes it very clear that urgent action must be taken, because other words, land will continue to be abandoned and youth will continue to flee the camp. Southern farmers feel abandoned by Europe, and rightly so. Mr Hogan, Commissioner, you were in my country until recently, you were in Valencia; saw the excellent work that the producers and cooperatives that they have constituted do. That work will go bust if those two problems are not urgently solved.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD).
text: – Madam President, I will not dwell on the common agricultural policy in general, beyond the simple point that, as a UKIP MEP, naturally I believe these matters could be dealt with better by the Member States themselves. I will, however, mention three points specifically from the report. Firstly, I commend the rapporteur for saying that simpler is best. The simpler a system is, the easier it is for farmers. Secondly, I agree with the rapporteur that there is a crisis in farming. I have seen this personally over the last couple of weeks, speaking to young people and seeing the attitudes towards farming and the number of people who are not getting involved in farming. It is a massive problem. Thirdly, the report mentions children not eating enough fruit and vegetables. I would suggest that governments should be doing more in that respect. There is, though, a danger of too much of a top-down approach. We have seen that where schools start policing what is put in children’s lunchboxes, this can cause hostility and become counterproductive. So, in keeping with the theme of this debate, I would suggest that the approach we need is carrot, not stick.

name: Phil Hogan
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I wish to thank Mr Melo for his report. It certainly offers me an opportunity to briefly address some of the issues that have been raised in relation to fruit and vegetables here. The Russian import ban has been mentioned by a number of speakers in respect of European fruit and vegetables. It once again highlights the vulnerability of the sector, where surpluses of perishable products can cause large market disturbances and falling producer prices. I am examining this issue at the moment to see what can be done to assist producers. It also shows the importance of strong producer organisations to collectively deal with such unexpected and adverse situations. The current CMO regulation offers the tools for strengthening their bargaining position vis-à-vis major retailers, as well as through production planning, innovation, and crisis prevention and management measures. Therefore I welcome Mr Melo’s report as a contribution to the debate on how producer organisations can be strengthened even further to become even more efficient and also more attractive to both current and future members. The EU fruit and vegetable regime is certainly on the Commission’s political agenda. President Juncker has asked me to focus on reviewing this potential for further simplification within the first 12 months of our mandate. This meets one of the main requests of this report, which is to increase the attractiveness of producer organisations by increasing legal certainty and reducing the administrative burden. Throughout this year the Commission will carry out a simplification exercise regarding the fruit and vegetable rules that are contained in the Commission-level legislation. This will improve the functioning of the scheme and provide a clearer legal framework. However, we foresee no changes to the basic act this year. Producer organisations and their operational programmes thus remain a cornerstone of the regime. The issue of an increase in the overall level of support to producer organisations and to APOs, which requires a change in the basic act, will not be addressed as part of this simplification exercise, where we are concentrating on secondary legislation. Unfair trading practices in the food supply chain are also on our agenda, as you know. For abuses of relative bargaining power, or unfair trading practices as they are known, there is currently no regulatory framework at EU level, but a large number of Member States have now begun to regulate the issue at national level, particularly in the United Kingdom and Spain. I will continue to work with Ms Bieńkowska, who is the Commissioner for the Internal Market, Industry, Entrepreneurship and SMEs and the lead Commissioner on this issue, in order to address issues that have been brought to the attention of this House tonight, and on other occasions, relating to unfair trading practices. The Commission has asked the food chain to agree on a self-regulatory mechanism at EU level for the moment. All food chain representatives agreed on a list of principles of good practice in contractual relations as far back as 2011. Furthermore, key stakeholders have been implementing an EU-wide voluntary scheme, the Supply Chain Initiative, since the end of 2013, but regrettably not all actors in the food chain are participating at the moment. The Commission will make an assessment of existing national and EU work streams and unfair practices at the end of this year and come to conclusions about where to go from there. Let me welcome again the European Parliament’s initiative and Mr Melo’s report, which will of course further enrich the ongoing debate regarding the reform that is required in the fruit and vegetables regime.

name: La Présidente. –
text: The point is closed. The vote will take place on Tuesday, July 7, 2015 at 1 p.m. Written statements (Article 162)

name: Julia Pitera (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – The aim of the reform in 2007 was to provide fruit and vegetable producer organisations with the tools to effectively address potential market crises and to improve quality and competitiveness while taking care of the environment. The conditions created encourage producers to come together and establish international cooperation. It is not insignificant that organisations can set up an operational fund derived from contributions from their members and from EU financial assistance.  A number of indicators demonstrate that the policy in the fruit and vegetables sector was justified. However, these effects do not apply to all Member States. In less modernised regions, the organisation rate remains low and producer organisations are small both in terms of the number of producer members and the total value of market production.  Therefore, in order to encourage producers to set up organisations, administrative procedures need to be simplified, bureaucratic burdens reduced, organisationally supported and clear control rules put in place. Indeed, differences in levels of modernisation and bureaucratic nuisance are certainly one of the more serious reasons why the largest producer organisations (around 18% of all producer organisations with a turnover in excess of EUR 20 million) receive around 70% of the financial assistance from their support.

name: Laurențiu Rebega (S&D)
text: in writing. – I strongly support the report on the request to the Commission for greater support for the organisation of the fruit and vegetable sector in producer organisations. We are all aware that in some countries, particularly in Eastern Europe, the average degree of organisation among producers is below the European average, which causes significant regional imbalances. If the Commission does not take appropriate measures and does not take into account the rules that are sometimes too complex for some countries that are only at the beginning of the organisation phase in the OP, this imbalance situation could adversely affect all European producers who are already facing problems because of the Russian embargo. The Commission must therefore encourage and further support the association of producers in Eastern European countries by a major simplification of the rules laid down to create oPs.

name: La Présidente. –
text: The agenda calls for the Dieter-Lebrecht Koch report, on behalf of the Committee on Transport and Tourism, on the creation of an integrated multimodal ticketing system in Europe (2014/2244(INI)) (A8-0183/2015).

name: Dieter-Lebrecht Koch
text: Rapporteur. Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has done What is the best way to get from Weimar to Lisbon? Despite the Internet even today, it is not an easy question to answer. The needs of travellers are very different. Some want to get to their destination as quickly as possible, others want to travel in the most sustainable way possible, and others are interested as tourists in choosing a well-worth seeing itinerary. Existing online travel planning services usually offer only a very limited range of travel options, which relate only to a few modes of transport and often only to travel within a Member State. Unfortunately, therefore, citizens keep coming back to their own cars as a travel alternative. Our aim should be to promote multimodal travel and to achieve seamless door-to-door transport with a single ticket, not only within a region, but across borders. Within my report, we are making specific demands to overcome the existing obstacles and difficulties on the way to EU-wide multimodal travel information, travel planning and ticketing services. Travellers need to be provided with a wide range of information that will give them a real choice between the different connections. Fair and equal access to real-time travel information is an important first step. Particular attention must be taken to the specific needs of persons with reduced mobility and of the elderly. Local and regional authorities need to be aware of their important role for the first leg of a journey – that is, the way from the front door – and the last section to the destination address. Without the networking of local and long-distance traffic, nothing can be done here. And national roadmap information systems need to be cross-border. Clear and transparent passenger rights for multimodal travel should also be defined. These do not exist at all today. Due to this legal uncertainty, travelling with different modes of transport is still unattractive. We must therefore significantly increase the attractiveness of multimodal travel, because they not only provide an efficient solution to existing congestion, but also promote sustainability, economic efficiency, energy efficiency and tourism in Europe. That is why we expect the Commission to provide a framework that concerns, at least once, the first step, that is, access to travel information. As far as ticketing services are concerned, the Commission should leave it to the sector itself to find appropriate solutions. However, unless significant progress can be made by 2020, it must take legislative action. Travellers should be given access to real-time information on possible disruptions, as well as on alternative travel options, both before and during the journey. Of course, a high level of data protection must be guaranteed in all processes. Finally, I would like to express my sincere thanks to the shadow rapporteurs. They enabled broad cross-party support for the proposals in the Committee on Transport and Transport. We can now put these proposals on the way to industry and the European Commission. I now very much hope for support in plenary and I would like to thank all my colleagues and my assistant, Mrs Cezara Petruc, in advance. Thank you very much!

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D).
text: – Madam President, it is very important that we call on Member States to share timetables and fare information and develop intermodal ticketing services. Service providers should build on existing synergies and cooperate more closely on providing multimodal, cross-border journey planners. The Commission should support and facilitate the efforts being made to develop international ticketing, and if no significant progress is made to develop intermodal ticketing by 2020, we will call for legislative action. Updated national timetable and fare information systems should be based on open interfaces linking regional and local urban public transport data, linked by 2024 on a cross-border basis and made accessible to operators, providers of journey planners and consumers.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). Madam President, the upgrading of European transport must be done in the light of the passenger and, as the report shows, the proper provision of valid information is the first step along this path.  However, in order to achieve multimodal travel, both in the transport and tourism sectors, we must make them more competitive. As far as the transport sector is concerned, the system of reservations and purchases on the internet should be simpler and more manageable than all ages, especially the elderly. Reduced prices should also be provided for people with disabilities and the elderly and greater attention should be paid to their specific requirements. As regards the tourism sector, the reservation system should be available in all the official languages of the European Union and reduced prices should be provided for students, unemployed and long-term families. Finally, the multimodal travel ticket could be included in the tourist holiday packages with the aim of attracting tourists even more.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE).
text: – Madam President, respected Commissioner Bulc, respected colleagues, would first ask Mr. Koch for excellent cooperation in drafting this document. There are three reasons why further efforts need to be made to implement multimodal integrated systems, both by the Commission and member states. The first is to use the modern IT technology at our disposal and to enable quick and easy booking and purchase of tickets for various types of transport that should complement each other instead of unfair competition. In this way, through IT, we will create new jobs.  The second reason is direct savings in energy consumption, which enables the transport sector to contribute very quickly to the climate-energy goals of the European Union and at affordable costs. The third reason is to protect the rights of EU citizens by issuing a single travel ticket and achieving mobility as a precondition for exercising their fundamental freedoms.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD).
text: – Madam President, the rapporteur mentions in the report the individual choice to travel by car. I would just mention that for a lot of people it is more a necessity than a choice. I could mention myself. To travel from my flat to my office is a 35— or 40-minute drive, but it would take four or five hours on public transport, so by the time I got there it would almost be time to come home again. For many people that is an issue, and we should focus as well on trying to make cars more efficient, with a carrot – and not a stick – approach. In terms of cross-border cooperation, this is great for countries which share a land border. It is great for countries where people are moving from one country to the other on a day-to-day basis. It will help them a lot, but I would just ask you to remember that the UK is pretty much an island, and so for the UK the cost of administering such a scheme and the harmonisation costs are very likely to exceed the benefits.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE).
text: Madam President, Dear Madam Commissioner, I know your job is not easy and thank you for joining us at such a late time. It is important to us that you are here because it means one type of guarantee that the Commission will really try to fully establish this system of multimodal integrated ticketing and airfare systems. What I want to warn the respected Ms. Bulc about is tourism, as a sector that is of utmost importance for many countries of the European Union, especially those in the south of the European Union, and it is in this part, if we manage to do a good job, I think tourism will really become even more competitive. That's why I think it's very important that we have fair and fair access to ticket prices. Today, it is much easier to achieve this over the Internet. It is important to include public transport in this story, and on the other hand, I want to invite you to exchange good practices within the European Union.

name: Violeta Bulc
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, the Commission would like to thank Mr Koch and the members of the Committee on Transport and Tourism for the really excellent work on this report, particularly as it highlights just how important multimodal travel information and services are for all of our citizens across the European Union. We also fully share the report’s emphasis on the end user and expected societal benefits. This is very much in line with the spirit and objective of the digital single market agenda promoted by the Commission. We need all the information we can get to deliver on key European transport policy goals, for instance in terms of reducing the environmental impact and increasing safety and security as well as enhancing the competitiveness of the European transport sector for the benefit of jobs and growth. Achieving all these goals has to be made compatible with the evolving mobility needs of society, notably urban mobility. The expected social benefits of more comprehensive multimodal travel information services are manifold and include better modal integration and more flexibility in case of disruptions. Ultimately, this information service contributes to efficiency gains in overall transport system management and in transport operations for both passengers and freight. For these services, the quality of the underlying data layer is a key aspect because it allows the provision of accurate and complete information to the end user. With the objective of setting a framework facilitating market—driven developments, notably in the field of ticketing, the Commission has already taken a number of these initiatives. The market shaped by people for people should offer travellers complete and reliable information on various travel options which is displayed in a neutral way, not biased by any communication or commercial interest or restricted according to the traveller’s geographical location. Particular attention should be given to symptoms of unfairness and disloyal competition. In the case of data related to road traffic and road infrastructure, mechanisms for sharing that data amongst public and private shareholders are being implemented in the Member States. However, the same cannot be said for travel information, as has already been pointed out. Accessible and available good—quality multimodal travel data that this interoperable and high quality is lacking so far. Timetables across the modes, as identified by Parliament, are one of the key data elements. In this context, the implementation of the ITS Directive provides the opportunity for the Commission to promote fair and equal access to data, an aim which also underpins different existing initiatives. By definition this is a cornerstone for creating a sound framework for better services and an essential element for a level playing field among service providers. The Commission welcomes action by the Member States targeted at improving the interoperability of ticketing systems, including across borders, as well as public sector initiatives enabling stakeholders to share market opportunities and improve service management, like the smart ticketing alliance for public transport and the full service model in the rail sector. Let me stress that the Commission fully agrees with Parliament’s assessment that the provision of information should be tailored to the needs of all travellers, including persons with reduced mobility. Another important point concerns transparent market conditions and fair and non-discriminatory access to the market, as well as a clear definition of the rights of the end users: consumer protection, data protection and privacy. This would greatly benefit the provision of more and better services. Finally, on passengers’ rights in the multimodal context, let me inform you that the Commission is currently addressing this issue, preparing an impact assessment of the various options to ensure that all passengers can fully and equally benefit from their rights.

name: La Présidente. –
text: The point is closed. The vote will take place on Tuesday, July 7, 2015 at 1 p.m. Written statements (Article 162)

name: Olga Sehnalová (S&D)
text: Writing. – Mr President, Commissioner, first of all, I would like to thank the rapporteur for a very good job. I welcome the ongoing efforts to make public transport more attractive. People using public transport plan a door-to-door journey. Unfortunately, there is currently no system that would allow the purchase of one ticket for the entire thoughtful route. It is often necessary to search very difficult for information about connections, connections and price. A clear framework is therefore needed to support the efforts of all stakeholders and competent authorities in order to make substantial progress in this area. The main benefit of unifying check-in systems should be the ease of providing information to all groups of residents, including people with reduced mobility and mobility, searching for multimodal routes in real time and purchasing a single ticket for the entire intended route. For this reason, I will support this report.

name: Claudia Tapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. – European transport policy faces a number of challenges, which invite us to reflect on how we ensure the mobility of European citizens.  Progress towards the objectives we set in 2011 in the White Paper on Transport is extremely slow. The draft report on the integrated issuance of multimodal tickets brings us closer to achieving a White Paper objective, namely facilitating uninterrupted multimodal travel, "from gate to gate". By providing a multimodal travel planning and ticketing service, we respond to the challenges of decarbonisation, digitisation and empowerment of those industries that depend on an efficient transport system, such as tourism.  Integrating modes of transport into a digital platform that can provide real-time information to users will facilitate the transfer of traffic to public transport and the sharing of vehicles. Multimodal services will also benefit Europe's border areas and hard-to-reach areas, undoubtedly contributing to the development of tourism.  The future-oriented European transport system is the one that provides the passenger with an integrated mobility experience and service without physical or digital barriers.
